## Adding an Assessment Using Assessment Builder {#adding_an_assessment_using_assessment_builder}

To create an assessment from scratch using the assessment builder:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Click on **Add**.
3.  Enter an assessment title.
4.  Ensure the \"Create using assessment builder\" option is selected.
5.  Click on **Create**.
6.  Add questions to the assessment by selecting a question type next to
    \"Add Question\".
    -   Depending on the question type you selected, you\'ll need to
        enter items like answer point value, question text, correct
        answers, and feedback.
    -   Click on **Save** when you\'re done editing the question.
7.  Continuing adding questions.
8.  Once all questions have been added and you\'ve reviewed your work,
    you can proceed to the \"Settings\" area and publish the assessment.
    For more help with these options, please visit the [See Available
    Settings](See_Available_Settings "wikilink") and [Publish an
    Assessment](Publish_an_Assessment "wikilink") pages.

## Adding an Assessment Using Markup Text {#adding_an_assessment_using_markup_text_1}

*Before following the steps below, format your text file by following
the [Format Questions for Markup
Text](Format_Questions_for_Markup_Text "wikilink") instructions.*

To create an assessment from scratch using markup text:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Click on **Add**.
3.  Enter an assessment title.
4.  Select the \"Create using markup text\" option.
5.  Click on **Create**.
6.  Outside of Isidore, open the formatted text file that contains the
    questions, point values, correct answers, and answer choice options.
    -   Select all of the text by highlighting it.
    -   Copy all of the text.
7.  In Isidore, click into the text box and paste the text you copied
    into it.
8.  Click on **Next**.
9.  Review your questions, answers, and point value to ensure no
    corrections need made. If corrections are needed, click on the
    **Back** button near the bottom of the page. If everything looks
    good, click on the **Create Assessment** button.
10. A draft of the newly created assessment should appear on the screen.
    You can proceed to the \"Settings\" area and publish the assessment.
    For more help with these options, please visit the [See Available
    Settings](See_Available_Settings "wikilink") and [Publish an
    Assessment](Publish_an_Assessment "wikilink") pages.

## Importing an Assessment from a File {#importing_an_assessment_from_a_file_1}

*Before following the steps below, please review the [Export an
Assessment](Export_an_Assessment "wikilink") page.*

To import an assessment from a file:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Click on **Add**.
3.  Click on **Import**.
4.  Click on **Choose File** or **Browse\...**.
5.  Navigate to where the exported-assessment file is saved on your
    computer, select it, and click on **Open**.
6.  Click on **Import**.
7.  A draft of the newly imported assessment should appear on the
    screen. You can proceed to the \"Settings\" area and publish the
    assessment. For more help with these options, please visit the [See
    Available Settings](See_Available_Settings "wikilink") and [Publish
    an Assessment](Publish_an_Assessment "wikilink") pages.

## Adding Fields {#adding_fields}

To add a field to calendar events:

1.  Navigate to the **Calendar** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click **Add/Edit Fields**.
3.  Next to \"Field Name:\", type a name for your custom field, and then
    click **Create Field**.
4.  Click **Save Field Changes**.

## Removing Fields {#removing_fields}

To remove a field from calendar events:

1.  Navigate to the **Calendar** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click **Add/Edit Fields**.
3.  From the list of custom fields, in the \"Remove?\" column, check the
    box next to any fields that you wish to remove, and then click
    **Save Field Changes**. When prompted to confirm if you wish to
    remove the field, click **Save Field Changes** to continue.

## Adding a teaching assistant to a section {#adding_a_teaching_assistant_to_a_section}

Once you have assigned a site member the role of teaching assistant, you
may assign the teaching assistant to a section.

1.  In the relevant course site, click **Section Info**.
2.  Under the section in which you wish to add a teaching assistant,
    click **Assign TAs**.
3.  From the list of participants, select the participant you wish to
    add, and click the right arrow to move the name to the box on the
    right.
4.  When you are finished, click **Assign TAs**.

3.  Expand the **Learning Apps** section by clicking on the heading.
4.  Check the box next to **Online MID**.
5.  Click on **Continue**.
6.  Click on **Finish**.
7.  The Online MID tool will now appear in the left-hand course menu.

It is the responsibility of the instructor to:

-   Communicate to students that the online MID is available as a menu
    choice in the Isidore course web site.
-   Turn off the online MID (by clicking the Settings button) - after a
    sufficient amount of time has passed. This will stop the tool from
    accepting student comments and release the feedback for the
    instructor to review.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Online MID](Online_MID "wikilink")

`     ``<text bytes="1407" sha1="rf76ry8ugwsbjhzl69f6f7v0i16wawu" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`To adjust settings for a threaded discussion:`

1.  Navigate to the Threaded Discussion tool in the Lessons pages of
    your Isidore site.
2.  Click on **Settings**.
3.  Adjust the available settings:
    -   Discussion title override - display a custom title for the
        discussion (instead of \"Threaded Discussion\")
    -   Give a 100% grade for a student making a post or a comment -
        gives students a 100% grade if they make a thread or comment.
        **NOTE: Grading should be enabled when the Threaded Discussion
        learning app is installed, as it can\'t be enabled after the
        fact.** **Currently, students will only receive points when they
        reply to a thread, not for creating a new thread.** Read more on
        the [Grade a Threaded
        Discussion](Grade_a_Threaded_Discussion "wikilink") page.
    -   Put comment box before comments in thread display - puts an
        empty comment box on the top of the threads page (instead of the
        bottom)
    -   Allowed depth of nested comments - adjusts how many levels of
        nested replies there can be (default is 2)
    -   Due date - set a due date for threads and replies
    -   Time zone - set your timezone
    -   Penalty time period - penalty deduction is calculated by each
        time period that passes (in seconds, specified by the
        instructor)
    -   Penalty deduction - percentage of points deducted per penalty
        time period (specified by the instructor)
4.  Click on **Save changes**.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Threaded
Discussion](Threaded_Discussion "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="2516" sha1="khn0rb2xmltj5wjxp9u35vi7q0brzen" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`The re-entry feature gives individual students the ability to re-enter the assessment for a specified period of time, while preserving their previously saved responses. Students may revisit questions they previously answered (if the default setting of returning to previous pages is allowed), change their responses, and finish answering questions. The student may either submit their assessment manually, or their assessment will be submitted automatically by the system when the specified time limit is reached or the due date occurs. The feature is available to instructors from the Scores page in Tests & Quizzes. `

*Please note that if this feature is used, the student\'s new submission
will need to be regraded and any previously entered feedback comments
may be overwritten.*

Below is a 1-minute video demonstration of this feature.
\<youtube\>jHmao6NcNdI\</youtube\>

How to allow re-entry:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Open the Scores page by clicking on the number in the \"Submitted\"
    column or by clicking on **Actions** and selecting **Scores** next
    to the assessment you wish to allow students to re-enter.
3.  Click on the **Allow retake/re-entry** link next to the student\'s
    name. This link will not show up if students have additional
    submissions remaining (or if the link has already been clicked to
    allow a retake or re-entry).
4.  Click on the **Re-enter** button.
5.  Specify the additional amount of time students should receive during
    re-entry (in hours and minutes). If you leave the setting defaulted
    to \"00\", then the student\'s re-entry will be untimed and will be
    submitted when the specified due date/time occur.
6.  Specify the date and time the student\'s submission is due.
7.  Click on **Save & Reopen**.
8.  The student will now be allowed to re-enter the assessment.

A couple of notes about re-entry:

-   You\'ll want to let students know that their re-entry is setup, as
    there are no automated features that alert them.
-   If you\'re using a time limit for re-entry, don\'t be alarmed if the
    time limit for a student\'s exception changes from what you
    originally set it to. The system accounts for the time the student
    originally spent in the assessment to properly set the student\'s
    re-entry time.
-   If you need to modify the student\'s re-entry time limit or due
    date, you can adjust their exception by following the steps on the
    [Setup Extended Time
    Assessments](Setup_Extended_Time_Assessments "wikilink") page.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Tests and
Quizzes](Tests_and_Quizzes "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

## Adding your Teaching Assistant to your Site {#adding_your_teaching_assistant_to_your_site}

To add your teaching assistant to your site:

1.  Navigate to the **Site Info** tool of your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **Add Participants**.
3.  Click on **Yes** when asked whether participants have an official UD
    email address.
4.  Enter your TA\'s UD username or ID number in the text box.
5.  Click on **Continue**.
6.  Select **TA-Grading** from the \"Role\" column next to the TA\'s
    name.
7.  Choose whether or not to send an email letting them know they\'ve
    been added to the site.
8.  Click on **Finish**.

## Granting Permission to Grade in Gradebook {#granting_permission_to_grade_in_gradebook}

To give your teaching assistant permission to grade in Gradebook:

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **Permissions**.
3.  Click on the **Select a grader** drop-down and click on a TA\'s
    name.
    -   We recommend allowing the grader to see the course grade and
        grade in all sections/groups.
    -   Optional: To give other TAs access, click on **Add Rule** and
        repeat these steps.
4.  If you\'re finished adding rules and granting access to TAs, click
    on **Save Changes**.
5.  Once the TA is added to your site with the TA-Grading role, they\'ll
    be able to grade in the Gradebook.

If you have any questions about this, please contact the Center for
Online Learning via (937) 229-5039 or <onlinelearning@udayton.edu>. \<br
/\>\<br /\> Return to main [Gradebook](Gradebook "wikilink") page

    email address.

    be able to grade in the Assignments tool.

## Allow Resubmission (Student has submitted the assignment) {#allow_resubmission_student_has_submitted_the_assignment}

To allow students to resubmit their assignment if they have already
submitted an assignment:

1.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Now click on the **Grade** link beneath the assignment.
3.  Locate the name of the students and click on the **Grade** link
    beneath the name.
    -   Check the **Allow Resubmission** check box.
    -   Specify the number of resubmissions the students is allowed.
    -   Specify the **Accept Until** date and time (the last moment the
        student can resubmit their assignment).
4.  Click on **Save and Release to Student**.

## Allow Extension (Student has NOT previously submitted the assignment) {#allow_extension_student_has_not_previously_submitted_the_assignment}

To allow students to submit their assignment after the due date has
passed (if they haven\'t previously submitted):

1.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on the **Grade** link beneath the assignment.
3.  Find the student who needs an extension and click on their name.
4.  Check the box next to **Allow Extension**.
5.  Change the date in the **Accept Until** date to the new due date you
    want for the student.
6.  Click the **Save and Release to Student** button.

Note: Remind your students to visit the Warpwire Video tool before
starting an assignment as the tool may not allow them to record if they
have never visited the tool within your course before.

To set up an assignment to accept student submissions via Warpwire,
follow these instructions:

1.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **Add**.
3.  On the Add a New Assignment page, fill in the information such as
    title, open date, due date, and points like normal. See [Adding an
    Assignment](Add/Edit/Delete_an_Assignment "wikilink") for more
    information.
4.  Under the section \"Student Submissions\", select \"Inline only\"
    from the dropdown menu.
5.  Under \"Assignment Instructions\", besides providing students with
    the prompt for their assignment you may want to provide instructions
    on how to record their assignment with Warpwire.
    -   Be sure students know that in addition to including the video,
        they must include some text in the text box otherwise they will
        not be able to submit the assignment.
    -   Example instructions: Record your own video based on the prompt
        above. Be sure to title your video inside Warpwire using the
        following format: lastname_date_assignment#. Below your video in
        the text editor write your name, date, and time of submission.
        When you are ready, be sure to click "Submit" to turn in your
        assignment.\'\'
6.  Finish filling out the information below the Instructions box. See
    [Adding an Assignment](Add/Edit/Delete_an_Assignment "wikilink") for
    more information.
7.  Click **Post**. This will make the assignment available to the
    students based on the date range you provided on the form.

`     ``<text bytes="1142" sha1="7wzeyhdbl5v113s4de4lwgeibp4s7ku" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Please see a `[`video demonstration`](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/fy8CAA/)` of these steps. `

To configure Warpwire to allow student video uploads, follow these
instructions:

1.  Navigate to your Isidore site.
2.  Click on the **Warpwire Video** tool in the left-hand menu bar.
3.  Click on the title of the media library (usually the name of the
    course site).
4.  Select **Settings** from the drop down menu.
5.  On the Settings page, there will be several options.
    -   Select **Yes** next to the option **Users with access to this
        library can Add Media** to allow students to add media to the
        library.
    -   Select **Unlisted (only Admins)** next to the option **Default
        visibility of media items** if you want the videos to ONLY be
        visible to you within the Warpwire Video tool. If the student
        then embeds the video within a Forum post, the video will be
        visible to other students.
    -   Note: Make sure you set this Visibility setting to \"Unlisted\"
        if students are submitting Assignments that only you should see.
6.  Warpwire is now set up to allow student uploads.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Warpwire
Video](Warpwire_Video "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="1227" sha1="6kmvd75apgv8bpjqicjdg1g42qy7v55" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`To complete a Pre/Post Reflection activity:`

1.  Click on the Pre/Post Reflection wherever it has been added.
2.  You\'ll see the first prompt you need to answer. Type your response
    into the **Pre-Question** text box. When you\'ve completed your
    response, click on the **Submit** button.
3.  Your instructor may elect not to show the post-question until a
    certain time period. If this is the case, read the text to know when
    you can submit the post-question.
4.  Once the optional time period has passed, the post-question text box
    will become available to you. Type your response into the
    **Post-Question** text box. When you\'ve completed your response,
    click on the **Submit** button.
5.  The final step (a wrap-up question) is optional. Your instructor may
    add a wrap-up question that can be used for you to reflect upon your
    pre-question response and your post-question response and how it\'s
    changed. If a wrap-up response is requested, a wrap-up question text
    box will become available to you. Type your response into the
    **Wrap-up Question** text box. When you\'ve completed your response,
    click on the **Submit** button.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Pre Post](Pre_Post "wikilink") page

Read about the available settings in Tests & Quizzes:

## About

-   **What is the title of this assessment?** - name of the assessment
-   **What instructions should students have?** - instructions students
    will see prior to beginning the assessment
-   **Do you want students to agree to an honor pledge before beginning
    the assessment?** Require students to agree to honor pledge before
    beginning assessment - if this is enabled, students must agree to
    the University\'s honor pledge before they can begin the assessment.
-   **If you would like to provide a file to students click \"Add
    Attachments\".** - attachment students will be able to open prior to
    beginning the exam

## Availability and Submissions {#availability_and_submissions}

-   **Who is this assessment released to?** - by default, the assessment
    is released to the entire class, but you can choose to release it to
    specific groups
-   **How many submissions should each student get?** - specifies the
    number of attempts students are allowed
-   **When does it open?** - day and time the students can see and
    submit the assessment
-   **When is it due?** - day and time the assessment is due
-   **Do you want this assessment to have a time limit?** - once
    students begin the assessment, they only have a certain amount of
    time to complete it
-   **Do you want to allow submissions after the due date?** - allows
    students who haven\'t submitted the assessment to submit it past the
    due date and time
-   **Would you like to receive emails notifications when students
    submit this assessment?** - choose whether you would like to receive
    a daily digest or an individual email when students submit their
    assessments, or no notification at all.

*Optional settings:*

-   **Ensure students take exams from specific location** - set a
    password on the assessment
-   **Add message that students will see after submission** - message
    that students will see after they submit their assessment

## Exceptions to Time Limit and Delivery Date {#exceptions_to_time_limit_and_delivery_date}

-   **Exception for User** - select a student who will be taking the
    test at an alternate time or who needs extended time
-   **Exception for Group** - select a group of students who will be
    taking the test at an alternate time or who need extended time
-   **When does it open?** - day and time the students can see and
    submit the assessment
-   **When is it due?** - day and time the assessment is due
-   **Do you want this assessment to have a time limit?** - once
    students begin the assessment, they only have a certain amount of
    time to complete it
-   **Late submissions accepted until?** - allows students who haven\'t
    submitted the assessment to submit it past the due date and time
-   Note: You must click on **Add an Exception** to save the current
    exception or to add another exception.

## Grading and Feedback {#grading_and_feedback}

-   **If multiple submissions are allowed, which score should be
    recorded?** - indicate whether the highest, average, or last score
    should be recorded
-   **Do you want to grade anonymously?** - indicate whether you want to
    see student\'s names or grade anonymously
-   **Should students\' scores be sent to the Gradebook?** - indicate
    whether you would like to add the assessment to the gradebook
-   **What type(s) of feedback would you like to be able to enter as you
    build the assessment?** - display correct/incorrect answer feedback,
    answer choice feedback, or both

:   

    :   *Only Release Student's Assessment Scores (questions not shown)*
        -- students will only be able to see their total score for the
        assessment. No other information concerning right or wrong
        answers will be shown and students will not be able to review
        the questions or their answers.
    :   *Student Response* - This will reveal what answer the student
        selected or typed.
    :   *Correct Response* - This will reveal which answer is the
        correct response.
    :   *Question Level Feedback* - This will reveal feedback that the
        test builder has built into each question as feedback for the
        overall question. "Correct answer feedback" will display to the
        student if the student selects the correct answer to the
        question. The "incorrect answer feedback" will display if the
        student chooses the incorrect answer option. This will only show
        if the test builder added this feedback to individual questions
        in the test/quiz setup.
    :   *Selection-Level Feedback* - If the test builder adds feedback
        based on the A,B,C,D or other selection by the students in the
        test question, this option will reveal this feedback to the
        student based on what they choose as their answer.
    :   *Grader's Comments* - When the grader adds feedback manually
        when grading the test, this will reveal those comments upon test
        review by the student.
    :   *Student's Questions and Part Scores* - This reveals the number
        of points earned out of total possible points for each
        individual question as well as each individual part of the quiz.
    :   *Student's Assessments Scores* - This will show the student's
        overall score for the assessment.

-   **When will students receive assessment feedback?** - specify when
    students can view feedback
-   **What should students see?** - specify what feedback components
    students can view

## Layout

-   **How should students navigate through the assessment?** - indicate
    whether students should be allowed to go back and forth between
    questions or revisit previously answered questions
-   **How many questions should be displayed per page?** - indicate the
    number of questions that should be on a single page of the
    assessment. **Note:** one question per page is the safest option to
    avoid students losing answers.
-   **How should the questions be numbered?** - choose how you would
    like the assessment to be numbered
-   **Do you want students to be able to mark questions for review?** -
    You can also choose to enable checkboxes so that students can mark a
    question and return back to it. This is the equivalent of circling a
    question on a paper test and coming back to it if you have time.

## Publish

-   **Save Settings and Publish** - make the assessment available to
    students

## CK Editor Templates {#ck_editor_templates}

The Center for Online Learning has created some templates for you to use
in your Isidore courses. These templates may be used anywhere the CK
Editor is available.

To access templates:

1.  Navigate to a tool that utilizes the CK Editor.
2.  Click on the **Templates** button.
3.  Select the template you wish to use by clicking on it.
4.  Edit the text within the CK Editor. If there\'s a template with an
    image, you can upload your own image by double clicking on the
    silhouette.
5.  When you're done editing, click on the **Save** button.

3.  Select **Yes** to receive email notifications. Select **No** to stop

`     ``<text bytes="2574" sha1="iezjr8xpr5ncj9nb5vcl2nitrseescw" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`In Preferences, you can set options for how often you receive email notification of course activity, such as Announcements, Resources/Drop Box, Blogs, Assignments, Tests & Quizzes and Syllabus. You can also choose which course sites can be hidden and what language and time zone you would like to use.`

To access Preferences:

1.  Click on your profile picture or initials in the top right hand
    corner of Isidore.
2.  Click on the **Preferences** link.
3.  Help for each tab of Preferences can be found below, based on topic.

## Notifications

On the **Notifications** tab under **Preferences**, you may choose from
several notification methods for Announcements, Resources/Drop Box,
Blogs, Assignments, Tests & Quizzes and Syllabus activity, under
\"Preferences\":

-   Receive each notification separately: You receive email notification
    each time that an Announcement is posted, a Resource is added, or
    email is sent.
-   Receive one email per day: Some tools have options where messages
    are bundled into a single email message (or a digest) and sent to
    you daily.
-   Do not send me low priority notifications: You receive no
    notification regarding low priority site activity.

## Time Zone {#time_zone}

By clicking on the **Time Zone** tab in the **Preferences** area, you
can change your time zone. If you are in another time zone, you may
select the time zone from the box to change dates and times throughout
the system to your local date and time. Click on **Update Preferences**.

## Language

By clicking on the **Language** tab under **Preferences**, you may
select a language from the box to change the language of the system
text. Click on **Update Preferences**. This will not change the language
of any content that has manually been entered or uploaded to the system.

## Sites

To change the sites that have their own tabs, see
[Sites](Sites "wikilink").

To *hide* sites:

1.  From the **Preferences** tool, click on the **Sites** tab.
2.  Check the box next to any term and/or sites you wish to hide.
3.  Click on **Update Preferences**.

## Editor

Select how the rich text editor is displayed on mobile devices and
desktop computers. Auto detect is recommended for best results.

## Theme

Choose your Isidore Theme. Light Theme is the classic theme you\'re used
to. Dark Theme is currently in beta, meaning that contrast issues are
still being addressed with additional improvements coming soon. \<br
/\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Home (Isidore

## Changing your View of Calendar Temporarily {#changing_your_view_of_calendar_temporarily}

To change your view of Calendar:

1.  Navigate to the **Calendar** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Use the \"View\" drop-down list to select **Calendar by Day**,
    **Calendar by Week**, **Calendar by Month**, **Calendar by Year**,
    or **List of Events**.

## Setting the Default View for your Course {#setting_the_default_view_for_your_course}

Instructors can change the default Calendar view for all site
participants.

To change the default view of Calendar:

1.  Navigate to the **Calendar** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Use the \"View\" drop-down list to select **Calendar by Day**,
    **Calendar by Week**, **Calendar by Month**, **Calendar by Year**,
    or **List of Events**.
3.  To make that selection your default view, click on **Set as Default
    View.**

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [Calendar](Calendar "wikilink") page

`     ``<text bytes="1308" sha1="bo4zq1khroo3msrw7jqc12vlc30ayc0" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`To change announcement options:`

1.  Navigate to the **Announcements** tool in your course site.
2.  Click on **Options**.
3.  Pick your display options.
    1.  Sortable table view is the default, where you only see the
        subject of the announcement and can sort announcements.
    2.  Sortable table view with announcement body is where you see a
        table that contains the subject and the announcement body and
        can sort announcements.
    3.  List view with announcement body is where you can view a list of
        announcements, with the entire announcement displayed, and is
        not sortable.
4.  If you would like to change how much of each announcement is
    displayed, the characters in body setting allows you to display all
    of the announcement text, or limits it to 50 or 100 characters.
5.  The RSS Feed options aren\'t really used, so you can scroll past
    those.
6.  Display Limits settings allow you to set display preferences for how
    many days in the past you can view announcements or by the number of
    announcements. One example is displaying announcements from the past
    30 days. Or, you could set it to display the last 3 announcements.
    By default, the tool is set to display all announcements.
7.  Once you\'ve set your preferences, click on the **Update** button.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main
[Announcements](Announcements "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

To change roster permissions:

1.  Navigate to the **Roster** tool.
2.  Click on **Permissions**.
3.  Click on the checkbox next to the item you want to grant permissions
    to and in the column of the role you want to grant permissions to:
    -   **View all participants:** can view all site participants
    -   **View hidden participants:** can view members of a site who are
        not visible
    -   **View groups:** can view and filter groups and sections
    -   **View participant\'s enrollment status:** can access enrollment
        status view
    -   **View participant\'s profile:** can view participants\'
        profiles
    -   **View participant\'s email:** can view participants\' email
    -   **View participant\'s official photo:** can view participants\'
        official photo
    -   **View participant\'s site visits:** can view participants\'
        site visit data
    -   **Export roster:** can export the currently displayed data
    -   **View roster statistics:** can view the statistics for the
        whole roster
4.  Click on **Save** once the desired changes are made.

## Changing the Grading Schema in your course site {#changing_the_grading_schema_in_your_course_site}

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your course site.
2.  Click on **Settings**.
3.  Under the **Grading Schema** section, you can select a grading scale
    that most resembles your own from the **Grade Type** drop-down menu
    and then adjust the minimum percentages to the lowest percentage a
    student needs to earn to be awarded a letter grade.
4.  Click on **Save Changes** when you\'ve completed your desired
    changes.

## Default Grading Schema {#default_grading_schema}

  ---- -------------
  A    minimum 93%
  A-   minimum 90%
  B+   minimum 87%
  B    minimum 83%
  B-   minimum 80%
  C+   minimum 77%
  C    minimum 73%
  C-   minimum 70%
  D    minimum 60%
  F    minimum 0%
  ---- -------------

`     ``<text bytes="1608" sha1="0ltq2rogp78ba7ng72hk35snzudosxu" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`When using charts, graphs, and tables in instructional materials, you need to consider individuals who have visual impairments, are color blind, or use a screen reader. If charts or graphs that are posted online or shown in class, a textual description must accompany it so that those using screen readers can understand what the graph or chart is trying to show. Improving the accessibility of charts and graphs are beneficial to all users because it assists them with interpretation of graphs and charts when they're formatted with grayscale or not enough color contrast.`

[Learn more on Penn State University\'s Chart Accessibility
Page](http://accessibility.psu.edu/images/charts/)

\_\_TOC\_\_

## Charts and Graphs {#charts_and_graphs}

These tips will help ensure your charts and graphs are accessible:

-   Use data labels (instead of relying on color) in bar graphs and pie
    charts.
-   Use varying background patterns (instead of color) in bar graphs and
    pie charts.
-   Increase color contrast of the colors (light, medium, dark).
-   Use different dashes to make up the lines (instead of color) in line
    charts.
-   Provide a description or summary of what the chart or graph is
    displaying.
-   Consider replacing charts with tables.
-   Add a title to the chart or graph.

## Tables

These tips will help ensure your tables are accessible:

-   Ensure that your row and column headers are formatted as headings.
-   Add a caption that describes the table.
-   Don\'t save your table as an image - tables are accessible, but
    images are not.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Making content and media
accessible](Making_content_and_media_accessible "wikilink") page

## Distribute Materials {#distribute_materials}

In a hybrid learning or online learning environment, we recommend adding
all course materials to Isidore so students have a one-stop-shop for
everything they need for their classes. If you can, we recommend posting
course resources within the Lessons tool, as [demonstrated in this
video](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-coursecontent-weeklymodules).

It's important to let students know where to find your course resources,
stay consistent in your approach, and to notify them when new resources
have been posted.

Whenever possible, it\'s ideal to share resources in PDF format. This
approach ensures that students will be able to easily access them on
phones or other mobile devices. See [Microsoft\'s Knowledgebase for
saving files in PDF
format](https://support.office.com/en-us/article/convert-or-save-to-pdf-7d88593b-d509-4225-a05a-076723a40beb?ui=en-US&rs=en-US&ad=US).

Additional Resources:

-   [Adding Content to Lessons](Add_Content "wikilink")

## Record Videos {#record_videos}

Instructors can create lecture videos through two different programs:
Snagit or Zoom. Your lecture videos should be 10-12 minutes, as students
are more likely to watch shorter videos. Longer lectures should be
recorded in parts to keep down the length of the videos.

If you need to do any video editing, we recommend using Snagit instead
of Zoom to record your videos.

### **Snagit**

Instructors can record videos on their own computers using a program
called [Snagit](https://www.techsmith.com/screen-capture.html). Email
<onlinelearning@udayton.edu> to obtain a license.

Snagit allows you to record your voice and your screen, so you can talk
through your PowerPoint slides or demonstrate a problem in Excel. You
may optionally record your webcam as well.

Once you record your video in Snagit, upload the video to the Warpwire
Video tool in Isidore. Then, add the video to the appropriate spot
within your Weekly Lessons so students can watch it asynchronously.
[Here is a demonstration of this
process](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-coursecontent-sharingvideos).

**Additional Snagit Resources**

-   [Link: Download
    Snagit](https://www.techsmith.com/screen-capture.html)
-   [Video: Creating and Sharing Videos with Snagit and
    Warpwire](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-coursecontent-sharingvideos)
-   [Video: Techniques for Recording
    Videos](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/8Q8CAA/)
-   [Video: How to Set Up a DIY
    Teleprompter](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/f-UBAA/)

### **Zoom**

Instructors can record lecture videos using the Zoom tool in their
Isidore sites. To record a lecture in Zoom:

1.  Navigate to your Isidore site
2.  Click on the Zoom Meetings tool
3.  Schedule a meeting
4.  Start the meeting
5.  Press Record
6.  Begin your lecture
7.  Close Zoom when you are finished
8.  The recording will appear in the **Cloud Recordings** tab for both
    your and your students when it is finished processing.

**Additional Zoom Resources**

-   [Video: Record Lecture Using
    Zoom](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/l1EBAA/)
-   [Instructions: How to Schedule a Zoom
    Meeting](Schedule_a_meeting "wikilink")

## Facilitate Discussion {#facilitate_discussion}

Discussions can occur either asynchronously or synchronously. We
recommend using the Discussion Forums tool in Isidore for asynchronous
discussions, while you can use Zoom to conduct synchronous discussions.

### Asynchronous Discussion Forums {#asynchronous_discussion_forums}

The \"Forums\" tool in Isidore can be used to facilitate online
discussions in an asynchronous format (e.g. within a certain time frame,
but not all at the exact same time). You can set up discussion topics
and define prompts that you'd like students to respond to.

Outline clear expectations with your students about the required level
of engagement in each online discussion. Do they simply need to respond
to a prompt you create? Do you want them responding to each other? Will
you grade these discussions?

Please [watch the
video](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-assessing-discussions)
on how to host and evaluate discussion forums in Isidore.

**Additional Resources**

-   [Instructions: Using Forums in Isidore](Forums "wikilink")
-   [Article: Designing Effective Discussion
    Questions](https://teachingcommons.stanford.edu/resources/teaching/student-teacher-communication/designing-effective-discussion-questions)
-   [9 Student Engagement Strategies for Online Discussion
    Forums](https://edservices.wiley.com/9-student-engagement-strategies-for-discussion-forums/)

### Synchronous Discussions on Zoom {#synchronous_discussions_on_zoom}

Zoom can be used for hosting synchronous discussions. To facilitate an
effective discussion on Zoom, provide clear expectations to your
students on how they should communicate within the Zoom room. Here are
some questions that might help you establish expectations for your
class:

-   Should students have their webcams on?
-   Should students have headphones?
-   Should students leave themselves muted unless they are speaking?
-   Should students interrupt you with a question, or should they type
    questions into the Chat window?
-   Will you have small group discussions within Zoom?
-   Will students answer poll questions?

You should familiarize yourself with [Zoom\'s nonverbal feedback
features](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/115001286183-Nonverbal-feedback-during-meetings),
as well as the [breakout rooms](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/IeEBAA/)
and [polls](https://youtu.be/erz4xtQHoVs) tools. **Additional
Resources**

-   [Guide: Best Practices for Teaching with
    Zoom](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/TeachingOnlineResources/Best%20Practices%20for%20Teaching%20with%20Zoom.pdf)

## Comment on a student\'s attendance record {#comment_on_a_students_attendance_record}

To comment on a students\' attendance record:

1.  Navigate to the **Attendance** tool in your course site.
2.  Click on the **Attendance** tab at the top of the screen.
3.  Click on the attendance item for which you\'d like to enter a
    comment.
4.  Click on the comment bubble for the student for whom you want to
    enter a comment.
5.  Enter a comment and press the **Save** button when you are finished.
6.  The comment box will become shaded (filled in) and there will be a
    green confirmation message at the top of the screen.

## Display comments to students {#display_comments_to_students}

To display comments to students:

1.  Navigate to the **Attendance** tool in your course site.
2.  Click on the **Settings** tab at the top of the screen.
3.  In the **Edit Comment Settings** area, scroll past the statuses to
    see an option to **Show comments to students** and check the box.
4.  Click **Save Settings**.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [Attendance](Attendance "wikilink") page

`     ``<text bytes="980" sha1="ltke9mex8e8c7nc5a6ad76fkuuqxyda" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Students may complete a SCORM assignment via the SCORM Player tool or via the Lessons tool.`

## Completing a SCORM package via the SCORM Player tool {#completing_a_scorm_package_via_the_scorm_player_tool}

1.  Navigate to the **SCORM Player** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on the package name to launch the assignment.
3.  Navigate through the package using the **Next** and **Back** buttons
    (or other navigation within the package) until it\'s complete.
4.  Close the window when you\'ve completed the package.

## Completing a SCORM package via the Lessons tool {#completing_a_scorm_package_via_the_lessons_tool}

1.  Navigate to the **Lessons** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Navigate to the page or subpage that has a link to the SCORM
    package.
3.  Click on the SCORM package link to launch the assignment.
4.  Navigate through the package using the **Next** and **Back** buttons
    (or other navigation within the package) until it\'s complete.
5.  Close the window when you\'ve completed the package.

Player](SCORM_Player "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="1876" sha1="kyd64x5n7lcfwspapz2oyso0n0a6jrm" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`== Peer Review Instructions for Students ==`

**Note: If you did not submit the assignment, you will not receive any
papers when the peer review period opens.**

To complete a peer review:

1.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Submit your assignment as you normally would.
3.  For a peer review assignment, you will see an additional row
    underneath the original assignment link indicating that it is a peer
    review assignment. You will be able to see the open and due dates
    for the peer review period in that row.
4.  Once the review period starts, you will see links for your peers\'
    submissions in rows underneath the original assignment link. Click
    on the student link to begin your peer reviews. You may be reviewing
    more than one of your peers\' submissions, so make sure you review
    all the peers listed underneath the assignment link.
5.  You'll be taken to a page that has the original assignment
    instructions, additional instructions from your instructor (if
    provided), and your peer\'s submission.
    -   Read your peer\'s submission, assign a grade, and enter
        comments. You may also submit an attachment.
    -   Whenever you're done, click on the **Submit** button.
    -   If you're not quite ready to submit your work, you can click on
        the **Save** button to come back and finish your review later.
    -   The **Cancel Changes** button erases any changes you've made.
6.  If there are additional peer submissions you still need to review,
    the \"Next\" button will be blue. Click on the **Next** button to
    proceed to the next peer. *If you cannot click the \"Next\" button,
    this means you are on your last peer review.*
7.  Click **Submit** to finish.
8.  On the assignment list, you will see a green check mark next to all
    the reviews you have completed.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [Assignments](Assignments "wikilink")

`     ``<text bytes="995" sha1="a9x6vx1znawuq1y3j3xowlmy4hvfwdt" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Your instructor may set up assignments for you to complete and submit online. To work on an assignment:`

1.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click the name of the assignment to open it.
3.  To work on the assignment, follow the instructions from your
    instructor. You may need to type within the text box, or add an
    attachment, or both.
4.  To add an attachment, click **Browse** or **Choose File** to find
    and select the file on your computer (maximum 5 attachments by this
    method). There is a limit of 250 MB per upload.
5.  When you have finished, click the **Proceed** button at the bottom
    of the screen.
6.  Click on the **Submit** button.
7.  A submission confirmation message will appear on the screen and you
    will receive an email message confirming your submission. If you do
    not receive a confirmation, check to see if you\'ve successfully
    submitted the assignment.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [Assignments](Assignments "wikilink")

`     ``<text bytes="1372" sha1="aofh9onssv29vio3nvhoa1wmjmf2apk" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`By default, only you will be able to access the question pools you create, but you can share your question pools with other instructors.`

To share your question pool with someone:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool of your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Click **Question Pools**.
3.  Locate the name of the question pool you want to share and click on
    the **Share** link beneath it.
4.  Check the box under **Grant Access** next to the person\'s name you
    would like to grant access to.

**Notes**:

-   You can only share a question pool with a user has instructor access
    to your course site. **Caution:** If a user has instructor access to
    your course site, they can edit your course contents and can view
    and edit grades.
-   Once someone shares a question pool with you, you can then access
    the pool from any site in which you have the ability to create
    assessments, unless the creator of the pool revokes access.
-   Pool owners will see the names of everyone with whom they\'ve shared
    the pool on the Share Pool screen in all of their own sites.
-   Removing a user from a site does not remove access to any question
    pools you\'ve shared with him or her; you must revoke access using
    the instructions below.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Question
Pools](Question_Pools "wikilink") page\<br /\> Return to the main [Tests
and Quizzes](Tests_and_Quizzes "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

## Copy Files from Another Site {#copy_files_from_another_site}

To copy files or folders from another site:

1.  Go into the course site you want to copy files and folders TO.
2.  Click on the **Resources** tool in the blue menu bar on the
    left-hand side of the screen.
3.  Scroll down to the bottom of the Resources screen and click on the
    **Copy Content from My Other Sites** link.
4.  Once the list expands, you\'ll want to locate the course site you
    want to copy files and folders FROM. Click on the folder to the left
    of the course site to expand the list.
5.  Once the list expands, you\'ll want to locate the files or folders
    you want to copy and click on the check box to the left of them.
6.  Click on the **Copy** button that became available near the top of
    the screen.
7.  Click on **Paste copied items here** (clipboard icon) next to the
    folder you want to copy the items to.

**Note:** If you choose to copy files or folders, they will be available
in the original course site and they will be copied to the destination
site.

## Move Files to Another Site {#move_files_to_another_site}

There is currently no action to move files to another site. Please see
[Import from Site](Import_from_Site "wikilink") for help moving files
between sites. \<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main
[Resources](Resources "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

## Copying one of your own rubrics {#copying_one_of_your_own_rubrics}

To copy a rubric:

1.  Navigate to the **Rubrics** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Locate the rubric you wish to copy and click on the **Copy** (two
    pieces of paper) icon.
3.  Enter a title for the new copy of the rubric and click on **Save**.
4.  You can now make changes to the new rubric, without worrying about
    modifying the original.

## Copying a publicly shared rubric {#copying_a_publicly_shared_rubric}

To copy a rubric from the \"Publicly Shared Rubrics\" section:

1.  Navigate to the **Rubrics** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Expand the \"Publicly Shared Rubrics\" section by clicking on the
    **\>** symbol next to \"Public Rubrics\".
3.  To use one of the rubrics in your own site, click on the **two
    pieces of paper icon** (copy icon) in the \"Actions\" column next to
    the rubric you would like to use.
4.  A copy of the rubric will appear in the \"Site Rubrics\" section
    above. You can modify the rubric and use it within your course site.

## Copying a featured rubric {#copying_a_featured_rubric}

To copy a rubric from the \"Featured Rubrics\" section:

1.  Navigate to the **Rubrics** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Expand the \"Featured Rubrics\" section by clicking on the **\>**
    symbol next to \"Featured Rubrics\".
3.  To use one of the rubrics in your own site, click on the **two
    pieces of paper icon** (copy icon) in the \"Actions\" column next to
    the rubric you would like to use.
4.  A copy of the rubric will appear in the \"Site Rubrics\" section
    above. You can modify the rubric and use it within your course site.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Rubrics](Rubrics "wikilink") page.

## Copying Multiple Videos to a Site {#copying_multiple_videos_to_a_site}

To copy multiple videos to a site:

1.  Go to your Isidore course site where the video is located.
2.  Click on the **Warpwire Video** tool.
3.  Click on the circle button in the top right corner next to the **+**
    icon. This is the **Edit in Batch** button.
4.  Press the **Select All** option to select all the videos. If you
    prefer to manually select your videos, click on the empty circles on
    the bottom right corner of the video thumbnails.
5.  Once you have selected all the videos you want to copy, click on the
    **Batch Actions** button and choose **Copy** from the menu.
6.  Search for the media library you want to copy to. Most media
    libraries are the title of your roster, e.g.
    \"21_SP_FT_PHY_101_01\". Click on the title of the library.
7.  Press **Next**.
8.  Press **Start**.
9.  When the videos are finished copying, press **Done**.

## Copying a Single Video to a Site {#copying_a_single_video_to_a_site}

To copy an individual video, follow the steps below:

1.  Go to your Isidore course site where the video is located.
2.  Click on the **Warpwire Video** tool.
3.  Locate the video in the library that you want to copy.
4.  Click on the circle icon with three dots.
5.  Press the **Copy** button from the menu.
6.  Search for the media library you want to copy to. Most media
    libraries are the title of your roster, e.g.
    \"21_SP_FT_PHY_101_01\".
7.  Click on the **Add Copy** button.

## The Office of Legal Affairs {#the_office_of_legal_affairs}

The Office of Legal Affairs at the University of Dayton states the
following with regard to copyrighted materials: **Unauthorized access,
reproduction or use of the resources of others is prohibited.** The
[Policy on Fair, Responsible and Acceptable Use of Electronic
Resources](https://udayton.edu/udit/_resources/documents/policies/FRAUP_guidelines.pdf)
states that people at the University of Dayton may not \"make illegal
unauthorized copies of copyrighted materials. Copying or downloading
materials without the authorization of the copyright owner or other
legal privilege is against the law, and may result in civil and/or
criminal penalties, including fines and imprisonment.\"

## Libraries Research Guides {#libraries_research_guides}

According to the [library\'s guide on Copyright and Fair
Use](http://libguides.udayton.edu/c.php?g=15205&p=82868), \"original
content is copyrighted at the instant it becomes fixed in a tangible
medium. Creators no longer have to register a copyright to receive
protection against unlawful use - it is automatic.\"

The library also explains the doctrine of Fair Use:

\"The doctrine of Fair Use, however, limits the exclusive rights of the
copyright owner and makes reasonable public access to copyrighted works
available for limited purposes. Determining what constitutes Fair Use in
a specific situation can be difficult. Section 107 of the copyright law
(Title 17, U.S. Code) specifies four factors that are balanced together
when determining whether a use is Fair or not:

-   The purpose and character of the use, including whether such use is
    of commercial nature or is for nonprofit educational purposes
-   The nature of the copyrighted work
-   The amount and substantiality of the portion used in relation to the
    copyrighted work as a whole
-   The effect of the use upon the potential market for, or value of,
    the copyrighted work\"

## Creating Folders {#creating_folders}

To create a folder for messages:

1.  Navigate to the **Messages** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **New Folder**.
3.  Enter a folder title.
4.  Click on **Add**.
5.  Once the folder is created, you can move messages into that folder.

## Editing Folders {#editing_folders}

To edit a folder for messages:

1.  Navigate to the **Messages** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **Folder Settings** next to the folder you wish to edit.
3.  Click on **Rename Folder**.
4.  Edit the folder title.
5.  Click on **Save Settings**.

## Removing Folders {#removing_folders}

To remove a folder from messages:

1.  Navigate to the **Messages** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **Folder Settings** next to the folder you wish to delete.
3.  Click on **Delete**.
4.  Click on **Delete** to confirm deletion. *Please note that any
    messages inside of that folder will be deleted as well.*

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Messages](Messages "wikilink") page

Your instructor may set up assignments for you to complete and submit
online. To work on an assignment:

1.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click the name of the assignment to open it.
3.  To work on the assignment, follow the instructions from your
    instructor.
4.  You will first see a text editor. Click on the Warpwire symbol (the
    W in the circle) on the right side of the editor to create a
    recording with Warpwire.
5.  Click **Add Media** in the pop-up to add a recording.
6.  Click **Capture from webcam or camera** on the new screen to make a
    new recording.
7.  Before beginning your recording you will be asked if Adobe Flash
    Player can have access to your camera and microphone. Click
    **Allow**.
8.  Make sure that the correct camera and microphone are selected. You
    can change which microphone and camera you use to record by
    selecting different options from the dropdown menus at the bottom of
    the pop-up.
9.  Click on the video camera (Record) button to start the recording.
10. Click on the red square (Stop) button to stop the recording.
11. Change the name of the recording to the title required by your
    instructor in the instructions. Click **Save Recording**.
12. You\'ll see a \"Queued\" message while the video is uploading.
13. Once the video is done uploading, click the round button at the far
    right of your recording to select it for submission. The circle will
    turn green when selected.
14. Click **Insert 1 item** to add the recording to your submission.
15. Your video should appear in the text editor. Before you submit your
    assignment you will have to write some text in the box. Your
    instructor should provide you with instructions as to what the text
    should say.
16. When you have finished, click **Proceed** and **Submit** at the
    bottom of the screen.
17. Once you've clicked submit you will be brought to a submission
    confirmation page that will provide you an overview of your
    assignment submission. Click **Back to List** to return to the
    Assignments home page.

## Creating a forum {#creating_a_forum}

To create a new forum:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your course site.
2.  At the top, click **New Forum**. The Forum Settings screen will
    open.
3.  In the \"Forum Title\" field, type your forum\'s title.
4.  In the \"Short Description\" field, you can provide a brief
    description (limited to 255 characters) that will be displayed along
    with the title in the Forums area, maybe a brief forum summary.
5.  In the \"Description\" field, you can enter an in-depth description
    of your forum, and provide any associated information or resources.
    This is a great place to put forum instructions.
6.  Under \"Attachments\", you can attach a file from your local
    computer or from Resources, or specify the address for a file on the
    web, by clicking on the **Add attachments** button.
7.  To disable forum postings, under \"Forum Posting\", check **Lock
    Forum (Disable forum postings)**. Students will be able to read
    forum contents, but will not be able to post in the forum.
8.  To moderate forum postings, under \"Forum Posting\", check
    **Moderate topics in forum**. This option requires instructors to
    approve forum posts before other students can read them.
9.  To require students to post before reading others\' postings, check
    **Require users to post before reading**.
10. Under \"Availability\", you can choose to display the forum
    immediately or to specify availability dates. Students will not be
    able to read the forum after the specified time period has passed,
    unless you check the option to \"Allow users to view discussions
    after close date and lock forum\".
11. If you specify dates, you can choose to send the open and close
    dates to calendar.
12. To automatically mark all messages in a conversation as read at one
    time, under \"Mark All Messages in Conversations Read\", check
    **Automatically mark all messages in a conversation as read**. With
    this setting, each time you open the first message in a
    conversation, all messages within that conversation are
    automatically marked as read. The default setting tracks read/unread
    status for each message individually. (With the default setting, you
    can also manually click **Mark All as Read** for a given
    conversation.)
13. If you expand the \"Grading\" heading, next to \"Gradebook Item\",
    you use the drop-down list to choose an item with which the forum
    should be associated.\<br /\>*Note: The item should be created prior
    to this set. To add an item to the Gradebook, see [Add/Edit/Delete
    Gradebook Items](Add/Edit/Delete_Gradebook_Items "wikilink").*
14. If you have the Rubrics tool installed in your course site, you can
    choose to grade forum posts with a rubric. For help with this,
    please see [Rubrics](Rubrics "wikilink").
15. If you expand the \"Automatically Create Forums\" section, the
    default is to create one forum, but you can select the
    \"Automatically create multiple forums for groups\" option to create
    one forum for each team you select by clicking on the check box next
    to each team.
    -   Under \"Permissions\", you can modify permission levels for
        participant roles (and groups, if you\'ve created them; see
        [Manage Groups](Manage_Groups "wikilink")). Click the right
        arrow next to \"Permissions\" to expand the options available.
        Next to the role of the participant, use the **Permission
        Level** drop-down list to select from several predefined
        permission levels. Additionally, you can create custom
        permission levels by clicking the right arrow next to
        \"Customize\" to enable or disable specific functions.\<br
        /\>**Note**: Forum permission settings will apply to all
        subsequently created topics in that forum, but if you modify
        forum permission settings after topics have been created, you
        must change the topic permission settings separately.\<br /\>For
        details, see [Set Forum
        Permissions](Set_Forum_Permissions "wikilink").
16. When you\'re finished, click **Save** to save your changes or **Save
    Settings & Add Topic** to save your changes and add a topic to your
    forum.

## Creating topics {#creating_topics}

To create a new topic:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **New Topic** next to the forum you want to put the topic
    into.
3.  Next to \"Topic Title\", enter a title in the text box (required).
4.  Next to \"Short Description\", you can provide a brief description
    (limited to 255 characters) that will display below the title, maybe
    a brief topic summary.
5.  Next to \"Description\", you can enter an in-depth description of
    your topic, and provide any associated information or resources.
    This is a great place to put topic instructions.
6.  To add an attachment, under \"Attachments\", click **Add
    attachments**. The file selector screen will open.
7.  To disable topic postings, under \"Topic Posting\", check **Lock
    Topic (Disable topic postings)**. Students will be able to read
    topic contents, but will not be able to post in the topic.
8.  To moderate topic postings, under \"Topic Posting\", check
    **Moderate Topic**. This option requires instructors to approve
    topic posts before other students can read them.
9.  To require students to post before reading others\' postings, check
    **Require users to post before reading**.
10. To allow students to post anonymously, check **Posts are
    anonymous**. *Please note that this setting cannot be applied to
    topics that already have posts in them and this setting cannot be
    undone once it\'s enabled.*
11. Under \"Availability\", you can choose to display the topic
    immediately or to specify availability dates. Students will not be
    able to read posts in the topic after the specified time period has
    passed, unless you\'ve selected the option to \"Allow users to view
    discussions after close date and lock forum\". If you\'ve selected
    to specify open and close dates, you can also choose to send those
    dates to the Calendar tool.
12. Under \"Notifications\", you can enable email notifications when new
    messages are posted to this topic, by checking the box next to
    \"Allow email notifications for new messages\".
13. To automatically mark all messages in a conversation as read at one
    time, under \"Mark All Messages in Conversations Read\", check
    **Automatically mark all messages in a conversation as read**. With
    this setting, each time you open the first message in a
    conversation, all messages within that conversation are
    automatically marked as read. The default setting tracks read/unread
    status for each message individually. (With the default setting, you
    can also manually click **Mark All as Read** for a given
    conversation.)
14. If you expand the \"Grading\" section, next to \"Gradebook Item\",
    you can use the drop-down list to choose an item with which the
    topic should be associated.\<br /\>*Note: The gradebook item should
    be created prior to this step. To add an item to the Gradebook, see
    [Add/Edit/Delete Gradebook
    Items](Add/Edit/Delete_Gradebook_Items "wikilink").*
15. Under \"Automatically Create Topics\", the default is to create one
    topic. However, you can select \"Automatically create multiple
    topics for groups\" if you would like to create a topic for each
    group you select by checking on the box next to them. *We feel
    there\'s a better way to do this, so please see [Release Forums and
    Topics to Groups](Release_Forums_and_Topics_to_Groups "wikilink")
    for our preferred way.*
16. Under \"Permissions\", you can modify permission levels for
    participant roles (and groups, if you\'ve created them; see
    [Managing groups](Managing_groups "wikilink")). Click the right
    arrow next to \"Permissions\" to expand the options available. Next
    to the role of the participant, use the **Permission Level**
    drop-down list to select from several predefined permission levels.
    Additionally, you can create custom permission levels by clicking
    the right arrow next to \"Customize\" to enable or disable specific
    functions.\<br /\>For details, see [Set Forum
    Permissions](Set_Forum_Permissions "wikilink").
17. When you\'re finished, click **Save**.
18. You\'ll see your newly posted topic within your forum on the Forums
    screen.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [Forums](Forums "wikilink") page

## Creating a Group {#creating_a_group}

To create a group folder, you must first create a group. For help, see
[Manage Groups](Manage_Groups "wikilink").

## Creating a Group Folder {#creating_a_group_folder}

To create a group folder:

1.  Navigate to the **Resources** tool in your course site.
2.  Click on the **Actions** button and click on **Add Folder**.
3.  Enter a title.
4.  Click **Add details for this item**.
5.  Under \"Availability and Access\", select **Display this file to
    selected groups only**. Check the groups you wish to allow access
    to, and then click **Create Folders Now**.\<br /\>**Note**: If you
    don\'t see any choices under \"Availability and Access\", you may
    need to adjust the permissions for the parent folder.

## Changing an Existing Folder to a Group Folder {#changing_an_existing_folder_to_a_group_folder}

To a change an existing folder to a group folder:

1.  Navigate to the **Resources** tool in your course site.
2.  Click on the **Actions** button next to the folder you wish to edit
    and click on **Edit Details**.
3.  Under \"Availability and Access\", select **Display this file to
    selected groups only**. Check the groups you wish to allow access
    to, and then click **Update**.

## Managing Permissions for Group Folders {#managing_permissions_for_group_folders}

Once you have created a group folder, you may need to manage permissions
in order to adjust the level of access for site participants. For
detailed instructions, see [Set Resources
Permissions](Set_Resources_Permissions "wikilink"). \<br /\>\<br /\>
Return to the main [Resources](Resources "wikilink") page

## To create a new question pool from the **Assessments** page: {#to_create_a_new_question_pool_from_the_assessments_page}

1.  On the menubar for the relevant site, click Tests & Quizzes.
2.  On the Assessments page, click the **Add** button to see assessment
    creation options.
3.  In the **Add Question Pool** area, select the method you would like
    to use to create your questions:
    -   **Build question pool**: Allows you to create your question pool
        questions using a graphical user interface.
    -   **Paste in markup text**: Allows you to create your question
        pools questions by typing appropriately formatted text. (See
        [Format Questions for Markup
        Text](Format_Questions_for_Markup_Text "wikilink").)
    -   **Import from file (XML or zip)**: Allows you to import a
        question pool saved as an XML or zip file.
4.  Enter the question pool\'s title in the \"Enter Title\" field.
    -   **Note**: It\'s a good idea to give your pool a unique name. If
        you later create a random draw part, you\'ll select a question
        pool from a list of all the pools that you own or have been
        shared with you.

**Notes**

-   If you chose **Paste in markup text** above, you\'ll go directly to
    a screen that allows you to type or paste your questions.
-   If you chose **Import from file (XML or zip)** above, you\'ll go
    directly to a screen that allows you to choose a file to import.

\<br /\>

## To create a new question pool from the **Question Pools** page: {#to_create_a_new_question_pool_from_the_question_pools_page}

1.  On the menubar for the relevant site, click **Tests & Quizzes**.
2.  On the Assessments page, click **Question Pools**.
3.  On the Question Pools screen, click **Add New Pool**.
4.  Then, on the Add Pool screen:
    -   In the \"Pool Name\" field, give your question pool a name.\<br
        /\>**Note**: It\'s a good idea to give your pool a unique name.
        If you later create a random draw part, you\'ll select a
        question pool from a list of all the pools that you own or have
        been shared with you.
    -   In the optional \"Department/Group\" field, you may type a
        department or group name.
    -   In the optional \"Description\" field, you may type a
        description of the question pool.
    -   In the optional \"Objectives\" field, you may type a description
        of the objectives for this pool.
    -   In the optional \"Keywords\" field, you may type any keywords
        that may help you or someone else locate this question pool.
5.  When you\'re finished, click **Save** to return to the Question
    Pools screen.
6.  You may not see your new pool listed under \"Pool Name\" unless you
    click on **Assessments** then **Question Pools** again to refresh
    the page.

## Adding Questions by Copying from a Question Pool {#adding_questions_by_copying_from_a_question_pool}

To copy a question from a question pool:

1.  In the menubar of your course site site, click **Tests & Quizzes**.
2.  Click on **Edit** from the **Select** drop-down menu next to the
    assessment you want to add questions to.
3.  In the Questions screen, from the **Add Question**: drop-down menu,
    select **Copy from Question Pool**.
4.  Click the name of the pool from which to import the question.
5.  Navigate to a subpool and/or use the checkbox(es) to select
    question(s) you wish to import into the current assessment, and then
    click **Copy**.

## Adding Questions to a New Assessment {#adding_questions_to_a_new_assessment}

To add a question to an assessment that you\'re currently creating:

1.  In the menubar of your course site site, click **Tests & Quizzes**.
2.  Click the **\'Add**\' button to see assessment creation options.
3.  In the **Add Assessment** area, select the method you would like to
    use to create your questions:
    -   **Build assessment**: Allows you to create your assessment
        questions using a graphical user interface.
    -   **Paste in markup text**: Allows you to create your assessment
        questions by typing appropriately formatted text. (See [Format
        Questions for Markup
        Text](Format_Questions_for_Markup_Text "wikilink").)
    -   **Import from file (XML or zip)**: Allows you to import a fully
        configured assessment saved as an XML or zip file.
4.  Enter the assessment\'s title in the \"Enter Title\" field.
5.  To begin adding questions to a new assessment, choose the type of
    question you want to add from the **Add Question**: drop-down menu.

\_\_NOTOC\_\_

## Adding Questions to an Existing Assessment {#adding_questions_to_an_existing_assessment}

To add a question to an assessment that currently exists:

1.  In the menubar of the relevant site, click **Tests & Quizzes**.
2.  Click on **Edit** under **Select** next to the assessment you want
    to add questions to.
3.  Choose the type of question you want to add from the **Add
    Question**: drop-down menu.

## Setting Up Moderated Forums or Topics {#setting_up_moderated_forums_or_topics}

To create a moderated forum or topic:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Either click on **New Forum** or **New Topic** to create a new forum
    or topic, or click on **Forum Settings** or **Topic Settings** to
    modify an existing forum or topic.
3.  Under the \"Forum Posting\" heading, select \"Moderate topics in
    forum\" or under the \"Topic Posting\" heading, check the box next
    to \"Moderate Topic\".
4.  Click on **Save**.

## Moderating Messages {#moderating_messages}

To moderate messages in Forums:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  At the top, click **Pending Messages**. The number in the
    parentheses is the number of messages awaiting your attention.
3.  Check the box next to the message you\'d like to moderate, and click
    **Deny** or **Approve**. You\'ll be returned to the Pending Messages
    page to continue moderation.

Note: Students will not be able to see messages until you\'ve approved
them. \<br /\>\<br /\>Return to main [Forums](Forums "wikilink") page

1.  Enter the Poll Question and any additional instructions such as the
    number of answers that the voter may select.
2.  Choose an opening date and a closing date, between which
    participants will be able to cast their votes.
3.  Next, select the maximum and minimum number of answer options that a
    user may select. If you want users to only select one option from
    the possible answers given, set both numbers to 1. If users may
    select more than one option, adjust these settings accordingly.
4.  Decide how and when results will be visible:
    -   **Always** allows participants to see the results from the open
        date, even if they haven't voted.
    -   **Never** restricts participants from seeing the results
    -   **To participants who have voted** allows participants to see
        the results from the open date, but only after they have voted
    -   **After closing date** restricts access to the results until the
        closing date, after which all participants (regardless of
        whether they have voted or not) will be able to view them.
5.  Click on Save and add options
6.  Type in the first answer option available for the question and then
    click on Save and add options. Repeat until all answer options have
    been entered, then click on \"Save\".
7.  Click on \"Save\" to save the poll.

To create a random draw from a question pool:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Click on **Add** to create a new assessment.
3.  Enter an assessment title, ensure that the \"Create using assessment
    builder\" option is selected and click on **Create**.
4.  Click on the **Edit** link to the right of "Part 1".
5.  Type "Default" into the "Title" box.
6.  Enter any information or instructions you would like to share with
    students in the "Information" text box. You may also choose to leave
    it blank.
7.  Under "Type", you want to click on the radio button next to "Random
    draw from question pool".
8.  Enter the number of questions that should be displayed for students
    and select the question pool you want to use in this part.
9.  Enter the point value of each question into the "Scoring" section
    and whether you want to deduct points from a student's score for
    incorrect answer. Most instructors keep the deduction at 0 points.
10. Click on **Save**.
11. If you would like students to answer questions from other question
    pools, click on the **Add part** link to add another part and setup
    the part the same way we just did, selecting the other question
    pool.
12. Continue adding parts until all of the question pools have been
    selected.
13. Once the assessment is ready to go, you'll need to walk through the
    assessment settings and publish the assessment to make it available
    to students. For more help on these topics, visit the [See Available
    Settings](See_Available_Settings "wikilink") and [Publish an
    Assessment](Publish_an_Assessment "wikilink") pages.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Question
Pools](Question_Pools "wikilink") page \<br /\> Return to the main
[Tests and Quizzes](Tests_and_Quizzes "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="3766" sha1="79dstiuu55wrkf6ybueacc7f4we59bz" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`== Creating a section ==`

Sections may or may not be populated with official course data,
depending on implementation. If they are not automatically created, then
you may create them if you have the appropriate role. Participants
(e.g., students) cannot create or modify sections.

**Note**: If your implementation has an automatic feed, you will have
the option to automatically or manually manage section membership from
the Options page in the Section Info tool. Membership information can be
based on official registration information, or you can discontinue
section and membership updates from the registration system and manually
control everything. However, when you select manual mode and then return
to automatic mode, you will lose all the changes you made while in
manual mode.

To create a section:

1.  In your site\'s menubar, click Section Info. This will open the
    Section Info tool.\<br /\>**Note**: If you do not see \"Section
    Info\" on your menubar, you may need to add the tool. For more
    information, see [Add or Remove
    Tools](Add_or_Remove_Tools "wikilink").
2.  Click **Add Sections**.
3.  From the drop-down menus, select the number of sections you wish to
    add and the category in which the section(s) will be placed. You may
    add up to 10 sections at one time; however, all these sections must
    be in the same category. To add different sections in different
    categories, add them one at a time. For the categories, you may
    choose from the following:
    -   Lecture
    -   Lab
    -   Discussion
    -   Studio
    -   Recitation\<br /\>**Note**: The name of a category is the only
        thing that differentiates it from other categories; the
        categories are otherwise the same. For instance, a Lab section
        will function exactly as a Discussion section in the Section
        Info tool.
4.  In the field next to \"Name\", give your section a name. If you
    don\'t enter a name, the name of the category plus a number will be
    the default name (e.g., Lab1, Lab2, Lab3).
5.  Next to \"Section Size\", choose either **Unlimited number of
    students in section** or **Limit number of students in section to**.
    For the second choice, enter the maximum number of members allowed
    in the section.
6.  Next to \"Meeting Details\", select which days of the week this
    section meets.
7.  In the \"from\" field, enter the time the section meets. Enter the
    time and minutes, for example, 8:00. Check next to **AM** or **PM**
    to indicate time of day.
8.  In the \"to\" field, enter the time the section\'s meeting ends. Use
    the same format as for \"from\".
9.  For \"in\", enter a short location identifier for where the section
    meets, up to 20 characters maximum.
10. If you have chosen to add more than one section at a time, enter
    information for the other sections.
11. When you are finished, click **Add Sections**. If you have changed
    your mind and do not wish to add the section(s), click **Cancel**.

## Editing a section {#editing_a_section_2}

To edit a section you have already created:

1.  In the menubar of the relevant worksite, click **Section Info**.
2.  If you aren\'t on the Overview page, click **Overview**.
3.  Under the section you wish to edit, click **Edit**.
4.  You will be able to modify any of the fields you first entered when
    you created the section. When you have finished with your revisions,
    click **Update** to accept these changes, or **Cancel** to cancel
    them.

## Deleting a section {#deleting_a_section_2}

To delete a section you have created:

1.  In the menubar of the relevant worksite, click **Section Info**.
2.  If you aren\'t on the Overview page, click **Overview**.
3.  In the row(s) of the section(s) you wish to remove, check the
    box(es) under \"Remove\".
4.  Click **Remove Sections** to remove the section(s), and then click
    **Remove** to confirm. Click **Cancel** to cancel.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Section
Info](Section_Info "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}
