## Word Processing Documents {#word_processing_documents}

Here are some tips for making your word processing documents accessible:

-   Add a [title](Text_Content "wikilink").
-   Add some [headings](Text_Content "wikilink").
-   Use well-formed [hyperlinks/URLs](Web_Links/URLs "wikilink").
-   Use [good font and color choices](Text_Content "wikilink").
-   Make sure images have [alt text](Images "wikilink").
-   Make sure [charts, graphs, and tables](Charts/Graphs "wikilink") are
    accessible.
-   Check your document using [Microsoft\'s built-in accessibility
    checker](https://support.office.com/en-us/article/Use-the-Accessibility-Checker-on-your-Windows-desktop-to-find-accessibility-issues-a16f6de0-2f39-4a2b-8bd8-5ad801426c7f).

## PDF Files {#pdf_files}

Here are some tips for making your PDF files accessible:

-   If a PDF file was created by scanning a document, it needs to be
    scanned with optical character recognition (OCR) instead of as an
    image.
-   If you have a PDF that has been scanned as an image, you can use
    [Sensus
    Access](https://udayton.edu/ltc/learningresources/disability/sensus_access.php)
    to convert it to an accessible PDF.
-   If the PDF file is poor quality and difficult to read, re-scan it at
    a higher resolution.
-   If the PDF file is turned sideways or upside down, rescan it or use
    Adobe to rotate it 90 degrees or 180 degrees, respectively.
-   If the PDF file is something you created:
    -   Add a [title](Text_Content "wikilink").
    -   Add some [headings](Text_Content "wikilink").
    -   Use well-formed [hyperlinks/URLs](Web_Links/URLs "wikilink").
    -   Use [good font and color choices](Text_Content "wikilink").
    -   Make sure images have [alt text](Images "wikilink").
    -   Make sure [charts, graphs, and tables](Charts/Graphs "wikilink")
        are accessible.

## Accessibility Checkers for Specific Products {#accessibility_checkers_for_specific_products}

-   [Microsoft Windows: Best Practices for Making Word Documents
    Accessible](https://support.office.com/en-us/article/Make-your-Word-documents-accessible-d9bf3683-87ac-47ea-b91a-78dcacb3c66d)

    Accessible](https://support.google.com/docs/answer/6199477?hl=en)

    Accessibility](https://helpx.adobe.com/acrobat/using/create-verify-pdf-accessibility.html)

        scores you would like to drop from each category.

## Duplicating a Forum {#duplicating_a_forum}

Note: Duplicating a forum will duplicate all of the topics with the
forum.

To duplicate a forum:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your course site.
2.  Locate a forum you wish to duplicate.
3.  Click on the **More** link next to the forum and select **Duplicate
    Forum**.
4.  Click on **Duplicate Forum** to confirm the action.
5.  A new forum will be created with \"Copy\" at the end of the forum
    title. You can change this and other settings by clicking on **Forum
    Settings**.

## Duplicating a Topic {#duplicating_a_topic}

To duplicate a topic:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your course site.
2.  Locate a topic you wish to duplicate.
3.  Click on the **More** link next to the topic and select **Duplicate
    Topic**.
4.  Click on **Duplicate Topic** to confirm the action.
5.  A new topic will be created with \"Copy\" at the end of the topic
    title. You can change this and other settings by clicking on **Topic
    Settings**.

\<br /\>\<br /\>Return to main [Forums](Forums "wikilink") page

## Using the Default Check-In Questions {#using_the_default_check_in_questions}

By default, there are 3 Check-In questions displayed to students:

-   Are you experiencing any problems related to this class?
-   What is working best for you in this class as we\'ve moved online?
-   Is there something more I could do to assist you during the
    remainder of the term?

If these questions work for you, there\'s nothing else you need to do,
other than to tell students it\'s ready for them to answer.

## Turning Off the Default Check-In Questions {#turning_off_the_default_check_in_questions}

To turn off the default questions, simply uncheck the box next to the
questions you don\'t want displayed to students and click on **Save**.

## Adding your own Check-In Questions {#adding_your_own_check_in_questions}

To add your own questions, type them into the empty text boxes and click
on **Save**. \<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main
[Check-In](Check-In "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

To edit an existing question in a question pool:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Click **Question Pools**.
3.  On the Question Pools screen, select the pool that you wish to
    enter.
4.  On the next screen, you will see all the questions in the desired
    pool. Subpools will also be listed below. If you wish to edit any
    questions within a subpool, you must enter the subpool from this
    screen.
5.  Find the question you wish to edit, and click on the **Edit** link
    beneath the question.
6.  Make any desired changes to the question type, question text,
    attachments, question formatting, or any additional features of the
    question.
7.  When you\'re done, click **Save**.

**Note: If this question pool has already been added to an assessment,
you will need to edit the assessment and click on the \"Update
Questions\" button.** \<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Question
Pools](Question_Pools "wikilink") page\<br /\> Return to the main [Tests
and Quizzes](Tests_and_Quizzes "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="1585" sha1="j5jsd4327llm5kuesdrx4n74hqukp23" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`==Editing a Published Assessment==`

To edit a published assessment:

1.  From your Isidore course site, click on the **Tests & Quizzes**
    tool.
2.  Select **Edit** from the **Action** menu next to the assessment
    you\'re wanting to modify. Click on **Edit** again to confirm
    you\'re modifying a published assessment.
3.  You can click on **Edit** next to each part or each question that
    you want to make changes to.
4.  When you\'re done editing the part or question, just make sure that
    you click on **Save**.
5.  You\'ll want to click the **Regrade and Republish** option. This
    will fix the question for students and will also regrade their
    submissions. If you don\'t want students\' grades to be updated, you
    can click on the **Republish** option.

## Editing a Draft Assessment {#editing_a_draft_assessment}

To edit a draft assessment:

1.  From your Isidore course site, click on the **Tests & Quizzes**
    tool.
2.  Select **Edit** from the **Action** menu next to the assessment
    you\'re wanting to modify.
3.  You can click on **Edit** next to each part or each question that
    you want to make changes to.
4.  When you\'re done editing the part or question, just make sure that
    you click on **Save**.

**Notes:**

-   If you\'re editing an assessment that has been published already,
    you may be limited as to what changes you can make.
-   If you make any changes to the assessment, you\'ll want to modify
    both the draft and the published copy of the assessment so that the
    modification is made if you use the assessment in the future.

To edit your captions:

1.  Navigate to the **Warpwire Video** tool within your course site.
2.  Locate the video you\'re wanting to modify.
3.  Click on the circle with the 3 dots in it, below the video
    thumbnail. \<br /\>\<br /\>![Warpwire video
    thumbnail](Video_thumbnail.jpg "Warpwire video thumbnail")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
4.  Click on **Settings**. \<br /\>\<br /\>![Warpwire menu
    options](Menu_options.jpg "Warpwire menu options")\<br /\>\<br /\>
5.  Scroll down to \"Advanced Media Options\" and click on **Edit** next
    to \"Captions\". \<br /\>\<br /\>![Edit
    button](Edit.jpg "Edit button")\<br /\>\<br /\>
6.  The caption transcript will appear on the right-hand side of the
    screen. You may either modify the captions immediately or you can
    play the video to get to the spot that needs edited. You can also
    type keywords into the \"Search transcript\" section to quickly jump
    to an area of the transcript you wish to review and modify.
7.  To modify text that appears in the transcript, click on the text
    block to select it, then position your cursor within the text to
    make the edit. Text can be modified, just as you would within a Word
    processing or text document. \<br /\>\<br /\>![Edit captions and
    save
    transcript](Edit_captions_save_transcript.jpg "Edit captions and save transcript")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
8.  When you\'re done making edits, click on the **Save Transcript**
    button that\'s located in the upper right-hand area of the screen.

## Editing a Forum or Topic {#editing_a_forum_or_topic}

To edit a forum or topic:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Click **Forum Settings** or **Topic Settings** next to the forum or
    topic to change.
3.  Make desired changes.
4.  When you\'re finished, click **Save Settings**.

## Deleting a Forum or Topic {#deleting_a_forum_or_topic}

To delete a forum or topic:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Click **Forum Settings** or **Topic Settings**.
3.  Click **Delete Forum** or **Delete Topic**.
4.  Confirm or cancel the deletion when prompted.

You can also delete forums and topics by selecting **Delete Topic** or
**Delete Forum** from the **More** drop-down menu. \<br /\>\<br

## Add Multimedia {#add_multimedia}

To add multimedia:

1.  Navigate to the desired Lessons page.#Click **Add Content** and
    select **Embed Audio, Video, or Image**.
    -   Click on **Browse** to upload a multimedia file from your
        computer.
    -   Click on **Or select existing files from Resources** to add a
        file that\'s already in resources.
    -   Paste or copy in the web link for a file that is on the
        Internet, into the **Or add a URL or \"embed code\"** box.
2.  Click on **Save**.

In many cases, you will need to adjust the size of the box in which the
content is shown. Use **Edit** (pencil and paper icon), as explained
below.

## Edit Multimedia {#edit_multimedia}

To edit multimedia:

1.  Navigate to the desired Lessons page.
2.  Click **Edit** (pencil and paper icon) to the right of the item you
    would like to modify.
3.  This will open up an \"Edit Item\" box on your screen. The options
    available for modification are as follows:
    -   **Height** - Change the height of the internal frame that will
        display your web link or contain your media. Note, you may use
        either percentages (%) or pixels (px) to denote either relative
        or absolute measurements.
    -   **Width** - Change the width of the internal frame that will
        display your web link or contain your media. Note, you may use
        either percentages (%) or pixels (px) to denote either relative
        or absolute measurements.
    -   **Item Description** - Change/add a description to your
        multimedia file, which will appear beneath the multimedia file.
    -   **Change File or URL** - Change the source of the media or
        change the URL of your web link.
    -   **Edit the groups for which this item should be shown** - If you
        have groups or sections in the site, allows you to make this
        item visible only to some groups. Students who are not in one of
        the checked sections of groups will not see this item on their
        page at all.
4.  To save your changes, click **Update Item**.

## Delete Multimedia {#delete_multimedia}

To delete multimedia:

1.  Navigate to the desired Lessons page.
2.  Click **Delete** (trash can icon) to the right of the multimedia
    object you would like to remove.
3.  Click **Delete** to verify deletion.

## Add Multimedia {#add_multimedia_1}

To add multimedia:

1.  Navigate to the desired Lessons page.
2.  Click **Add Content** and select **Embed Multimedia**.
    -   To upload a file on your computer, click on **Choose Files** or
        **Browse** under \"Upload new file\".
    -   To add a file or URL that is in Resources, click on **Select
        existing files from Resources** and then **Select Resource(s)**.
    -   To add a file or URL from the Internet, click on the **Add new
        URL (web link)** and paste or type the web link or embed code
        into the \"Or add a URL or embed code\" box.
3.  Click on **Save**.

In many cases, you will need to adjust the size of the box in which the
content is shown. Use **Edit** (pencil and paper icon), as explained
below.

## Edit Multimedia {#edit_multimedia_1}

To edit multimedia:

1.  Navigate to the desired Lessons page.
2.  Click **Edit** (pencil and paper icon) to the right of the item you
    would like to modify.
3.  This will open up an \"Edit Item\" box on your screen. The options
    available for modification are as follows:
    -   **Height** - Change the height of the internal frame that will
        display your web link or contain your media. Note, you may use
        either percentages (%) or pixels (px) to denote either relative
        or absolute measurements.
    -   **Width** - Change the width of the internal frame that will
        display your web link or contain your media. Note, you may use
        either percentages (%) or pixels (px) to denote either relative
        or absolute measurements.
    -   **Item Description** - Change/add a description to your
        multimedia file, which will appear beneath the multimedia file.
    -   **Edit the groups for which this item should be shown** - If you
        have groups or sections in the site, allows you to make this
        item visible only to some groups. Students who are not in one of
        the checked sections of groups will not see this item on their
        page at all.
    -   **Don\'t release Item Until All Prerequisites are Completed** -
        This option allows you to restrict access to the item until
        students have completed other tasks listed earlier on the page.
4.  To save your changes, click **Update Item**.

## Delete Multimedia {#delete_multimedia_1}

To delete multimedia:

1.  Navigate to the desired Lessons page.
2.  Click **Delete** (trash can icon) to the right of the multimedia
    object you would like to remove.
3.  Click **Delete** to verify deletion.

**Note:** If you use the \"Add to Gradebook\" option in Assignments,
Forums, Lessons, or Tests & Quizzes, you must enter grades in the tool
from which the item originated.

To enter grades for items in Gradebook:

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Locate the column of the gradebook item in which you want to enter
    grades.
3.  Enter grades for each student by clicking in the cell that lines up
    with the corresponding gradebook item and the student\'s name and
    typing in the score.
    -   As you click on the \"Tab\" or \"Enter\" key on your keyboard or
        click in another cell, the grades will be automatically saved.
    -   If you wish to enter comments, click on the downward-facing
        arrow in the lower right corner of a student\'s cell.
    -   Click on **Edit Comment**.
    -   Enter comments in the text box that is displayed on the screen.
    -   Click on **Save Comment**.

## Editing grades {#editing_grades}

**Note:** If you want to edit grades for Assignments, Forums, Lessons,
or Tests & Quizzes, you must edit grades in the tool from which the item
originated.

To edit previously entered grades in Gradebook:

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Locate the column of the gradebook item in which you want to edit
    grades.
3.  Change grades for each student by clicking in the cell shows the
    score you would like to edit.
4.  Enter the new score.
    -   As you click on the \"Tab\" or \"Enter\" key on your keyboard or
        click in another cell, the grades will be automatically saved.
    -   If you wish to edit comments, click on the comment bubble in the
        upper right corner of a student\'s cell.
    -   Click on **Edit Comment**.
    -   Edit the comments in the text box that is displayed on the
        screen.
    -   Click on **Save Comment**.

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Locate the student\'s cell for the gradebook item you want to excuse
    them from.
3.  Click on the small downward-facing arrow in the bottom right of the
    cell, and select **Excuse/Include Grade**.
4.  The item will then have a strike through it and won\'t be calculated
    into the student\'s course grade.

To reverse this, simply follow the same steps, but click on
**Excuse/Include Grade** again. \<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main
[Gradebook](Gradebook "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

**Note:** New Attendance items cannot be added through Excel. Any items
for which you wish to record Attendance must first be created in the
Attendance tool before you export the file for modification.

To export the Attendance records as a .xls (Excel) file:

1.  Navigate to the **Attendance** tool in your course site.
2.  Click on the **Import/Export** tab.
3.  In the **Export** section, click on the **Export Attendance Sheet**
    button.
    -   Check the box next to the option to include comments if you want
        to record comments on students\' attendance records in Excel.
    -   Check the box next to the option to \"Export blank attendance
        spreadsheet\" if you do not want to export any existing
        attendance records. For example, if you have already recorded
        attendance for an Attendance item, selecting this box will strip
        out the attendance records for that item.
4.  Click on **Export Attendance Sheet**.
5.  The downloaded Attendance records will be saved to your Downloads
    folder on your computer (or a location of your choosing).

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [Attendance](Attendance "wikilink") page

## External Tools {#external_tools}

External tools are also referred to as LTI tools. [LTI stands for
Learning Tools
Interoperability](http://www.imsglobal.org/toolsinteroperability2.cfm),
a standard created by [IMS Global Learning
Consortium](http://www.imsglobal.org/). LTI tools allow you to bring
rich content into Learning Management Systems, like Isidore, from
outside companies. *Keep in mind that you must purchase access from some
of these companies before you have access to some of these tools.*

**[How to install external tools in your course
site](How_to_install_external_tools_in_your_course_site "wikilink")**

Please contact the Center for Online Learning via
<onlinelearning@udayton.edu> or (937) 229-5039 for help with external
tools (or LTI tools).

**Available External Tools** \<div

`     ``<text bytes="43225" sha1="k6lizs6dw1c2aw0w4wv8esirs6nqd81" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Below are answers to some commonly asked questions about flexible teaching and the template sites. `

### Course Management {#course_management}

**If I divide my students into groups for in-class meetings, what is the
best way to do that?**\</br\>

Please see [our video and email
template](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-communication-groups)
that demonstrates how to split your students into groups and notify
them. \<br/\> Instructors may choose to divide their students in any way
that best suits their course objectives as long as the division does not
create problems with equity. Students may be divided randomly, by first
letter of last name, or any other means selected by the instructor. If
adjusted classroom capacities permit, it may be a good idea to make sure
that a few extra seats are available for students who need to
temporarily switch meeting days. If you wish to be truly random, Isidore
has a tool - "Randomly" - that will evenly divide your class roster
based on the number of desired groups. In class with students from a
variety of majors, you may consider groups that represent that variety
to ensure a more diverse group and class discussion. Once instructors
have split their classes into groups they should communicate with their
students ahead of the term so that they are aware of which days they can
attend.

**What does it mean to say all classes should be fully available for
remote students?**\</br\> While many students are coming back to campus
in the fall and in-person instruction will be extremely important there
will likely be times where some students may be forced to quarantine
themselves during the semester, removing their option to attend
in-person for a period of time. Faculty will need to do their best to
accommodate students in their classes during these periods so that they
can continue to participate in class. There will also be some students
that will never return campus during the fall that will only be able to
join classes remotely.

**How do students meet in small groups in class?**\</br\> This depends
in part on the lengths of the group meetings and the nature of the
interactions. Current medical guidance is that interactions in
proximities of less than six feet lasting less than fifteen minutes pose
little risk of viral transmission, assuming that everyone wears proper
face coverings. (Keep in mind that the fifteen-minute time estimate is
cumulative.)

Groups meeting in class can also set up virtual meetings through Zoom
while maintaining physical distances of at least six feet. instructors
can set up these meetings as breakout groups and be able to virtually
visit the groups as they meet, or students can set up their own
meetings. Virtual student group meetings can accommodate students who
attend class remotely. The advantage of using class time for such
meetings is to assure instructors that students are in fact meeting and
to have the instructor available to assist groups in their work.

When possible, instructors may also consider having student groups meet
outside. Fall provides some of the nicest weather and outdoor spaces
offer the ability to spread out in conditions less conducive to viral
transmission. If an instructor will be using small groups that meet
face-to-face, they may want to consider keeping the membership of the
small groups consistent throughout the semester to minimize the number
of unique individuals to which students have direct contact.

**How can instructors meet with students individually in class and still
maintain social distancing?**\</br\> Isidore and Zoom both provide chat
capabilities that permit private student and instructor conversations,
though somewhat less efficiently than verbal conversations. Depending on
circumstances, instructors might invite students into the hallway
outside of the classroom for a conversation where six foot distances can
more easily be maintained while still providing a degree of privacy.
While individual conversations that respect social distance guidelines
may be problematic during a class meeting the student may be able to
stay after class to ask their question or meet with their instructor in
a departmental conference room or open classroom before/after class.

**What is the recommended way to schedule individual meetings?**\</br\>
This is ultimately up to each instructor to decide what works best for
them. For many, it may be simple enough to handle via email.
Alternatively, the "Sign up" tool in Isidore is useful for this purpose.
Instructors can also create 'Appointment Slots' on their Google Calendar
or use other tools with which they have experience.

**Will students who opt to start online have the ability to switch to
return to face to face? Are any students locked in to their mode of
instruction (F2F vs Online)?**\</br\> If students come to campus, the
expectation is that they will come to class for in person instruction.
Whether students who opt for a remote semester from home can decide to
change is up to the Provost and decided on a case-by-case basis.
Students who start in-person may have to change for reasons of illness
or quarantine.

**How should instructors handle office hours?**\</br\> Instructors are
required to provide office hours in support of their classes. Consult
with your department to determine the exact amount of hours required.
This will likely best be [handled through Zoom
sessions](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-zoom-officehours)
but individual meetings are allowed in spaces that can allow for proper
social distancing. This likely means that individual meetings can not
take place in instructor offices and would need to held in department
conference rooms or open classroom/meeting spaces.

**How should I track pass/fail assignments?**\</br\> The easiest way to
do this is to just add pass/fail assignments to the Gradebook as 1 point
items. Then, make sure the item is not included in the course grade
calculation. Give students a \'1\' for a pass and a \'0\' for a fail.
[Here\'s a quick video
demonstration](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/jywCAA/) of how to do
this.

\<br/\>

### Course Delivery {#course_delivery}

**How can I tell what technology is in my classroom?**\</br\> The
Classroom Technology team created a [Classroom Technology Capabilities
Spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1f1yXjDFRLwDklyJduprDi9qvObk6K9T4HqhHCO53hCs/edit?usp=sharing)
that shows what technology will be available in each teaching space at
UD in the fall. The spreadsheet also shows the new room capacity for
each space.

**Can I visit my classroom and try things out?**\</br\> Yes. Beginning
on August 5th, you should be able to swipe into your classrooms. Please
note that the technology might not be completely set up at this point.
Note: please contact your chair about accessing rooms in buildings that
require physical keys.

**Are there online resources to help prepare to teach in a
classroom?**\</br\> Yes. UDit has created a great [set of resources to
help faculty with classroom
technology](https://udayton.teamdynamix.com/TDClient/1868/Portal/KB/ArticleDet?ID=112788).
Specifically, you may want to check out the [Pre-Flight
Checklist](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1yZz3LpJwtfFn9WaWSb2y35r_7FD93qHNq6gApiZ6i0Y/edit?usp=sharing)
to help you understand how to prepare your room before class begins and
watch the [Introduction to the Hybrid/Blended
Classroom](http://udayton.warpwire.com/w/0SkCAA/) video.

**How will I know which students are going to be face-to-face and which
will be remote?**\</br\> Beginning on August 12th, you will be able to
see which students will be studying remotely in the fall through [the
Statistics page within the Roster
tool](https://www.screencast.com/t/629hXzH8EzS).

**What is the best file-type to share with students?**\</br\> Faculty
are encouraged to share files in PDF format, if possible. PDFs can be
opened directly in most web browsers and are ideal for viewers on mobile
devices that don't have access to Microsoft Office products.

[SensusAccess](https://udayton.edu/ltc/learningresources/disability/sensus-access-instructions.php)
is a quick self-service tool that faculty and students can use to
convert document(s) to formats that are accessible. Users simply upload
a file and select the format of the accessible file that they want
returned to them via email.

**Can remote students just watch the recordings of my live sessions
rather than attend the live session?**\</br\> Zoom cam automatically be
set to record all meetings held on the platform and that function may
prove useful to all students. However, recordings of class should not
predominantly take the place of live class attendance. On occasion, it
may be necessary to simply refer one or more students to recordings of
class sessions. However, the expectation is that students will attend
class sessions either in person or through Zoom. Exceptions to this can
be made at the professor's discretion.

**What does Active Learning look like while social distancing?**\</br\>
Louisiana State University has outlined some common active learning
strategies and corresponding approaches appropriate for online teaching
in both synchronous and asynchronous approaches.

**What assessment tools are available in Isidore/at UD?**\</br\> There
are a number of different assessment tools available in Isidore.
Asynchronous training modules of some of these assessment tools are
available on the Keep Teaching site. Specifically, formative assessments
provide ways for students to measure their progress in the course and
instructors to monitor student engagement. Specific tools for designing
formative assessments in Isidore include:

-   [Tests & Quizzes
    tool](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Category:Tests_and_Quizzes)
-   [Assignments tool](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Assignments)
-   [Forums
    tool](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Grading_Forum_Postings)
-   Learning Apps (found within the Lessons tool)
    -   [Quick Quiz](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Quick_Quiz)
    -   [Quick Write](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Quick_Write)
    -   [Interactive
        Video](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Interactive_Video)
-   [Perusall](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Perusall)

In addition to tools found natively within Isidore, there are many great
apps that can be linked into an Isidore course site or released through
textbook publisher platforms. In addition, there are many ways that the
suite of Google products could be used to drive assessment activities.

\<br/\>

### Testing & Assessment {#testing_assessment}

The [Testing & Assessment
FAQs](https://docs.google.com/document/d/e/2PACX-1vQ7-ElxPmVxlq2StvaIXQsPDNQQA2SZd95O4mRGAE5trybRTtje-CWucOIlKSKAXl4-4Y4YaYvXmFiw/pub?urp=gmail_link)
were created by the Path Forward Testing & Asssessment subgroup.

**What are the online proctoring options the University is considering
and when will decisions be made?**\</br\> Per the message sent to
instructors by Paul Benson on July 24th, the University understands that
need to proctoring solutions going into the fall semester. The message
outlined through three options going into the fall.

-   **Zoom \"Self-Recording**\': For lower-stakes tests, we suggest
    using our current Zoom recording capabilities for exam proctoring.
    This approach will outline how to instruct students to set their
    personal Zoom account to \"self-record\" their test-taking session
    and submit the recording to their professor for possible review.
    Please [see this
    guide](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/TeachingOnlineResources/StudentSelfRecordingInstructionsZoom.pdf)
    to help students set up the self-proctored exam.
-   **Digital Textbook Proctoring**: For those courses that are using a
    digital textbook, there may be an option to enhance the digital
    packet with an online proctoring service. These proctoring services
    offer recorded test sessions with artificial intelligence (AI) that
    flags suspicious behavior for possible review by the instructor. The
    Bookstore is in the process of identifying all eligible courses for
    this service and will be communicating this information to
    departments soon. We intend to absorb the added costs of digital
    textbook proctoring into the university budget. Faculty using
    digital textbook proctoring will use the publisher\'s site as the
    testing platform.
-   **Isidore-integrated Proctoring**: We are currently reviewing
    proctoring solutions that would integrate into Isidore\'s Tests &
    Quizzes tool. The goal will be to provide an automated and recorded
    proctoring experience for students with AI-flagging similar to what
    the textbook publishers offer. We are working aggressively on this
    solution since it will likely offer the most effective and
    convenient method for managing online testing. \<br/\>

The university is also working on a plan to offer larger spaces that can
be scheduled on Friday afternoons and Saturdays where faculty could
bring their entire class together for an in-person proctored exam.

**How can my students scan in their written work?**\<br/\> Please see
[our guide for using the GeniusScan
app](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/01%20Flexible%20Teaching/GeniusScan%20Guide.pdf).
This app allows students to take multiple pictures of documents, then
merges those images into a single PDF.

**How can I mitigate cheating in online assessments?**\<br/\> Please see
[our guide to minimize
cheating](https://isidore.udayton.edu/keepteaching/cheating.html) using
the features within Isidore\'s Tests & Quizzes tool.

**How can I set up extended time assessments?** \<br/\> Please see [our
step-by-step
instructions](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Setup_Extended_Time_Assessments).

**How can I create a random draw from question pools?**\<br/\> Please
see [our help
documentation](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Add_a_Question_Pool).

**How can I export and import Tests & Quizzes?**\<br/\> Please see [this
3 minute video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wSR9Fc_hRtE).

**How can I get help creating my tests?**\<br/\> Please complete the
[exam building request
form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfUASfmg0nVIzqZ2rOoTd-sSL6DHc2GWYE6S8oa8x7h_FcFEA/viewform?usp=sf_link),
and someone from Online Learning will build the test in Isidore on your
behalf. **PLEASE NOTE:** We highly suggest getting your tests in as soon
as possible so we can have plenty of time to build them.

\<br/\>

### Isidore Template Sites {#isidore_template_sites}

**How do I unpublish my Isidore sites?**\<br/\>

1.  Navigate to the Site Info tool in your site
2.  Click on the Manage Access tab
3.  Click on \"Leave as Draft\"
4.  Click on \"Update\"
5.  Please note that if you unpublish your site, you will need to click
    on the Publish button to make it available to your students again.

\<br/\>

**How do I unhide the Resources in my site?**\<br/\>

1.  Navigate to the Site Info tool
2.  Click on the Manage Tools tab
3.  Click on the Gear icon next to the tool
4.  Click on Make Tool Visible to Students
5.  Click Save

\<br/\>

**How do I add the Academic Calendar to my site?**

1.  Download this file to your computer:
    <https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/calendar/ical/academiccalendar.ics>.
2.  Go to the Calendar tool in Isidore
3.  Click on the **Import Events** tab
4.  Click on the iCalendar option
5.  Press Continue
6.  Locate the Calendar file on your computer
7.  Press Continue
8.  Press Import Events

**How do I add someone to my Isidore site?**\<br/\>

1.  Navigate to the Site Info tool
2.  Click on the Add Participants button
3.  Click \'yes\' for does the person have a UD email
4.  Enter the person\'s UD username \-\-- not email (e.g. \"jmorgan2\",
    **not** \"jmorgan2@udayton.edu\")
5.  Press Continue
6.  Select the role you want the person to have (Student, TA-Grading,
    Instructor, etc.)
7.  Press Finish

\<br/\>

**How can I merge two template rosters/sites together?**\</br\> Please
email [onlinelearning@udayton.edu](mailto://onlinelearning@udayton.edu),
and we will merge rosters together into a single site for you. \<br/\>

**Do I have to use the template site?**\</br\> No. However, we do highly
recommend that you review the [Course Facilitation and Engagement
Guidelines](https://isidore.udayton.edu/keepteaching/guidelines/index.html)
and adhere to those guidelines as much as possible. If you would like to
have the template site deleted so you can create sites yourself, please
[complete this
form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeIEZeMtM1ln0e9yTpQWJ-hLDXJgpbjiHhQQQ7xFJBajduL6Q/viewform?usp=sf_link),
and we will remove them. \<br/\>

**How can I import content that I\'ve previously used in older Isidore
sites?**\</br\> Please see [our training
module](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-gettingstarted-importing)
about importing content for instructions. **NOTE:** In order to import
content from Tests & Quizzes, you MUST have drafts of your Tests &
Quizzes in the site. If you have recently deleted drafts of tests, you
may be able to restore them from the **Trash** tab within the Tests &
Quizzes tool. \<br/\>

**How do I add a video to the course Homepage?** Please see this [2
minute video
demonstration](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XPkphPqYicM).

**How do I changes the dates on the weekly lessons?**\</br\> Please see
[this 2 minute video](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/CRkCAA/).

**The buttons in Manage Groups aren\'t working. How can that be
fixed?**\<br/\> Please [clear your browser\'s
cache](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nj9sYfJ9EH4).

**How do I handle multiple instructors/sections within a single
site?**\</br\> Most of the tools within Isidore let you release content
to specific rosters. [This quick video
demonstrates](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/hSwCAA/) how you can handle
multiple sections/instructors within a single Isidore site. For Zoom
meetings, you can just schedule meetings with titles like \"PHY 101
Section 01\" and \"PHY 101 Section 02\". \<br/\>

**What do all the buttons in the Lessons tool do?**\</br\> [This
video](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/hRoCAA/) walks through all the
buttons you might use in the Lessons tool in the template site.

**How do I add my Student Success Network Calendar to Isidore?** [Please
see this
guide](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/01%20Flexible%20Teaching/Adding%20a%20SSN%20link%20to%20your%20Isidore%20Course%20Tool%20Menu-3.pdf)
that provides instructions on how to add the SSN link to your Isidore
course site.

**Can I see an example of the template site?**\</br\> Sure! [Follow
these
step](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/01%20Flexible%20Teaching/Instructions%20for%20Joining%20Example%20Site.pdf)
to join an example of a template site in Isidore.

### Classroom Guidance {#classroom_guidance}

**How do I distribute or return materials to students while in
class?**\</br\> Whenever possible, please consider sharing and receiving
of materials in electronic format. For materials that are difficult to
type, students can use free scanning apps (e.g., Scannable or Genius
Scan) that produce pdf files of hand written notes and assignments which
can then be submitted electronically through Isidore. Not only is this a
sustainability improvement, it does cut down on the handling of print
materials. According to study done by
[OCLC](https://www.webjunction.org/content/dam/WebJunction/Documents/webJunction/realm/test1-report.pdf),
the virus can live on printed materials for up to three days.

Many students use public printers at the library or other locations on
campus, where multiple people touch printer controls and that could
serve as transmission points. This is another reason favoring electronic
submissions.

As for handling materials touched by others, current medical guidance is
that viral transmission by this route occurs less frequently than
through respiratory infection. However, as always, instructors and
students should use appropriate hand sanitizers after handling materials
touched by others and avoid touching their faces. These guidelines could
change.

**Am I required to use my classroom during every assigned
meeting?**\</br\> Instructors should be interacting with students
synchronously during scheduled class times, and should make every effort
to ensure opportunities for each student to meet with all students on an
in-person basis at least once a week. Within that framework, instructors
retain broad discretion to determine the modality of each scheduled
class meeting. As an example, an instructor teaching a MWF course may
elect to meet with half of their on-campus students in-person on Monday,
the other half of their on-campus students in-person on Wednesday, and
then elect to hold Friday's class session for everyone through Zoom.

\<br/\>

### Communication

**How do I notify students what group they are in?**\</br\> The goal of
the notification is to avoid having all students show up on the first
day of class only to have half sent away. Thus, assignment to groups and
communication of those assignments to students should be done well
before the semester starts, repeated several times prior to the start of
class, and communicated through several channels, such as regular UD
email, email through Isidore, and prominent posts on course Isidore
pages.

**What is the best way to communicate with students?**\</br\> Individual
communication between a student and an instructor is likely best handled
via campus Gmail accounts [while class-wide messages are best posted as
'Announcements' inside the course Isidore
site](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-communication-announcements).
Instructors should share their [communication
plan](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-communication-strategy)
with students in their syllabus so that they understand where to look
for course communications, how best to ask class questions, and what the
expected response time may be.

**Am I allowed to email a student at their personal email
address?**\</br\> All messages to students must be sent to their UD
email addresses. It\'s the only way the instructor can be sure that the
student is the actual person receiving the message. Also, UD email
accounts are FERPA compliant. Other email addresses are not. Instructors
that receive messages from students through their personal email
addresses should ask the student to email from their UD account before
responding.

\<br/\>

### Video Creation {#video_creation}

**What\'s the best way to create lecture videos?**\</br\> Choose
whatever software you are most familiar with, either Snagit or Zoom.
Both of these programs let you record yourself, your mic, and your
screen.

-   [See this
    webpage](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-coursecontent-sharingvideos)
    for more information about how to use Snagit. Contact
    [onlinelearning@udayton.edu](mailto://onlinelearning@udayton.edu)
    for a Snagit license.
-   [See this
    webpage](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-zoom-starting)
    for more information about how to start a Zoom meeting and [record
    and share a
    lecture](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-zoom-recordings).

If you would like someone to record you in-person for a special video
please schedule contact with Aidan Curran (acurran1@udayton.edu) in the
Center for Online Learning.

**What is the best way to share lecture videos with students?**\</br\>
Instructors are encouraged to [upload their videos to the Warpwire Video
tool](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-coursecontent-sharingvideos)
in their course Isidore site.

**How do I share Warpwire videos from previous courses with
students?**\<br/\> Please see our guide with [step-by-step
instructions](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/01%20Flexible%20Teaching/SharingWarpwire.pdf)
on how to share Warpwire videos from previous courses with students.

**Does UD have a site license for Camtasia or other video editing
software?**\</br\> No. The university does have licenses for Snagit,
which has similar functionality. Contact
[onlinelearning@udayton.edu](mailto://onlinelearning@udayton.edu) for a
Snagit license. UD Users that want to purchase their own copy of
Camtasia can do so on their [educational technology
page](https://www.techsmith.com/store/snagit/education) for a discounted
rate. [Movavi Screen Recorder
Studio](https://www.movavi.com/screen-recorder/studio/buynow.html#main)
is similar to Camtasia but is much cheaper to purchase individually.
Both Camtasia and Movavi offer free trials for anyone looking to
download and test them out.

**How can I show a film online?**\</br\> If you need help showing a film
that you own on DVD or VHS during online please contact Chris Tangeman
[(ctangeman1@udayton.edu)](mailto:ctangeman1@udayton.edu) in Roesch
Library. Please provide him the name of the film(s) you would like to
show to your class, along with the course and section number. Chris will
do his best to procure an online version of the film(s) for your classes
through one of our online content providers. It is important to note
that not all films are available from these sources, so some requests
may not be able to be filled.

**How can my students create videos and share those with the
class?**\</br\> First, you should change your Warpwire Library settings
[to allow students to upload](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/fy8CAA/).
Then, send your students instructions for how you would like them to
create their presentation and where to post it. [Here are written
instructions](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/TeachingOnlineResources/Student%20Recording%20Video%20_%20Upload%20to%20Warpwire%20Instructions.pdf)
and a [video guide](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/j_UBAA/).

\<br/\>

### Attendance

**How can I see who attended my Zoom meeting?**\<br\> See this [two
minute demo video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9LKZKti8CPE).

**What is the best way to take attendance for large sections?**\</br\>
Instructors have the ability to view an auto-generated attendance report
after a Zoom session ends that includes the name of each user that
joined the session and how long they were present. The 'Report' link for
each meeting can be found under the 'Previous Meetings' tab within the
Zoom Meetings tool in Isidore. This saves the instructor from having to
take attendance during class.

Alternative approaches could include:

-   Using the 'Attendance tool in Isidore. This would require the
    instructor to mark students present. It could be used live during
    class or after-the-fact by consulting a secondary source (Zoom
    Reports, Google Form submissions, etc.)

**Can instructors expect in-person attendance for on-campus
students?**\</br\> Yes. Instructors can expect students that are
on-campus during the fall to attend class in-person but some flexibility
will likely be needed. There may also come times where an on-campus
student needs to quarantine and will be forced to miss class or attend
remotely through Zoom.

**What advice is given regarding an attendance policy?**\</br\>
Instructors have always had a great deal of latitude when it comes to
their attendance policies. In general, instructors can expect students
who are healthy and not under quarantine to attend class. With that
said, instructors should consider several important factors regarding
attendance and health. If instructors have very strict attendance
requirements, these requirements may actually encourage a sick student
to attend class so that they aren't penalized. Attendance policies
should not wind up making other people sick. Students that are
experiencing any symptoms should be encouraged to go to the Health
Center. As general advice, Instructors are encouraged to explain the
purpose of their attendance policy to students in their syllabus to
reinforce the value and rationale behind their policy.

**Can remote students just watch the recordings of my live sessions
rather than attend the live session?**\</br\> Zoom cam automatically be
set to record all meetings held on the platform and that function may
prove useful to all students. However, recordings of class should not
predominantly take the place of live class attendance. On occasion, it
may be necessary to simply refer one or more students to recordings of
class sessions. However, the expectation is that students will attend
class sessions either in person or through Zoom. Exceptions to this can
be made at the professor's discretion.

\<br/\>

### Zoom {#zoom_1}

**How can I download the Chat file?** \<br/\> The Chat file currently
cannot be downloaded from within your Zoom meeting due to a security
issue. If you are recording the meeting to the Cloud, the chat messages
will be saved as one of the files included with the recording.

**How can I copy and paste in the Chat?** \<br/\> Unfortunately, copy
and paste does not currently work in the Chat because we had to turn off
the ability to download chat for security reasons. You can click on the
links in the Chat or take screenshots of it.

**I really need to be able to download the Chat. How can I enable it?**
\<br/\> You can turn on the setting to the download the chat. However,
we **highly** recommend disabling private chats and/or letting students
know that their private chats can be viewed by others. [a quick demo
video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bcYSFtE4ymEHere's).

**How can I change what\'s being recorded by Zoom? Speaker view isn\'t
what I want recorded.** \<br/\> Users can log into their UD Zoom
accounts at <https://udayton.zoom.us> and change what views are being
recorded by Zoom. [This video](https://www.screencast.com/t/rlRbDlus6)
outlines the steps to follow to adjust your recording settings for
future meetings.

**How can my students see my recordings? They\'re getting an error
message.**\<br/\> Students must first log in to go.udayton.edu/zoom in
order to see your recordings in Isidore. Please send them [this
guide](https://udayton.edu/0/elearning/Instructions%20for%20Students%20to%20Access%20Zoom%20Recordings.pdf),
and that should enable them to see the recordings.

**How can I share my Zoom recordings with students who were not in the
original class?**\<br/\> Please see [our guide for sharing Zoom
recordings](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/01%20Flexible%20Teaching/SharingZoom.pdf).
**Please be aware of the FERPA considerations you must account for when
sharing Zoom recordings.** The FERPA warning is spelled out in the
guide.

**How can I see who attended my Zoom meeting?**\<br\> See this
[two-minute demo video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9LKZKti8CPE).

**How can I trim my recording?**\<br/\> You can trim the ends and
beginnings of your recordings. Please see this [2 minute demo
video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qAetQt_EVg8). If you need to cut
out segments in the middle of videos, you will need to use a more
advanced video editing software like
[Snagit](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-coursecontent-sharingvideos).

**How can I set up polls in Zoom?** \<br/\> Please see [this
demonstration video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rauhbFD1AIs).

**How can I see who watched my Zoom recordings?**\<br/\> Please see
[this one minute demo
video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RseiMDIvQG4).

**What\'s the best way to schedule Office Hours with Zoom?**\<br/\>
Please see [our quick
video](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-zoom-officehours)
that provides a few options for how to set up Office Hours with Zoom.

**How can I schedule Zoom appointments and Office Hours in Google
Calendar?**\<br/\> Please see [this
video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ilfAHZOsYp0) that demonstrates
how to use appointment slots and Zoom within Google Calendar, and then
post that appointment calendar in Isidore.

**How can I schedule Zoom sessions for multiple rosters within my
Isidore site?**\<br/\> Please see [this
video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pkiax9aH3BQ) that demonstrates
how we recommend approaching this.

**Zoom doesn\'t let me schedule my meeting that starts at 9:05 AM. It
only lets me schedule at 9:00 AM. What should I do?**\<br/\> Just choose
the 9:00 AM option. All this means is that students can technically join
the meeting room 5 minutes prior to class beginning - which is actually
nice. It\'s equivalent to a student showing up in the classroom early.
As for the meeting ending time, you can choose the Zoom timeslot that is
before your actual Zoom meeting end time. The Zoom room will not close
at this time - it just means that the button to \'join\' the meeting
will disappear at that time.

**Can I require that students turn on their webcams in Zoom?**\</br\>
While this decision is ultimately up to each individual instructor it's
generally acceptable to require that students turn on their webcams
during Zoom sessions. Students are required to have working webcams and
microphones on their computers this fall. With that said, instructors
should be aware that some students may be unable to turn their webcam on
at all times (for good reason) and that it could shine a light on
certain inequities between students with them having to reveal their
location/background. Instructors should be clear about their
expectations in Zoom with their students from the beginning. Try not to
focus on making them have their webcam on to focus their attention but
instead how it will benefit the class experience.

**What is the best practice/protocol if a student experiences technical
difficulties (Wifi, application issues, hardware issues) while attending
class via Zoom?**\</br\> Students that experience technical difficulties
should be directed to the UDit Service Center (937-229-3888 or
<itservicecenter@udayton.edu>). While it can be expected that some
students will experience issues during the semester the key is to not
let it become a trend. The student should not be penalized for missing a
single class because of a bad internet connection or hardware failure
that they have little control over but it would be fair for the
instructor to ask the student how they might be able to avoid similar
issues moving forward.

Recording class Zoom sessions is a great way to allow a student that has
technology issues during a class period to catch up on what they've
missed.

Depending on the attendance policy, instructors may ask students that
will miss class (or get kicked off during class) for technological
reasons to send them an email alerting them to their absence and
complete a quick summary of the important points after watching the
class session recording.

**Will classrooms be equipped with cameras that will follow me as I move
around? Where are the microphones located and how far can I get from
them and still be heard?**\</br\> Classrooms are not equipped with
cameras that will follow instructors. All classroom cameras are fixed to
the podium, which means that instructors should be prepared to deliver
their content from behind the podium. The microphones are built-in to
the webcams and will not work well if the faculty member moves farther
than 6-8 feet from them. It will be important for instructors to check
with remote students periodically each class to ensure they can hear the
class.

**What is the recommended method of having students joining Zoom
sessions?**\</br\> Instructors are encouraged to [add their Zoom
sessions](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-zoom-meetings)
in the Zoom Meetings tool located in their Isidore site. This gives
students a central and consistent spot to join Zoom sessions and access
past Zoom session recordings which automatically populate back into the
Isidore Zoom Meetings tool. Instructors can also access their UD Zoom
account outside of Isidore at <https://go.udayton.edu/zoom>. Instructors
will need to share meeting URLs with students for any meetings created
outside of Isidore.

**What are the passcodes within Zoom meetings?**\</br\> Please see our
[Zoom_FAQs](Zoom_FAQs "wikilink") about the passcodes.

**How do I set up pre-assigned breakout rooms?**\</br\> Please see our
[step-by-step
guide](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/01%20Flexible%20Teaching/Using%20Pre-Assigned%20Breakout%20Rooms%20in%20Zoom.pdf)
and our [demo video](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/W1YCAA/). Feel free
to send [this
guide](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/01%20Flexible%20Teaching/Student%20Guide%20for%20Pre-Assigned%20Breakout%20Rooms%20in%20Zoom.pdf)
to your students to help them get started.

**How can I stop students from annotating while I am sharing something
with them (ppt, whiteboard, website, etc.)?**\<br/\> Non-hosts in Zoom
(students) have the ability to annotate by default in Zoom. Instructors
can disable annotations at any time. Please see this [2 minute demo
video](https://www.screencast.com/t/yFfUqLVuWW) for how to disable
annotations in a Zoom meeting.

**How can I see the Participants and Chat windows while sharing my
screen in a Zoom meeting?**\<br/\> The key is keep whatever you\'re
sharing from taking up the whole screen so that you will have some real
estate to open the Participants and Chat windows up without having them
overlap your content. Please see this [2 minute demo
video](https://youtu.be/UeFrkPobKbk) on how to manage this in a Zoom
meeting.

**What do the Spotlight and Pin features in Zoom do and how can I use
them?**\<br/\> The host of a meeting can right-click on a any users\'
tile in Zoom to \'Spotlight\' them for everyone in a meeting. This
forces everyone\'s view into \'Speaker View\' in Zoom, puts the
spotlighted individual(s) in the main window, and keeps them there for
everyone else to see until the spotlight is removed. Alternatively,
individuals can right-click on a any users\' tile in Zoom to \'Pin\'
them within their own view. This does not affect the view of others in
the meeting. Please see this [2 minute
demonstration](https://youtu.be/BNurAcbP3GE) of how to use these
features and how they affect the users in a meeting.

**How can I enable live transcripts for students?**\<br/\> The host of
the meeting must turn on the live transcript setting within each Zoom
meeting in order for participants to be able to see live transcripts.
Please [refer to this
guide](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/01%20Flexible%20Teaching/Enabling%20Live%20Captions%20in%20Zoom.pdf)
for instructions.

### Student Resources {#student_resources}

**What resources do students have for this semester?**\<br/\> Front and
center on every students homepage of Isidore, there is a link to our
[Keep Learning website](https://isidore.udayton.edu/keeplearning/) that
provides students with information about blended course delivery,
technical help resources, and learning support resources.

**How can students add videos to my class?**\<br/\> First, make sure
your Warpwire Library is [set up to allow students to upload
videos](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Allow_students_to_upload_videos_to_Warpwire).
Then, share with your students the [written instructions for uploading
videos](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Allow_students_to_upload_videos_to_Warpwire)
and and/or the [video instructions for uploading
videos](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/j_UBAA/).

### Course Planning {#course_planning}

**How do I know if I\'m ready to start the fall semester?**\</br\>
Please read through the [Faculty Readiness
Checklist](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1p4mjBLGVNj7JclmK1Af8RUsJuVNhy5XsmtT6lcHSZzg/view)
prepared by the Office of the Provost. It contains information and
multiple checklists aimed at helping faculty prepare their courses,
prepare for the classroom, and prepare for their students.

**Are there any guidelines I need to follow in delivering my course this
fall**\</br\> Yes. You are encouraged to review the [Fall 2020 Course
Facilitation & Engagement
Guidelines](https://isidore.udayton.edu/keepteaching/guidelines/index.html).

**Can my course be offered fully asynchronously?**\</br\> In general,
the answer is no. The University expects that all classes will be
delivered synchronously, whether online or in person. Certainly,
instructors may need to rely on recorded materials to deliver some
course content. However, this should not take away from students
engaging synchronously with instructors and classmates.

**Is there a standard template for course syllabi?**\</br\> The Center
for Online Learning has created a [Flexible Teaching Syllabus
Template](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/01%20Flexible%20Teaching/Flexible%20Teaching%20Syllabus%20Template.docx)
that faculty are encouraged to download and review. The template
syllabus contains all of UD's policies and campus services for students
as well as many elements that will assist faculty in properly planning
their course to support flexible teaching this fall.

**Do the new reduced classroom capacities include the
instructor?**\</br\> They do not include instructors. This means that if
an instructor is teaching in a room with a capacity of 20 they are
allowed to have 20 students PLUS the instructor in the room. TAs and the
like will need to be viewed as 'students' when considering how many can
attend.

**When will fall Isidore sites be made available to students?**\</br\>
To ensure that students have access to any potential grouping or
attendance information ahead of the first day of classes the Center for
Online Learning will publish all fall sites at 8 AM on Thursday, August
20th. Instructors are welcome to make their sites available earlier by
clicking on the 'Publish Now' button in the yellow bar at the top of
their site.

**How do I know if I have everything ready in my Isidore sites?**\</br\>
The Center for Online Learning has created an [Isidore Readiness
Checklist](https://isidore.udayton.edu/keepteaching/checklists/isidore.html).
It provides a high-level overview of the steps faculty should take to
prepare each of their Isidore course sites for the fall term.

**Do I have to use 11:55 PM as the due times? Do I have to use Sundays
at my due dates?**\</br\> No. What matters most is establishing a
consistent schedule throughout the semester. Choose dates and times that
make most sense for YOU and for your classes. We recommend no more than
2 due dates per week, and keep those dates and times consistent as much
as possible. You may want to schedule due dates on days when you know
you can be available to answer last minute questions.

**How should I handle holidays?**\</br\> Try to avoid putting due dates
on holidays, but remember that if you have given students plenty of time
to complete the assignments, there shouldn't be a need to change your
schedule just because there are holidays.

**Do I have to break my course down on a week-by-week basis?**\</br\> We
do recommend using the week-by-week template, but if you break down your
content in chunks of 2 weeks, that's fine, too. Just be consistent and
clear with your due dates. [Here's a
video](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/QR8CAA/) that shows you how to
adjust the template into 2 week chunks.

**Where do I need to add dates? It looks like there's a lot of spots for
dates.**\</br\> There are 3 spots where you will need to add dates
throughout the template site. [Here's a 2 minute
video](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/CfoBAA/) demonstrating where the
dates need to be entered.`</text>`{=html}

## General instructions {#general_instructions}

For the tool to distinguish between questions, each question must begin
with the word \"Question\" or a number; for graded questions, include
the number of possible points in parentheses.

All of the following are valid:

Question 23 (10 points) \<br /\> 23. (10 points) \<br /\> Question 23
\<br /\> 23. \<br /\>\<br /\> **Note:** the entries above without \"(10
points)\" would result in a question worth zero points.

The text of the question itself may be placed on this same line or below
it, and should be followed by answers in the appropriate format for that
question type. The parser will use this format to deduce the question
type of the question.

c. Lincoln \<br /\> d. Clinton \<br /\>\<br /\>

`     ``<text bytes="5762" sha1="trfteazasqcooh7bz6phjx6cl8hiutb" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`The steps below outline the process that students will need to follow to complete the ProctorTrack Onboarding assessment. `

Students completing ProctorTrack assessments from China using a VPN will
need to [follow special
steps.](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/ProctorTrack/Using%20ProctorTrack%20from%20China.pdf)

Each student must successfully complete an onboarding assessment in
Proctortrack before they will be able to take proctored online tests.
Students should complete the onboarding quiz at least 1-2 days before
their first "real" proctored exam. Unless otherwise specified by the
instructor, the onboarding quiz is a simple ungraded quiz that only
contains a few questions). It serves these purposes:

-   Downloads and installs software (and browser plug-in, if required)
    needed for proctoring.
-   Runs a system check to make sure you have the necessary equipment.
-   Performs an identity check.
-   Lets you practice the same steps you will go through when taking
    your "real" proctored exam.

## Before Your Begin {#before_your_begin}

-   Take the onboarding quiz on the same computer you will use later for
    taking your "real" exam.
-   Your computer must meet the [technical requirements for
    Proctortrack](https://www.proctortrack.com/tech-requirements/):
    -   You must use a computer (Windows or Mac) -- not a Chromebook,
        mobile device, or tablet.
    -   You must have a working webcam and microphone.
-   Prepare your workspace -- remove all papers, books, devices.
-   Make sure you have a valid ID handy (will be needed for identity
    check). Valid IDs include:
    -   UD ID card
    -   Valid Driver's License
    -   Valid passport
-   Make sure you have either Chrome (preferred) or Firefox installed on
    your computer.
    -   You cannot use Safari, Edge, or other browsers for proctored
        testing

## Steps to Complete the ProctorTrack Onboarding Assessment {#steps_to_complete_the_proctortrack_onboarding_assessment}

The following video provides a step-by-step walkthrough of how to
complete the onboarding assessment in your class Isidore site.
\<youtube\>V1nqzgdLmXg\</youtube\>

1.  Close ALL applications on your computer.
2.  Open **Chrome** (preferred) or Firefox web browser. Make sure only
    one tab is open. Log in to Isidore.
3.  Click on the 'ProctorTrack' tool in the Isidore course site.
4.  In the Test List section of the page, click on the 'Go To Test'
    button next to the 'ProctorTrack Onboarding'
5.  Read through the ProctorTrack settings for this assessment. This
    page will explain what you are allowed and not allowed to do while
    taking your test through ProctorTrack.

    NOTE - The settings for this test may be different than the settings for other tests. For example, in other tests, you may be permitted to use digital resources. It is important that you thoroughly review the settings for any exam you take through ProctorTrack so you know what rules are in place.
6.  Check the box at the bottom of the page, and click on the 'Go To
    Next Step' button.
7.  Following the onscreen prompts to download, install, and run the
    ProctorTrack application on your computer.
8.  The ProctorTrack application will automatically launch on your
    computer. You will be guided through the following steps:
    1.  Agree to the privacy policy by checking the box.
    2.  Begin the system check by pressing the 'Start System Check'
        button
        1.  Select the microphone and webcam that you will use and press
            the 'Confirm' button.
        2.  During the system check, you may be prompted to:
            -   Unplug devices in your room or house
            -   Unplug external devices such as flash drives, mice,
                monitors, etc.
            -   Close applications on your computer that are not
                permitted. **Make sure you save any open documents or
                files you want to preserve** before pressing the 'Close'
                button.
    3.  Scan your face by following the on-screen instructions. Press
        'no' to re-scan. Press 'yes' if the scan is satisfactory.
    4.  Scan your Student ID by following the on-screen instructions.
        Press 'no' to re-scan. Press 'yes' if the scan is satisfactory.
    5.  The Exam Guidelines will again be available to review. Review
        the guidelines as necessary, then click the 'I Agree, Let's
        Begin' button. This will launch a new tab in your browser.
9.  Click the 'Exam Password' button to copy the exam password and then
    use the Ctrl+V or Cmd+V keys on your keyboard to paste the password
    in the box provided.
10. Click the 'Begin Assessment' button.
11. Complete and submit the exam in Isidore.
12. End the Proctoring Session by clicking on the 'End' button in the
    top right corner.
13. Confirm that you want to end the proctoring session by checking the
    box next to 'Yes, I have completed and submitted my test.' Click
    'End' again.
14. Your proctoring session will be uploaded. **Do not close ProtorTrack
    until it says "Uploading Complete."**
15. Click on the 'Quit App' button to finish. \[You may uninstall the
    application at this time if you\'d like.\]

You should receive an email within 4-6 hours of taking the ProctorTrack
Onboarding assessment to let you know if you have passed or not. You can
also return to the ProctorTrack tool in our site to see if you have
passed the onboarding assessment. Passing the onboarding assessment has
nothing to do with your score on the actual quiz. Passing the onboarding
assessment means that you've successfully installed the software,
completed the ID scans, taken the test, and properly ended and uploaded
your proctoring session.

If you did not pass the ProctorTrack Onboarding assessment, you will
need to follow the same steps and take it again. You MUST pass the
Onboarding Test before you will be able to take the test in your class.
All students are advised to take the Onboarding Test no later than 2
days before their actual test. \<br /\>\<br /\> Return to [ProctorTrack
for Students](ProctorTrack_for_Students "wikilink") `</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="2489" sha1="nxh7ygp63imszx8ifhlb4bq2lo6dc71" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`If Zoom is not an option, you are able to use the Google Meet web conferencing platform associated with your UD Gmail account. These instructions will walk you through scheduling a Google Meet session.`

**Note:** *Though you are free to use Google Meet, Zoom is the only web
conferencing platform for which UD will provide user support. It is
recommended that you use Zoom if possible.*

## Scheduling a Google Meet Session {#scheduling_a_google_meet_session}

Use these steps to schedule a Google Meet session with any individuals
or entire class rosters.

#### Step 1: Create a Google Calendar Event {#step_1_create_a_google_calendar_event}

Use your preferred process to begin creating a Google Calendar Event.
Enter a title and time frame for the meeting. If you want to start the
meeting immediately, set the time frame for current time. [How to create
Calendar events](https://support.google.com/calendar/answer/72143?hl=en)

#### Step 2: Add Google Meet Video Conferencing {#step_2_add_google_meet_video_conferencing}

While creating your Calendar event, choose the option to **Add video
conferencing** and select **Google Meet**.
![](GMeetConf.jpg "GMeetConf.jpg")

#### Step 3: Add Attendees or Class Rosters {#step_3_add_attendees_or_class_rosters}

While creating your Calendar event, click on the **Add guests** option.
You can add individual guests by name or email, or you can add a class
roster by typing the roster in the following format: "BIO 101". Then
select your course section from the list.
![](GMeetRoster.jpg "GMeetRoster.jpg")

#### Step 4: Verify Settings & Save {#step_4_verify_settings_save}

Double check that your Calendar event settings are correct and **Save**.
This will trigger an email to all the individuals you added to the
event. This invite will include a link to the Google Meet session.

*We recommend, especially the first couple times you do this, to also
send a separate communication to explain that your guests need to check
their email and calendar for the invitation and to look for the meeting
link.*

#### Step 5: Join the Meeting {#step_5_join_the_meeting}

At the appointed time, you can click the Google Meet link by opening the
event in your Google Calendar. Click the **Join with Google Meet**
button and it will launch the meeting.

*If it's your first time using the software, grant permission to allow
Google Meet to access your camera and microphone when prompted.*

![](GMeetCalJoin.jpg "GMeetCalJoin.jpg")

Google Meet will open in your browser. Click the **Join now** link to
begin your session.

For more information, please refer to the [Google Meet Help
Documentation](https://support.google.com/meet/?hl=en#topic=7306097)

To add a threaded discussion:

1.  Navigate to a Lessons page or subpage in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **Add Learning App**.
3.  Select **Learning App Store**.
4.  Click on **+Install** next to Threaded Discussion.
    -   Enter a title of the discussion (topic) and a description of the
        discussion. *You\'ll want to change the default title of the
        item from \"Threaded Discussion\" to something else, as items
        can\'t have the same name in Gradebook.*
    -   Next to \"Configure LineItem\", select \"Send LineItem\".
    -   Enter a maximum possible score for an activity (a numeric point
        value).
    -   Leave the \"Tool provided ID\" blank.
    -   Leave the \"A tag used to mark this item.\" blank.
    -   *(Optional)* Set the available dates (students will be able to
        see and read the threaded discussion between these dates).
    -   *(Optional)* Set the submission dates (students will be able to
        add a thread and reply between these dates).
5.  Click on **Submit**.
6.  Click on the title of the threaded discussion to launch it.
7.  Click on **Settings**.
    -   Check the box next to \"Give a 100% grade for a student making a
        post or comment.\"
8.  Click on **Save changes**.
9.  As students add a thread or reply, a gradebook item will be created
    and their scores will appear automatically. **Currently, students
    will only receive credit for replying to a thread, not creating a
    new thread.**

If you would like to set advanced grading options, please see the
[Adjust Threaded Discussion
Settings](Adjust_Threaded_Discussion_Settings "wikilink") page. \<br
/\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Threaded
Discussion](Threaded_Discussion "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}
