## Returning to Classic Grader {#returning_to_classic_grader}

New Grader is enabled by default, but if you would like to switch back
to Classic Grader, follow these steps:

1.  Navigate to your Isidore course site.
2.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool.
3.  Click on the **Grade** link beneath the title of the assignment you
    wish to grade.
4.  Ensure that the box next to \"Use new Grader to grade submissions\"
    is unchecked. This check box is located in the upper right-hand
    portion of the screen.
5.  Proceed with grading students\' submissions.

## Grading within Isidore\'s Assignments Tool {#grading_within_isidores_assignments_tool}

To review student submissions and grade assignments:

1.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  You will see a list of assignments.
3.  The \"In / New\" column displays the number of submissions that have
    come in from students (the \"In\" value) and the number of new
    submissions (the \"New\" value) for each assignment.
4.  Under the name of the assignment you want to grade, click **Grade**.
    You will see a table with a list of students\' names. Click on an
    individual student\'s name to view and grade their submission.
    -   *If a student has saved an assignment as a draft, you will be
        able to grade the assignment, but you will be unable to see the
        text of the student\'s draft until the due date has passed.*
5.  Under \"Assignment Submission\", you\'ll see the student\'s
    attachment or submitted text.
6.  Next to \"Grade\", select the grade for the student\'s assignment,
    or enter points in the box.
7.  To leave comments, you have the following options:
    -   If the submission type is inline or inline and attachments, you
        can add comments to the student\'s submitted text by clicking on
        the **Provide Inline Comments** button, and then typing into the
        \"Assignment Submission\" text box. We recommend enclosing your
        comments in double curly brackets, for example:
        \<nowiki\>`{{Cite your sources, please.}}`{=mediawiki}\</nowiki\>
        The student will see your comments appear in red.
    -   Under \"Instructor Comments\", you can enter summary comments in
        the text box (no special formatting is required).
8.  If you would like to add an attachment to give to the student, click
    **Add Attachments**.
9.  If you wish to allow the student to resubmit the assignment, check
    \"Allow Resubmission\", and use the drop-down menu to set the number
    of resubmissions allowed. Then, next to \"Accept Until\", set a
    resubmission deadline.
10. When grading is complete, click **Save and Release to Student** to
    make the student\'s assignment grade immediately available, or click
    **Save and Don\'t Release to Student** to return to the submitted
    assignments list to continue grading.
    -   If you choose the \"Save and Don\'t Release to Student\" option,
        you\'ll need to release all of the grades when you\'re finished
        grading. When you are ready to make feedback available to
        students and/or to send grades to the Gradebook, click on the
        **Release Grades** link when viewing the student list for an
        assignment.

## Grading Assignments Offline Using the Bulk Download Feature {#grading_assignments_offline_using_the_bulk_download_feature}

\<youtube\>apuH8c9GeC0\</youtube\>

1.  From your Isidore course\'s tool menu, go into the **Assignments**
    tool and click the **Grade** link under the assignment you will be
    grading.
2.  You are now looking at the submission list for your entire class.
    You can use the \"View\" drop‐down menu to select specific groups in
    your site instead of your whole class, if desired. You can grade
    each student individually by clicking on the student's name but that
    may take a long time in a large site. There is a much simpler way
    that involves downloading all of the assignment files, viewing and
    grading the assignments offline, and re‐uploading everything quickly
    and easily to the site.
3.  Click the link at the top of the page that says **Download All**. On
    the next page, check the box next to \"All\". You will be prompted
    to save the ZIP file somewhere on your computer. Save it somewhere
    obvious, such as your Desktop or your Downloads folder.
4.  Once the file is downloaded, right‐click on the bulk_download.zip
    file you downloaded and select **Extract All...**
5.  In the \"Files will be extracted to this folder\" text box, replace
    the bulk_download text with something meaningful (i.e. Assignment
    7). Then click on the **Extract** button.
6.  A new window will open with a folder with the title of the
    Assignment submissions you downloaded. Double click on the folder to
    open it.
7.  Inside the assignment folder you will notice that each student has
    their own folder. In each student folder you will find the following
    items:
    -   Submission Attachment(s) folder -- If the student submitted
        their assignment as an attachment (MS Word document) you will
        find the file(s) in this folder.
    -   Feedback Attachment(s) folder --This folder is where you can
        save marked up files that you want to return to the student
        through Isidore. Any file that is saved into this folder will be
        returned to the student with their grade.
    -   Comments.txt ‐ This file can be used to type general comments to
        be returned to the students with their grade. Simply open the
        file, type in your comments, and save it to its current location
        before closing.
    -   Student Name_submissionText ‐ If the student submitted their
        assignment inline using the online WYSIWYG HTML editor their
        submission will be in this file. You can open it by
        double‐clicking on it but you will need to open it in Microsoft
        Expression Web or FrontPage if you wish to make edits to it.
    -   feedbackText.html ‐ If you open the student's inline submission
        file and make changes in it (mentioned above) you will want to
        do a 'Save As' as opposed to a 'Save' and overwrite this file.
        This will allow the students to see their original submission
        WITH your comments in the file.
8.  In the simplest use, most faculty will look in the folders at the
    submitted files, possible write some notes in the student's
    comments.txt file, and assign a grade as described in the next step.
9.  In the main assignments folder, along with the student folders, you
    will see a grades.csv file. Double click on it to open it.
10. In the file you will see a \"grade\" column where you can record the
    score for each student. Save and close the grades file when you're
    done in the same location.
    -   You don't need to grade every student at once. You can grade
        half the class, for example, and move on to the uploading steps
        without causing any problems.
11. Once you've entered the grades and made all of the necessary changes
    in the student folders you will need to ZIP everything back together
    so you can upload it back into Isidore.
12. Right‐click on the main assignment folder and select Send To -\>
    Compressed (zipped) folder from the menu that appears. This process
    will take a few seconds and you will see a ZIP file appear in the
    same directory. This is the file you will need to upload into
    Isidore.
13. Next, go back into the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore site and
    click the **Grade** link under the assignment title you are grading.
14. Click the **Upload All** link towards the top of the window.
15. On the next page use the **Browse** or **Choose File** button to
    find and upload the ZIP file you created in the steps above.
16. Next, check the boxes of the elements you want to return to the
    students and decided whether you want to release the information to
    the students immediately or not. It is generally safe to click all
    of the boxes if you're unsure.
17. Click the **Upload** button to complete the process. The upload may
    take a few minutes. If done correctly, the grades and any uploaded
    files will be added to your site.

## Enabling New Grader {#enabling_new_grader}

New Grader is enabled by default. But, if you\'ve switched to Classic
Grader and wish to re-enable New Grader, follow these steps:

1.  Navigate to your Isidore course site.
2.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool.
3.  Click on the **Grade** link beneath the title of the assignment you
    wish to grade.
4.  Ensure that the box next to \"Use new Grader to grade submissions\"
    is checked. This check box is located in the upper right-hand
    portion of the screen.
5.  Proceed with grading students\' submissions.

## Using New Grader to Grade Assignment Submissions {#using_new_grader_to_grade_assignment_submissions}

To review student submissions and grade assignments:

1.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  You will see a list of assignments.
3.  The \"In / New\" column displays the number of submissions that have
    come in from students (the \"In\" value) and the number of new
    submissions (the \"New\" value) for each assignment.
4.  Under the name of the assignment you want to grade, click **Grade**.
    You will see a table with a list of students\' names. Click on an
    individual student\'s name to view and grade their submission.
    -   *If a student has saved an assignment as a draft, you will be
        able to grade the assignment, but you will be unable to see the
        text of the student\'s draft until the due date has passed.*
5.  The text of the student\'s submission will be displayed on the
    screen. If the student submitted more than one file, you can click
    on the links under \"Submitted Attachments\" to view text of the
    other submitted files.
6.  Next to \"Grade\", select the grade for the student\'s assignment,
    or enter points in the box.
7.  You can click on the **Feedback Comments** button to enter your
    grading comments that students will see.
8.  You can click on the **Add Attachments** button to upload a feedback
    file for students to review.
9.  If you wish to allow the student to resubmit the assignment, check
    \"Allow Resubmission\", and use the drop-down menu to set the number
    of resubmissions allowed. Then, next to \"Accept Resubmission
    Until\", set a resubmission deadline.
10. When grading is complete, click **Save and Release to Student** to
    make the student\'s assignment grade immediately available, or click
    **Save** to return to the submitted assignments list to continue
    grading.
    -   If you choose the \"Save\" option, you\'ll need to release
        grades to all students when you\'re finished grading. When you
        are ready to make feedback available and/or send grades to the
        Gradebook, click on the **Release Grades** link when you\'re
        viewing the list of students for an assignment.

Some course sites may not appear in the Gradebook Summary list. If an
individual has the \"Student\" role in a course site and the site is
published, it will appear in their list. However, instructors may choose
whether to use Isidore\'s Gradebook tool and whether to make course
grade percentages and/or letter grades available.

**Important Notes:**

-   **The calculated course grades in Isidore do not represent official
    course grades. To view official course grades, please use the Flyer
    Student Services tab in Porches.**
-   **The calculated course grade may be inaccurate if there are
    ungraded or missing items in the Gradebook.**

## Add the Gradebook Summary widget {#add_the_gradebook_summary_widget}

To add the Gradebook Summary widget:

1.  Navigate to your **[Home (Isidore
    Home)](Home_(Isidore_Home) "wikilink")**.
2.  Make sure the **Overview** tool is selected in the menu on the left.
3.  Click on **[Manage Overview](Manage_Overview "wikilink")** in the
    upper right-hand corner of the screen.
4.  Click on the **+ Gradebook Summary** link under \"Available
    Widgets\".
5.  Use the up, down, left, and right arrows to move the Gradebook
    Summary widget to the desired location.
6.  Click on **Save**.

## View grades using the Gradebook Summary widget {#view_grades_using_the_gradebook_summary_widget}

To view your current course grade:

1.  Navigate to your **[Home (Isidore
    Home)](Home_(Isidore_Home) "wikilink")**.
2.  Make sure the **Overview** tool is selected in the menu on the left.
3.  Locate the Gradebook Summary widget. If you\'re in a private
    location to view your grades, click on the **Show Grades** button.

## Hide courses from the Gradebook Summary widget {#hide_courses_from_the_gradebook_summary_widget}

Students may choose to hide courses from their Grade Summary widget.
*Note: If you\'ve hidden a site in your
[Preferences](Preferences "wikilink"), it will not appear in the
Gradebook Summary widget or on the Options tab.*

To hide course(s):

1.  Navigate to your **[Home (Isidore
    Home)](Home_(Isidore_Home) "wikilink")**.
2.  Make sure the **Overview** tool is selected in the menu on the left.
3.  Click on the **Options** tab.
4.  Check the box next to courses you don\'t wish to see in the
    Gradebook Summary widget.
5.  Click on **Update**.

## Create a Gradebook Item {#create_a_gradebook_item}

Before following the other directions on this page, you must first
create an item in the Gradebook to link the forum posting grades to; for
instructions, see [Add/Edit/Delete Gradebook
Items](Add/Edit/Delete_Gradebook_Items "wikilink").

## Setting Up Forums and Topics for Grading {#setting_up_forums_and_topics_for_grading}

To setup grading in forums and topics:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Click on either **Forum Settings** or **Topic Settings** next to the
    forum or topic you want linked to the gradebook item.
3.  Expand the \"Grading\" section and select the gradebook item you
    created from the drop-down menu. *If the item doesn\'t yet appear,
    you may need to refresh the Forums tool and repeat these steps.*
4.  Scroll down and click on the **Save** button once you\'ve selected
    the gradebook item.

## Grading Forum Posts {#grading_forum_posts}

To grade an individual student\'s post:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click the title of the topic.
3.  Find and click the individual message to grade, and then click the
    **Grade** link at the top of the message.
4.  Enter a point value for a grade and any comments.
5.  When you\'re finished, click **Submit Grade**.

To grade several or all students\' posts:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **Statistics & Grading**.
3.  Click on **Statistics & Grading by Topic**.
4.  Click on a topic title or a forum title.
5.  You may either click on the **Grade** link next to each individual
    student to enter scores and comments, or you can select the
    gradebook item from the drop-down menu to grade all students.
    -   If you\'ve selected a gradebook item, point text boxes will be
        displayed where you can enter numeric scores for students, enter
        zeros by applying grades to all ungraded, and then click on the
        **Submit Grades** button.
6.  The scores should now be updated in Gradebook.

`     ``<text bytes="14350" sha1="l9xhvpgdgtpmp39ed4kd2wifiotjbdh" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Assessments are an essential piece of any class to ensure your students have effectively learned the content of your course. Assessments in an online or hybrid class do present some unique challenges with potential technical roadblocks, difficulty with preventing cheating, and simply the stress of reformatting a traditionally face-to-face assessment for an online environment. `

Below are several sections of guidance that will hopefully be helpful to
you as you plan assessments for an online or hybrid class.

## General Advice for Online Assessments {#general_advice_for_online_assessments}

Below are a few tips for ensuring a successful approach to assessments.

-   Start planning your assessments early. \</br\>

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```
-   Review the [University\'s guidance for in-person
    exams](https://docs.google.com/document/d/e/2PACX-1vQ7-ElxPmVxlq2StvaIXQsPDNQQA2SZd95O4mRGAE5trybRTtje-CWucOIlKSKAXl4-4Y4YaYvXmFiw/pub?urp=gmail_link#h.hsm4mhvw2fkg).

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```
-   Ensure your assessments align with your course learning objectives.
    If your assessments do not adequately measure if students have
    achieved the learning objectives, then the assessment should be
    re-thought or re-designed. \</br\>

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```
-   Provide your students with examples or practice opportunities for
    high-stakes assessments so students have an idea of what to expect.
    This is especially important for assessments that require the usage
    of a lot of technology.\</br\>

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```
-   Be prepared to be flexible with your assessment approach. Technology
    and/or accessibility limitations may prevent some students for
    successfully completing exams, so you should provide ways to either
    alternatively measure the students\' learning or provide the
    resources for them to be able to complete the exam offline. Consult
    the Chair of your department for advice and guidance on this.
    \</br\>

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```
-   To minimize academic dishonesty, consider using an alternative
    approach to traditional exams with multiple choice questions.
    Alternative approaches you can consider are listed
    [below](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Guide_for_Online_Assessments#Alternatives_to_Exams).
    \<br/\>

## Proctored Exams {#proctored_exams}

Traditional timed, proctored exams are possible using the Tests &
Quizzes tool in Isidore and the
[ProctorTrack](ProctorTrack_for_Instructors "wikilink") service.
However, **proctored remote exams have several drawbacks** and **we
recommend carefully considering** [alternative approaches to
assessments](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Tips_for_Exams_and_Alternative_Assessments#Alternatives_to_Exams)
or [strategies to reduce
cheating](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Tips_for_Exams_and_Alternative_Assessments#Strategies_to_Reduce_Cheating_with_Online_Assessments)
before moving forward with a proctored exam with ProctorTrack. You
should also consider allowing students to [self-proctor via
Zoom](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/TeachingOnlineResources/StudentSelfRecordingInstructionsZoom.pdf)
as a potential alternative.

Here are some drawbacks of proctored exams delivered through
ProctorTrack you should be aware of:

-   They are often even more stressful for students than in-person
    proctored or self-proctored exams, which can negatively impact
    student performance.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```
-   They require substantial planning and set up on the part of the
    instructor and the student. Instructors may need to spend
    substantial time reviewing any flags generated by ProctorTrack.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```
-   Some students may encounter technical problems while taking
    assessments through ProctorTrack because of the extremely stringent
    requirements the service has to ensure secure exams. Instructors
    should be prepared to make accommodations for students who run into
    technical trouble.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```
-   Students may have legitimate privacy concerns about
    third-party-recorded remote proctoring. Students may request
    alternative formats for their assessments.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```
-   A [self-proctored exam via
    Zoom](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/TeachingOnlineResources/StudentSelfRecordingInstructionsZoom.pdf)
    requires much less set up and stress for instructors and students.

If you\'d like to set up a proctored exam with

## Alternatives to Proctored Exams {#alternatives_to_proctored_exams}

Some of the information below was adapted from [Rutgers\' guidance on
exams and alternative
assessments](https://sasoue.rutgers.edu/teaching-learning/remote-exams-assessment#10-alternatives-to-exams).

Your learning goals are an excellent place to start when considering
alternative assessments: what do you hope students will be able to do by
the end of your course, and in what ways can they demonstrate what they
know?

### Alternatives to Exams {#alternatives_to_exams}

-   Series of quizzes: offer a low-stakes opportunity for students to
    demonstrate mastery of material, and give you ongoing information
    about student understanding. Frequent quizzing has also been shown
    to reinforce student understanding. See [helpful information about
    writing good multiple choice
    questions](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Guide_for_Online_Assessments#Resources_for_Writing_Multiple_Choice_Exams),
    as well as [strategies to reduce
    cheating](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Strategies_for_Reducing_Cheating_with_Online_Assessments)
    using features in Isidore.
    -   Example: Create six (or more) quizzes rather than the
        traditional two exams. These could cumuluatively encompass a
        similar gradebook weight as the midterm and final often do. The
        final quiz should still be cumulative, but since the students
        have been proving their learning throughout the term, the heavy
        weighting on the final isn\'t as crucial.

\<br/\>

-   Student-developed quiz questions and answers: writing quiz questions
    both builds and demonstrates students' understanding of the
    material.
    -   Example: The following is a way to get students to take reading
        seriously, create friendly competition, and deepen their
        learning.
        -   Phase 1: At midweek students submit a proposed quiz question
            (essay style with answer) that demonstrates deep
            understanding of the reading. Quality is scored in the
            gradebook.
        -   Phase 2: You choose the best question and reward that
            student with a perfect score on the quiz in Phase 3.
            Consider switching it up if the same students are always
            winning
        -   Phase 3: In class, the winner is announced and that question
            is delivered as an OPEN-NOTE Quiz to the class. Quality is
            scored in the gradebook.

\<br/\>

-   Open-book, take-home assessments: many disciplines already have a
    tradition of take-home exams, typically involving more conceptual or
    applied questions that students cannot quickly look up in a
    textbook.
    -   Example: In a business statistics class, students might be
        provided with an Excel datasheet. Then, within that datasheet,
        they must perform different types of analysis to arrive at the
        correct answers. A [self-proctored Zoom
        exam](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/TeachingOnlineResources/StudentSelfRecordingInstructionsZoom.pdf)
        can capture the student\'s screen and webcam to ensure they are
        actually working through the problems themselves.

\<br/\>

-   Presentations or demonstrations: ask students to present to the
    class via Zoom or record themselves presenting while talking through
    a PowerPoint presentation. Either of the options below will help
    students create recorded demonstrations.
    -   [Instructions for Students to Self-Record with
        Zoom](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/TeachingOnlineResources/StudentSelfRecordingInstructionsZoom.pdf)
    -   [Instructions for Students to Record and Upload to
        Warpwire](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/TeachingOnlineResources/Student%20Recording%20Video%20_%20Upload%20to%20Warpwire%20Instructions.pdf)
    -   Example: Each student is assigned a concept from the class to
        \"teach\". Students create their own pre-recorded presentations
        about the topic and upload to the Forums tool in Isidore for
        other students to watch. Alternatively, the student presents
        their teaching of the concept during a live Zoom session.
        Instructors can use [Rubrics](Rubrics "wikilink") to evaluate
        the presentations.

\<br/\>

-   Peer- and self-review activity: these allow for personal reflection
    on learning and peer-to-peer instruction, both of which reinforce
    and deepen understanding. Students should receive guidance on how to
    provided constructive feedback. Instructors can provide students
    with rubrics to help guide them through this process.
    -   Example: Use peer review to allow students to find errors in
        each other\'s projects or papers BEFORE they submit them to you.
        Students will often be motivated to help one another in hopes
        that they do better when they submit for final grading. (Bonus:
        This will make grading easier on you!)

\<br/\>

-   E-Portfolio: a student-selected portfolio of work from the semester
    or preferably created to show the work of a full program. Students
    compile their best or representative work from the semester, writing
    a critical introduction to the portfolio and a brief introduction to
    each piece. The [CompFolio](CompFolio "wikilink") tool in Isidore
    can be used to have students submit multiple documents to a
    portfolio. Experts also suggest using public blogs or simple
    websites to encourage students to take it more seriously, and to
    potentially share it with prospective employers and colleagues.
    -   Example: Ask students to use Google\'s
        [Blogger](https://www.blogger.com/) platform to create media
        rich posts that tell their story and demonstrate their command
        of the key performance indicators. Students can submit the posts
        or the entire blog for your review, and because it\'s public,
        they will tend to avoid posting substandard work.

\<br/\>

-   Non-Traditional Paper or Project: creative assignments work best
    when they have some \"real-world\" relevance and offer students some
    choice in delivery format.
    -   Example: Allow students to select a problem drawn from today\'s
        current events. Their challenge is then to demonstrate their
        ability to apply course concepts to solve the problem.

\<br/\>

-   Group Project: group projects require students to demonstrate
    mastery of subject matter and develop their ability to communicate
    and work collaboratively. It is crucial to make your assessment
    criteria and grading scheme clear, and to ensure that there are
    clear, explicit expectations for each team member.
    -   Example: Present each group with a malfunctioning machine.
        Establish roles within the groups for students to select. E.g.,
        Researcher, Tinker, Record Keeper. Keep the groups as small as
        you can so students can\'t \"hide\". The groups\' goal is to
        repair the machine while documenting observations and trials.
        The groups present to the class what the problem was and what
        steps were taken to solve it. Each student in the group presents
        in equal measure based on their role.

### Tips for Open-Book Assessment in Quantitative Courses {#tips_for_open_book_assessment_in_quantitative_courses}

STEM and other quantitative courses face a particular challenge in
creating effective online exams, in part because it\'s so easy to cheat
and in part because so many questions are computational.

-   Ask more conceptual questions (e.g., \"what is the next step in this
    problem?\", \"state the definition of\...\", \"explain why this
    hypothesis in the theorem is necessary\").
-   Ask students to identify an error in a proof or computation (this is
    particularly effective since it can\'t be googled).
-   Eliminate multiple-choice and fill-in questions in favor of
    show-all-work questions where students have to scan and upload their
    work.
-   If using problems from a textbook, change not only the numbers but
    also the names (e.g., John to Alice) and the scenario (e.g., pulling
    a boat in to letting a kite string out). The reason for this is that
    popular textbooks will probably have many of their problems already
    solved online somewhere, for example, on Chegg.
-   Use letters and variables in place of specific numbers.
-   When randomizing the exam, don\'t just randomize numbers. Also
    randomize discrete parts of the problem. For instance, one version
    might have a problem like \"maximize the volume of the box given its
    surface area\" whereas another version might have \"minimize the
    surface area of a box given its volume\". (The numbers can even be
    the same for the two versions.)
-   Avoid questions that consist of only simple computations. For
    example, instead of \"calculate this integral\", present students
    with some application in which they also have to set up a proper
    integral. \"Write an integral expression that is equal to the
    probability that\...\" or \"write a triple integral which is equal
    to the mass of the region\" are good alternatives. There are online
    calculators that will not only solve many computational problems,
    but also give step by step solutions. Adding more words and
    applications to a problem makes it more difficult to cheat and also
    tests the real learning goal: do students know how to apply basic
    principles? (Ultimately, anyone can use a calculator, but only if
    you know what you want to calculate.)

### Resources for Writing Multiple Choice Exams {#resources_for_writing_multiple_choice_exams}

Multiple choice exams are often a necessity. These resources provide
information on writing effective multiple-choice exams:

-   [Vanderbilt University Guide to Writing Good Multiple Choice
    Questions](https://cft.vanderbilt.edu/guides-sub-pages/writing-good-multiple-choice-test-questions/)

```{=html}

```
-   [University of Waterloo Tips for Designing Multiple Choice
    Questions](https://uwaterloo.ca/centre-for-teaching-excellence/teaching-resources/teaching-tips/developing-assignments/assignment-design/designing-multiple-choice-questions)

steps you can take to make it more difficult when offering online
assessments through the Tests & Quizzes tool.

Please see the [ full
guide](Strategies_for_Reducing_Cheating_with_Online_Assessments "wikilink")
for reducing cheating.

## Hiding a File or Folder {#hiding_a_file_or_folder}

To hide a file or folder:

1.  Navigate to the **Resources** tool in your course site.
2.  Find the file or folder you\'d like to hide, and click on the
    **Actions** button and select **Edit Details**.
3.  In the window that opens, under \"Availability and Access\", select
    **Hide this item** or **Hide this folder and its contents**.
    Alternatively, you can specify available dates if you prefer to
    auto-hide and auto-show the file or folder.
4.  When you\'re finished, click **Update**.

## Showing a File or Folder {#showing_a_file_or_folder}

To make a file or folder available again:

1.  Navigate to the **Resources** tool in your course site.
2.  Find the file or folder you\'d like to make available, and click on
    the **Actions** button next to it, then select **Edit Details**.
3.  In the window that opens, under \"Availability and Access\", select
    **Show this item** or **Show this folder**. Alternatively, you can
    specify available dates if you prefer to auto-hide and auto-show the
    file or folder.
4.  When you\'re finished, click **Update**.

To hide certain syllabus sections from students:

1.  Navigate to the **Syllabus** tool in your course site.
2.  Locate the section you wish to hide from students.
3.  Click on the **eye** (unpublish) icon next to the section.
4.  The eye should switch to an eye with a slash through it, indicating
    the item is unpublished.

## Show Syllabus Sections {#show_syllabus_sections}

To make an unpublished section available to students:

1.  Navigate to the **Syllabus** tool in your course site.
2.  Locate the section you wish to show to students.
3.  Click on the **eye with a slash through it** (publish) icon next to
    the section.
4.  The eye with a slash through it should switch to an eye, indicating
    the item is published.

`     ``<text bytes="2788" sha1="1krsqf6n2dypbpchljn46ajjqut4rby" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`A Zoom meeting must have a host to run successfully. Only instructors may host meetings within the Isidore integration, but anyone at UD can host meetings outside of Isidore. See the `[`Add a Zoom Meeting`](Add_a_Zoom_Meeting "wikilink")` article for more information `

Below is Zoom\'s video overview of the host controls.

\<youtube\>4w_pRMBEALE\</youtube\>

The host controls will appear at the bottom of your screen if you are
not currently screen sharing. Please see [Zoom\'s additional help
documentation](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/201362603-Host-Controls-in-a-Meeting)
about each of these controls for more information.

-   **Mute/Unmute**: This allows you to mute and unmute your microphone.
    -   Audio Controls (via the \^ arrow next to mute/unmute): The audio
        controls allow you to change the microphone and speaker that
        Zoom is currently using on your computer, leave computer audio,
        and access the full audio options in the Zoom settings.
-   **Start/Stop Video**: This allows you to start and stop your own
    video.
    -   Video Controls (via the \^ arrow next to Start/Stop Video): If
        you have multiple cameras on your computer, you can select which
        Zoom is using, access the full video controls, and select a
        Virtual Background.
-   **Invite**: Invite others to join your meeting. [Read more about
    inviting
    participants](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/201362183-How-Do-I-Invite-Others-To-Join-a-Meeting-).
-   **Manage Participants**: This opens up the Participants window.
    [Read more about managing
    participants](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/115005759423).
-   **Share Screen**: Click on this to start a screen share. You will be
    able to select the desktop or application you want to share. [Learn
    more about screen
    sharing](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/201362153-How-Do-I-Share-My-Screen-).
    -   Screen Share Controls (via the \^ next to Share Screen): Select
        who can share in your meeting and if you want only the host or
        any participant to be able to start a new share when someone is
        sharing.
-   **Chat**: Access the chat window to chat with the participants. Read
    more about in-meeting chat.
-   **Record**: Start or stop a cloud or local recording. Read more
    about local recording. Read more about cloud recording.
-   **Closed Caption**: If you have enabled closed captioning for your
    account, click here to access the closed caption options. Read more
    about closed caption.
-   **Breakout Rooms**: Start breakout rooms. Read more about breakout
    rooms.
-   **More**: Clicking on More will give you access to additional
    options.
-   **End Meeting**: This will end the meeting for all participants. If
    you want to have the meeting continue, you should give another
    participant host control before leaving the meeting.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [Zoom](Zoom "wikilink") page

it may take 1 business day before you gain access to the site. For
specific questions about course assignments and deadlines, please
contact the instructor. \<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main

## Installing an External Tool in Lessons {#installing_an_external_tool_in_lessons}

To install an external tool in a Lessons tool:

1.  Navigate to the Lessons page or subpage where you would like to
    install the tool.
2.  Click on **Add Content** and then **Add External Tool**.
3.  Select the tool from the list.
4.  You may need to provide configuration parameters or settings.
5.  Click on **Save**.

## Embedding Images in Text Entries in Isidore {#embedding_images_in_text_entries_in_isidore}

\<youtube\>iNmxQmzFGFE\</youtube\>

### Approach 1: Uploading an Image from your Computer {#approach_1_uploading_an_image_from_your_computer}

1.  Begin your text entry wherever you want to embed the image. Make
    sure your cursor is located where you want the picture to appear.
2.  Click on the Image icon in the text editor.
    ![](Picture.png "Picture.png")
3.  Click on the **Upload** tab in the Image Properties pop-up.
4.  Click on the **Choose File** button to upload.
5.  Navigate to where the image is stored on your computer, select it,
    and click on **Open**.
6.  Click on the **Send it to the Server** button.
7.  Edit the image\'s size, alignment, and caption in the same popup.
8.  Press the **OK** button to add the image to your entry.
9.  Save or post the entry to see the image included in your text entry.

### Approach 2: Copying and Pasting {#approach_2_copying_and_pasting}

1.  Find a picture you would like to copy into your text entry.
    -   If you are finding the picture on the internet, right click the
        image and select **Copy Image** from the pop-up menu.
    -   If you are finding the picture on your computer, you must first
        open the picture on your computer\'s default picture viewing
        software (Photos on Windows systems) or within a picture editing
        program. Then right click on the image and select **Copy** from
        the pop-up menu.
2.  Begin your text entry wherever you want to embed the image. Make
    sure your cursor is located where you want the picture to appear.
3.  Press **ctrl + v** on your keyboard to paste in the image. Most
    browsers do NOT allow you to right click in the text editor to paste
    the image. You must use the keyboard.
4.  Save or post the entry to see the image included in your text entry.

### Approach 3: Dragging and Dropping {#approach_3_dragging_and_dropping}

1.  Find a picture you would like to drag and drop into your text entry.
    You can choose a picture from the internet or from your computer.
2.  Begin your text entry wherever you want to embed the image. Make
    sure your cursor is located where you want the picture to appear.
3.  Click on the picture and hold down the mouse key. While holding down
    the mouse key, drag the picture into the text editor and release the
    key.
4.  Save or post the entry to see the image included in your text entry.

### Approach 4: Using Web Addresses from the Internet {#approach_4_using_web_addresses_from_the_internet}

1.  Find a web address of an image you\'d like to embed into a text
    entry in Isidore.
2.  Copy the web address.
3.  Begin your text entry in Isidore. Make sure your cursor is located
    where you want the picture to appear.
4.  Then select the Image icon in the text editor.
    ![](Picture.png "Picture.png")
5.  In the **Image Properties** popup, paste the web address in the URL
    field.
6.  Edit the image\'s size, alignment, and caption in the same popup.
7.  Press the **OK** button to add the image to your entry.
8.  Save or post the entry to see the image included in your text entry.

## Editing Embedded Images {#editing_embedded_images}

Embedded images may have the following properties applied to them
through the rich-text editor: horizontal alignment, width and height
adjustments, alt text, and captions. Follow the instructions below to
edit an embedded image:

1.  Locate the image you wish to edit and open the text editor in which
    it is embedded.
2.  Double click on the image.
3.  The **Image Properties** pop-up will display.
4.  On the **Image Info** tab, you can edit the following properties:
    -   **Alternative Text**: Add a description of your image. Read more
        about [ alternative text](Images "wikilink").
    -   **Width and Height**: The image you upload will show the
        dimensions of the image in pixels in these fields. Either reduce
        or increase the pixels in either the width or height field to
        make the image smaller or larger as needed.
    -   **Alignment**: The image will have no alignment by default.
        Choose left, center, or right to position the image within the
        text entry.
    -   **Captioned image**: Selecting this option will give you the
        ability to enter a caption that is displayed underneath the
        picture. If you choose this option, you will enter the text of
        the caption in the text editor itself, not within the **Image
        Properties** pop-up.
5.  Press **OK** to see the changes to your picture.

## Adding Alt Text to an Image {#adding_alt_text_to_an_image}

How to add alt text to an image:

1.  Switch into edit mode in Isidore so that the html/WYSIWYG editor is
    available.
2.  Right-click on the image you want to add alt text to and select
    **Image Properties**.
3.  In the \"Alternative Text\" box, type in a brief description of what
    the image shows. Consider what the image is conveying. For example,
    if it\'s a right-facing arrow, considering adding \"Right-facing
    arrow indicating \"next\" or \"forward\" as the alternative text.
4.  Click on **OK**.
5.  Save your changes.

To import the Attendance records from an .xls (Excel) file:

1.  In your site\'s tool menu, click **Attendance**.
2.  Click on the **Import/Export** tab.
3.  In the **Import** section, click the **Browse** or **Choose File**
    button to open your file explorer.

5.  Select the file and click on **Open**.
6.  Click the **Import Attendance Sheet** button.
7.  You will be taken to a preview page that identifies the changes to
    your Attendance records.
    -   You will see a column, **Old Status**, that informs you of what
        the record currently is.
    -   The **New Status** column informs you what the record will be
        updated to after the import is completed.
    -   Ensure the changes look correct to you, then press **Cancel** to
        cancel the changes or **Complete Import** to complete the import
        process.
8.  If you select **Complete Import**, you will be returned to the main
    page of the Attendance tool. You will see a green confirmation
    message informing you that the import process has completed
    successfully.

## Importing content from another site {#importing_content_from_another_site}

To import material from another site:

1.  Navigate to the **Site Info** tool in your Isidore course site that
    you wish to import content into.
2.  Click on **Import Content**. \<br
    /\>![](import_content_tab.jpg "import_content_tab.jpg")\<br /\>
3.  On the \"Import Material from Other Sites\" screen, select a site(s)
    that you wish to import from. Scroll down and click on
    **Continue**.\<br /\>![](select_sites.jpg "select_sites.jpg")\<br
    /\>
4.  On the \"Re-use Material from Other Sites\" screen, select which
    tool(s) that you would like to import content from. You can bring in
    all items, or with Assignments or Tests & Quizzes, you can select
    specific assessments to copy in.
    -   *Please note that selecting some tools auto-selects the
        Resources tool. This prevents content from having broken links
        and images when being copied into a new site.*
    -   *Please note that you must have DRAFTS of your tests in the
        Tests & Quizzes tool in order to import anything in this tool.
        If no assessments are showing up to be imported, they must first
        be restored from the **Trash** tab within the Tests & Quizzes
        tool.*\<br
        /\>![](select_tools_and_assignments.jpg "select_tools_and_assignments.jpg")\<br
        /\>
5.  Scroll down and expand the \"Additional Options\" section near the
    bottom of the screen.
    -   By default, groups are selected to be copied along with the
        content. This ensures that features like group assignments or
        Lessons subpages released to groups are not broken.
    -   If you would like assignments to be copied over and immediately
        posted, check the box next to \"Assignments - Publish imported
        content\". Otherwise, they will come in as a draft and you\'ll
        need to modify the settings and post the assignments manually.
    -   The default setting for importing content is that content will
        be merged with existing content in the site. If you would like
        to clear out (replace) content before importing, select the box
        next to \"Clear existing content before importing\". *Leaving
        \"Clear existing content before importing\" unchecked is the
        safest option, as there is no \"undo\" for replacing content.*
6.  Click **Finish**.\<br
    /\>![](select_additional_options.jpg "select_additional_options.jpg")\<br
    /\>
7.  Some of the content you selected to be imported will show up in your
    new site immediately, but the entire process can take 10-15 minutes.
    You should receive an email notification once the process completes.

## Importing Homepage Builder Content to a Newly Created Site {#importing_homepage_builder_content_to_a_newly_created_site}

To import your Homepage Builder content from another site:

1.  Navigate to the **Overview** tool in a newly created Isidore site.
2.  Click on the **Get Started** button in the Homepage Builder widget.
3.  Click on the **Import from Previous Site** link in the upper
    right-hand corner of the Homepage Builder widget.
4.  Select the site that contains the existing Homepage Builder content
    you wish to import.
5.  Click on **Submit**.
6.  The imported items from the other site should now appear in the new
    site, and you can make edits as needed.

## Importing Homepage Builder Content into a Site with Existing Content {#importing_homepage_builder_content_into_a_site_with_existing_content}

If you\'ve already setup your Homepage Builder content and wish to
overwrite the content with another site\'s Homepage Builder content:

1.  Navigate to the Homepage Builder widget on the **Overview** tool in
    your Isidore site.
2.  Click on the **Edit** button in the upper right-hand corner of the
    widget.
3.  Click on the **Actions** button in the upper right-hand corner of
    the widget and select **Import from Previous Site**.
4.  Select the site that contains the Homepage Builder content and click
    on **Submit**.

`     ``<text bytes="4444" sha1="6hfi062s75ql91exlvqlg9v2ye0sqwe" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`To import your grades into Porches/Banner:`

1.  Navigate to the **Faculty Resources** tab in
    [Porches](https://porches.udayton.edu).\<br /\>\<br /\>![Faculty
    Resources Link in
    Porches](Faculty_Resources_Link.jpg "Faculty Resources Link in Porches")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
2.  Click on the **Faculty Grade Entry** link.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Faculty
    Grade Entry Link in
    Porches](Faculty_Grade_Entry_Link.jpg "Faculty Grade Entry Link in Porches")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
3.  You'll be directed to the Ellucian Banner screen.\<br /\>\<br /\>
4.  Click on the **Faculty Grade Entry** link.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Faculty
    Grade Entry Link in
    Banner](Banner_Faculty_Grade_Entry_Link.jpg "Faculty Grade Entry Link in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
5.  Make sure you're on the **Midterm Grades** tab if you're entering
    midterm grades or the **Final Grades** tab if you're entering final
    grades. The selected tab will be underlined.\<br /\>\<br
    /\>![Midterm or Final Grading tab in
    Banner](Selecting_Miterm_or_Final_Grades_Tab.jpg "Midterm or Final Grading tab in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
6.  Click on a class section that you want to enter midterm or final
    grades for.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Section Selection in
    Banner](Select_Section_to_Enter_Grades_For.jpg "Section Selection in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
7.  Click on the settings icon in the upper-right corner of the screen
    and select **Import**.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Settings icon and Import
    link in
    Banner](Settings_and_Import.jpg "Settings icon and Import link in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
8.  When the Import window appears, click on the text box that reads
    **Browse**. \<br /\>\<br /\>![Browse in
    Banner](browse.jpg "Browse in Banner")\<br /\>\<br /\>
9.  This will open your computer's file explorer where you can select
    the file you exported from Isidore. As previously mentioned, this
    file is usually automatically downloaded to your \"Downloads\"
    folder.\<br /\>\<br /\>
10. Once the file is selected, click on the **Upload** button. Once the
    system prepares the file, you can click on the **Continue**
    button.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Upload and Continue buttons in
    Banner](upload_and_continue.jpg "Upload and Continue buttons in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
11. A preview will load, where you can scroll right and left and up an
    down to see the data from your file. Once you\'ve verified the
    preview looks good, click on the **Continue** button.\<br /\>\<br
    /\>![Preview and Continue buttons in
    Banner](preview_and_continue.jpg "Preview and Continue buttons in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
12. The next step ensures that the data you\'re importing is going into
    the correct columns. Check to make sure that the following map
    selections and column headers are paired: Term Code, CRN, Student
    ID, and Midterm Grade or Final Grade (depending on what type of
    grading you\'re doing). It\'s fine for the other maps to have
    \"Other\" selected. Once the columns have been mapped, click on the
    **Continue** button.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Map and Continue buttons in
    Banner](map_and_continue.jpg "Map and Continue buttons in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
13. Any records that will be updated by the import are displayed as a
    preview on the screen. Once again, you can scroll right and left or
    down and up. If no data records display on the screen, no records
    will be updated. Verify that the changes look okay, and click on the
    **Continue** button.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Validate and Continue buttons
    in
    Banner](validate_and_continue.jpg "Validate and Continue buttons in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>If by chance the data is not what you\'re expecting to
    see, clicking on the \"Download the validation report\" link can be
    helpful. A spreadsheet will be downloaded to your computer, which
    contains details about importing errors.\<br /\>\<br /\>
14. Click on the **Finish** button.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Finish buttons in
    Banner](finish.jpg "Finish buttons in Banner")\<br /\>\<br /\>
15. The page will refresh, where you\'re looking at the list of your
    course sections. The section you just imported grades for should now
    have a grading status of \"In Progress\" if you imported grades for
    some students or \"Completed\" if you imported grades for all
    students. *Please keep in mind that grading for each section is not
    complete until the \"Grading Status\" column shows \"Completed\".*
    You may need to click on a section and manually select midterm or
    final grades for certain students if their grades weren\'t imported
    during the process.\<br /\>\<br /\>Until the grades are rolled
    overnight, you may still change the grades for students. **It is
    recommended that you make any grade changes for a student prior to
    midnight on the day you enter the grades.** Once the grades have
    been rolled, you will need to follow the [grade change
    instructions](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1VAeLLnLPZoGtfF4NViHgPTe6CHDmdBH0OXhKVwny4Yc/edit)
    to change students' grades once End of Term Processing is
    complete.`</text>`{=html}

## Step 1: Exporting Grades from Isidore {#step_1_exporting_grades_from_isidore}

The first step in the process is to export a properly formatted grades
file from your Isidore Gradebook.

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in one of your
    [Isidore](https://isidore.udayton.edu/portal) course sites.\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
2.  Click on the **Import / Export** tab.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Isidore\'s
    Import/Export
    tab](import_export_tab.jpg "Isidore's Import/Export tab")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
3.  Click on the **Export Midterm Grades** button for midterm grading or
    **Export Final Grades** for final grading.\<br /\>\<br
    /\>![Isidore\'s export midterm and final grades
    buttons](export_midterm_final_grades.jpg "Isidore's export midterm and final grades buttons")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
4.  An .xls file will be automatically saved to your computer, usually
    in the "Downloads" folder. You do not need to edit the file, as
    it\'s already prepared to be imported into Banner.

\<br /\>\<br /\> *If you have multiple course sections combined into one
Isidore site, the midterm and final grades import will work. A single
exported file will be downloaded, that contains grades for students from
all of your sections. In Banner, you\'ll need to select the first class
section and follow the import process using the exported file. Then,
you\'ll need to select the subsequent sections and follow the import
process, using the same exported file.* \<br /\>\<br /\>

## Step 2: Importing Grades to Porches/Banner {#step_2_importing_grades_to_porchesbanner}

The second step in the process is to import the grades file into Banner.

1.  Navigate to the **Faculty Resources** tab in
    [Porches](https://porches.udayton.edu).\<br /\>\<br /\>![Faculty
    Resources Link in
    Porches](Faculty_Resources_Link.jpg "Faculty Resources Link in Porches")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
2.  Click on the **Faculty Grade Entry** link.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Faculty
    Grade Entry Link in
    Porches](Faculty_Grade_Entry_Link.jpg "Faculty Grade Entry Link in Porches")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
3.  You'll be directed to the Ellucian Banner screen.\<br /\>\<br /\>
4.  Click on the **Faculty Grade Entry** link.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Faculty
    Grade Entry Link in
    Banner](Banner_Faculty_Grade_Entry_Link.jpg "Faculty Grade Entry Link in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
5.  Make sure you're on the **Midterm Grades** tab if you're entering
    midterm grades or the **Final Grades** tab if you're entering final
    grades. The selected tab will be underlined.\<br /\>\<br
    /\>![Midterm or Final Grading tab in
    Banner](Selecting_Miterm_or_Final_Grades_Tab.jpg "Midterm or Final Grading tab in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
6.  Click on a class section that you want to enter midterm or final
    grades for.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Section Selection in
    Banner](Select_Section_to_Enter_Grades_For.jpg "Section Selection in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
7.  Click on the settings icon in the upper-right corner of the screen
    and select **Import**.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Settings icon and Import
    link in
    Banner](Settings_and_Import.jpg "Settings icon and Import link in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
8.  When the Import window appears, click on the text box that reads
    **Browse**. \<br /\>\<br /\>![Browse in
    Banner](browse.jpg "Browse in Banner")\<br /\>\<br /\>
9.  This will open your computer's file explorer where you can select
    the file you exported from Isidore. As previously mentioned, this
    file is usually automatically downloaded to your \"Downloads\"
    folder.\<br /\>\<br /\>
10. Once the file is selected, click on the **Upload** button. Once the
    system prepares the file, you can click on the **Continue**
    button.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Upload and Continue buttons in
    Banner](upload_and_continue.jpg "Upload and Continue buttons in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
11. A preview will load, where you can scroll right and left and up an
    down to see the data from your file. Once you\'ve verified the
    preview looks good, click on the **Continue** button.\<br /\>\<br
    /\>![Preview and Continue buttons in
    Banner](preview_and_continue.jpg "Preview and Continue buttons in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
12. The next step ensures that the data you\'re importing is going into
    the correct columns. Check to make sure that the following map
    selections and column headers are paired: Term Code, CRN, Student
    ID, and Midterm Grade or Final Grade (depending on what type of
    grading you\'re doing). It\'s fine for the other maps to have
    \"Other\" selected. Once the columns have been mapped, click on the
    **Continue** button.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Map and Continue buttons in
    Banner](map_and_continue.jpg "Map and Continue buttons in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>
13. Any records that will be updated by the import are displayed as a
    preview on the screen. Once again, you can scroll right and left or
    down and up. If no data records display on the screen, no records
    will be updated. Verify that the changes look okay, and click on the
    **Continue** button.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Validate and Continue buttons
    in
    Banner](validate_and_continue.jpg "Validate and Continue buttons in Banner")\<br
    /\>\<br /\>If by chance the data is not what you\'re expecting to
    see, clicking on the \"Download the validation report\" link can be
    helpful. A spreadsheet will be downloaded to your computer, which
    contains details about importing errors.\<br /\>\<br /\>
14. Click on the **Finish** button.\<br /\>\<br /\>![Finish buttons in
    Banner](finish.jpg "Finish buttons in Banner")\<br /\>\<br /\>
15. The page will refresh, where you\'re looking at the list of your
    course sections. The section you just imported grades for should now
    have a grading status of \"In Progress\" if you imported grades for
    some students or \"Completed\" if you imported grades for all
    students. *Please keep in mind that grading for each section is not
    complete until the \"Grading Status\" column shows \"Completed\".*
    You may need to click on a section and manually select midterm or
    final grades for certain students if their grades weren\'t imported
    during the process.\<br /\>\<br /\>Until the grades are rolled
    overnight, you may still change the grades for students. **It is
    recommended that you make any grade changes for a student prior to
    midnight on the day you enter the grades.** Once the grades have
    been rolled, you will need to follow the [grade change
    instructions](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1VAeLLnLPZoGtfF4NViHgPTe6CHDmdBH0OXhKVwny4Yc/edit)
    to change students' grades once End of Term Processing is complete.

\<br /\>\<br /\>

## FAQs

**How does export/import work if I have multiple course sections
combined in an Isidore site?**\<br /\>If you have multiple course
sections combined into one Isidore site, the midterm and final grades
import will work. A single exported file will be downloaded, that
contains grades for students from all of your sections. In Banner,
you\'ll need to select the first class section and follow the import
process using the exported file. Then, you\'ll need to select the
subsequent sections and follow the import process, using the same
exported file.

**How do I enter an \"Incomplete\" for a student?**\<br /\>To enter an
\"incomplete\" for a student, you can change a student\'s letter grade
to an \"I\" in the \"Final Grade\" column of the midterm or final grades
export from Isidore before you import into Banner. Alternatively, you
can go through the Banner import process, then manually change the
letter grade by selecting an \"I\" in the \"Final Grade\" column next to
a student\'s name.

**What happens during the Banner import with students/participants who
aren\'t officially registered for one of my course sections?**\<br
/\>The midterm grades export and the final grades export are only needed
for students/participants who are officially registered for one of your
course sections. If there are participants added to your Isidore course
site who are not officially registered for your course, or are added
with a local Isidore guest account, those individuals won\'t be included
in the export downloaded from Isidore.

**What if I need to change a grade that\'s been entered in
Porches/Banner?**\<br /\>Until the grades are rolled overnight, you may
still change the grades for students. It is recommended that you make
any grade changes for a student prior to midnight on the day you enter
the grades. Once the grades have been rolled, you will need to follow
the [grade change
instructions](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1VAeLLnLPZoGtfF4NViHgPTe6CHDmdBH0OXhKVwny4Yc/edit)
to change students' grades once End of Term Processing is complete. \<br
/\>\<br /\>

`     ``<text bytes="3114" sha1="poovx26lzb6sffncli8urbaef1zyhde" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`There are several ways to insert an image into a forum post. Images may either be embedded into the post itself or added as an attachment to the post. If it's embedded into the post, this means that the image will appear on the page without people needing to click on a link. `

The method shown in the image below demonstrates how to embed a photo in
a post. It shows how to embed a photo located on the internet as well as
a photo located on your device.

### Approach 1: Embed an Image Using Web Addresses from the Internet {#approach_1_embed_an_image_using_web_addresses_from_the_internet}

1.  Find a web address of an image you\'d like to embed into a text
    entry in Isidore.
2.  Copy the web address.
3.  Begin your text entry in Isidore, then select the Image icon in the
    text editor. ![picture](Picture.png "picture")
4.  In the **Image Properties** popup, paste the web address in the URL
    field.
5.  Edit the image\'s size, alignment, and caption in the same popup.
6.  Press the **OK** button to add the image to your entry.
7.  Save or post the entry to see the image included in your text entry.

### Approach 2: Embed an Image by Uploading an Image from your Computer {#approach_2_embed_an_image_by_uploading_an_image_from_your_computer}

Images uploaded from your computer must first be stored in a location
that is publicly accessible in Isidore so that others may view the
image.

1.  On your Isidore homepage, click on the **My Resources** tool in the
    tool menu.
2.  Click on the **Actions** button adjacent to the \"Home\" link.
3.  From the dropdown menu, click on the **Upload Files** option.
4.  Click in the gray area to pull up your computer\'s file explorer and
    find the image you\'d like to upload.
5.  Press the **Continue** button.
6.  When you are redirected to your Resources folder, locate the image
    you uploaded and select the **Actions** button in-line with it.
7.  Click on the **Edit Details** option from the dropdown menu.
8.  In the **Additional Access** section, click the checkbox next to the
    \"This file is publicly viewable\" option.
9.  Press **Update** to save that change.
10. Then begin your text entry wherever you want to embed the image.
11. Click on the Image icon in the text editor.
    ![picture](Picture.png "picture")
12. In the **Image Properties** popup, click on the **Browse Server**
    button. This will bring up Isidore\'s file browser.
13. Click on the **Home** site from the list of sites in the menu.
14. Double click on the Resources folder.
15. Find the image you want to embed, then select it and press **OK**.
16. Edit the image\'s size, alignment, and caption in the same popup.
17. Press the **OK** button to add the image to your entry.
18. Save or post the entry to see the image included in your text entry.

### Approach 3: Attaching an Image from your Computer {#approach_3_attaching_an_image_from_your_computer}

1.  Click on the **Add attachments** button under the post you are
    adding to the forums tool.
2.  On the **Add Attachment** popup, click on the **Choose File**
    button.
3.  Locate the image you\'d like to attach to your post in the file
    explorer window and click Open.
4.  Press **Continue**.
5.  You will see the name of the file under the **Attachments** heading
    for your post.
6.  Click **Post** to post to the Forum.

    site.

        doing so.

    only appear as a thumbnail.
11. Click the **Post** button.

`     ``<text bytes="1589" sha1="qi9c0edq9rpwd9l0inyub0xccp0255t" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Students can upload videos into the Warpwire tool `**`only`**` when instructors have enabled their permission to do so. `

To insert a Warpwire video into an assignment submission:

1.  Navigate to your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on the **Warpwire Video** tool from the tool menu.
3.  Click on the **+** button from the top right corner. **Note:** If
    you do not see a **+** button, your instructor has not enabled your
    permission to add videos. Please ask your instructor for further
    instructions.
4.  Select **Upload files** from the drop down menu.
5.  Navigate to where the video file is stored on your device, select
    it, and click on the **Open** or **Choose** button.
6.  If you wish, you can change the title of the video and add a
    description. Click on the **Start Uploading** button.
7.  At the bottom of the page, you\'ll see a green progress bar while
    the video is uploading. **Note:** Do NOT navigate away from this
    page while your video is uploading.
8.  Once your video has finished uploading, you will see a thumbnail of
    it appear in the library. It may say \"Queued\" next to it. It is
    now safe to navigate away from the page.
9.  Click on the circle with 3 dots in the frame of your video.
10. Click on **Share**.
11. Click on the **Copy** link next to the web address bar.
12. Navigate to the **Assignments** tool.
13. Click on the assignment where you\'d like to add the link to the
    video.
14. In the text box for the assignment, paste in the link.
15. Make any other adjustments to your assignment and press submit.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Warpwire

`     ``<text bytes="1238" sha1="2ya906b30rvs5le26pf0zqtmh76ci7a" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`To embed (or insert) a video into an assignment, forum post, or announcement:`

1.  Navigate to your Isidore course site.
2.  Navigate to the tool where you\'d like to insert a video (e.g.
    Forums, Assignments, etc.)
3.  Get to the spot where you\'re wanting to insert your video. *For
    example, in the Forums tool, you may want to click on a topic and
    then select **Start a New Conversation**.*
4.  When the rich-text editor loads, look for an icon that is a black
    circle with a white \"W\". It will say **Insert Warpwire** when you
    hover your cursor over it. Click on the **Warpwire** icon.
5.  You can either select an existing video from your library, by
    clicking on the empty circle to the right of the video, or you can
    follow the instructions to [Upload a video from my
    computer](Upload_a_video_from_my_computer "wikilink"). Once the
    video has been selected, the circle will be filled in with solid
    green coloring.
6.  Once the video is selected, click on the \"Insert 1 item\" button
    near the bottom of the screen.
7.  You\'ll see a thumbnail version of the video has been inserted into
    the text editor.
8.  When you\'re finished writing your discussion post, assignment, or
    announcement, go ahead and post or submit it.

`     ``<text bytes="3346" sha1="6u6h43nnty0tyu4thbyw29krjs9sw0z" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Before Zoom can be used, a client/app must first be installed on your computer or mobile device. `

Please see our [Zoom Installation Guide for step-by-step instructions
with
images](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Ph4s5xvKk3lOwSeEkGf4iutCK8IRCyJYL1tSyFaAFR8/edit?usp=sharing).

### Web Client Installation {#web_client_installation}

You will be prompted to install the web client for Zoom when you join a
Zoom meeting for the first time. This is how most people will access
zoom. This client will need to be installed for each browser (in other
words, if you install the client for Chrome, but then the next day use
Firefox, you will need to install the client again). Please note that
installing the web client will ALSO install the desktop client.

1.  When you join a meeting, you will see a screen that says, "A
    download should start automatically in a few seconds."
2.  You may need to agree to "Run" the installation file as shown in the
    picture above.
3.  Verify that the file is coming from "Zoom Video Communications,
    Inc." then click "Run" again:
4.  Zoom will launch in a new application.

### Desktop Client - Windows {#desktop_client___windows}

If you would like to install the desktop client for Zoom on a Windows
machine, follow the steps below. This client allows you start new
meetings, join existing meetings, schedule meetings, chat with contacts,
and more.

1.  Open a browser and navigate to the following web address:
    [<https://udayton.zoom.us/download>](https://udayton.zoom.us/download)
2.  Click on the **Download** button for Zoom Client for Meetings.
3.  Save the installation file, \"ZoomInstaller.exe\", to a place on
    your computer where you can find it.
4.  Locate the installation file and double click it to start.
5.  Verify that the file is coming from \"Zoom Video Communications,
    Inc.\" then click \"Run\" again.
6.  Once the file has finished installing, it will launch the desktop
    client from which you can launch and join meetings.

### Desktop Client - Mac {#desktop_client___mac}

If you would like to install the desktop client for Zoom on a Mac
machine, follow the steps below.

1.  Open a browser and navigate to the following web address:
    [<https://udayton.zoom.us/download>](https://udayton.zoom.us/download)
2.  Click on the **Download** button for Zoom Client for Meetings.
3.  The Zoom installation file will download to your Downloads folder.
    Click on the downloads icon in the top right corner of Safari to see
    it.
4.  Double click on the file name (\"Zoom.pkg\").
5.  Press \"Continue\" when prompted.
6.  Zoom will launch.

### Mobile - Android {#mobile___android}

Zoom can be used on mobile devices using an app. Before joining a Zoom
meeting, you will be prompted to install the Zoom app from the Google
play store.

1.  Open the Google Play Store or attempt to join a Zoom meeting, where
    you will be prompted to download the Zoom app from the store.
2.  Once the app is installed, open the app or return to the original
    link to the Zoom meeting to join it.

### Mobile - iOS {#mobile___ios}

Zoom can be used on mobile devices using an app. Before joining a Zoom
meeting, you will be prompted to install the Zoom app from the Apple
store.

1.  Open the Apple Store or attempt to join a Zoom meeting, where you
    will be prompted to download the Zoom app from the store.
2.  Once the app is installed, open the app or return to the original
    link to the Zoom meeting to join it.

## About Isidore {#about_isidore}

Isidore is UD\'s open-source Learning Management System or LMS that runs
on the Sakai platform. Isidore is named after St. Isidore of Seville,
the patron saint of students and recommended for patronage of computers
and the Internet. The University of Dayton has been using Isidore since
the Fall semester in 2008.

If you are new to Isidore, we suggest clicking the button below to get a
better understanding of this system. \<br /\>\<br /\>

Isidore\"\|link=New_To_Isidore](NewtoIsi.png "fameless|200px|left|Button that reads "New to Isidore"|link=New_To_Isidore")
\<br /\>\<br /\>\<br /\>

To join a site:

## Unjoining a Site {#unjoining_a_site}

To unjoin a site:

1.  From [Home (Isidore Home)](Home_(Isidore_Home) "wikilink"), click on
    **Membership** in the menu bar on your left.
2.  Under \"My Current Sites\", you\'ll see a list of all the sites to
    which you belong. (This includes sites you have joined, and sites
    that you have been added to as a participant by the creator of the
    site.)
3.  If you\'d like to unjoin any of them, click the check box next to
    the site and click on **Unjoin Selected**.

### Joining a meeting within Isidore {#joining_a_meeting_within_isidore}

1.  Navigate to the Isidore site where the meeting has been set up.
2.  If you are a student, click on the **Join** button.
3.  If you are an instructor, click on the **Start** button.
4.  If this is the first time opening Zoom, follow the steps for
    [installing the Zoom client](Install_Zoom_Client "wikilink").
5.  If you see a pop-up asking to \"Open Zoom Meetings\", check the box
    for \"Always open these types of links in the associated app\", then
    click the **Open Zoom Meetings** button.
6.  The Zoom room or waiting room will launch.
    -   The Zoom waiting room says, \"Please wait for the host to start
        this meeting\" and includes the meeting start time. While
        waiting, press the **Test Computer Audio** button to make sure
        your mic and speakers are working properly. When the host starts
        the meeting, you will join the room automatically from this
        screen.

### Joining a meeting outside of Isidore {#joining_a_meeting_outside_of_isidore}

1.  Open a browser
2.  Type in the following web address: go.udayton.edu/zoom
3.  You can join a meeting in-progress or host your own meeting.
    -   To join a meeting in-progress:
        -   Click on the click on the **Join** button.
        -   Type in the meeting ID (a 9, 10, or 11-digit number), and
            click **Join** again.
    -   To host your own meeting:
        -   Click on the **Host** button. **Note:** Only people with
            official UD accounts can host meetings.
        -   You maybe asked to enter your UD credentials.
4.  If this is the first time opening Zoom, follow the steps for
    [installing the Zoom client](Install_Zoom_Client "wikilink").
5.  If you see a pop-up asking to \"Open Zoom Meetings\", check the box
    for \"Always open these types of links in the associated app\", then
    click the **Open Zoom Meetings** button.
    -   The Zoom room or Zoom waiting room will launch.
    -   The Zoom waiting room says, \"Please wait for the host to start
        this meeting\" and includes the meeting start time. While
        waiting, press the **Test Computer Audio** button to make sure
        your mic and speakers are working properly. When the host starts
        the meeting, you will join the room automatically from this
        screen.

### Joining a meeting from an email invitation {#joining_a_meeting_from_an_email_invitation}

You may be invited via email to join a meeting in progress or a
scheduled meeting.

1.  To join a meeting in-progress or a scheduled meeting, click on the
    link sent in the email to meeting room.
2.  If this is the first time opening Zoom, follow the steps for
    [installing the Zoom client](Install_Zoom_Client "wikilink").
3.  If you see a pop-up asking to \"Open Zoom Meetings\", check the box
    for \"Always open these types of links in the associated app\", then
    click the **Open Zoom Meetings** button.
4.  You may be asked to enter your name. Enter your name and press
    **Join**.
    -   The Zoom room or Zoom waiting room will launch.
    -   The Zoom waiting room says, \"Please wait for the host to start
        this meeting\" and includes the meeting start time. While
        waiting, press the **Test Computer Audio** button to make sure
        your mic and speakers are working properly. When the host starts
        the meeting, you will join the room automatically from this
        screen.

Please see Zoom\'s help page for [joining a
meeting](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/201362193-Joining-a-Meeting)
for additional assistance. \<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main
[Zoom](Zoom "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}
