`     ``<text bytes="1134" sha1="sp463ck0tsyqwftplp0y81bh14623h9" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`You must publish an assessment draft to make it available to students.  Students won't see it until the open date & time you specify.  When you publish an assessment, a new copy of the assessment will appear. `

**It\'s important to note that you should not remove draft versions of
assessments, as these are what are copied forward when you duplicate a
site or import from site.**

Please keep in mind that there\'s no link between the draft copy and the
published copy. If you make changes to one, you\'ll need to make changes
to the other.

To publish an assessment:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Next to the draft version of the assessment, click on the **Action**
    menu and select **Settings**.
3.  Walk through the settings tabs from left to right. For more help on
    this step, see [See Available
    Settings](See_Available_Settings "wikilink").
4.  The final tab is named **Publish**. You\'ll want to click on the
    **Save Settings and Publish** button and then click **Publish**
    again to confirm that you\'re publishing the assessment.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Tests and
Quizzes](Tests_and_Quizzes "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

## Reading Chat Room messages {#reading_chat_room_messages}

To read messages in the Chat Room:

1.  Navigate to the **Chat Room** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  You will be in the default chat room. To change rooms, click
    **Change Room** at the top, and select the room you\'d like to
    enter. *Note: The \"Change Room\" button will only be available if
    the instructor has created additional chat rooms.*
3.  To see who is presently in the room, look under \"Users in Chat\" on
    the right side of the screen.
4.  Messages appear in chronological order, with the most recent at the
    bottom. Messages will always identify the sender.

## Posting Chat Room messages {#posting_chat_room_messages}

To post a message:

1.  Navigate to the **Chat Room** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  In the text box at the bottom of the window, type your message, and
    then click **Add message**.\<br /\>*Note: No one can see your
    message until you click **Add message**, but once you do, only an
    instructor or a participant with special permission can delete your
    message.*
3.  To discard a message that you haven\'t sent yet, click **Clear**.

## Deleting Chat Room messages {#deleting_chat_room_messages}

To delete a Chat Room message that you have sufficient permission to
delete:

1.  Navigate to the **Chat Room** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click the trash can icon next to the chat message, and then click
    **Delete**.

**Note**: If you don\'t see a trash can icon, you don\'t have permission
to delete the message.

To permanently delete all messages from a chat room, click **Options**,
and then click **Clear History**. Click **Delete** to confirm. \<br
/\>\<br /\> Return to main [Chat Room](Chat_Room "wikilink") page

`     ``<text bytes="1428" sha1="2twgzuk7xgmmz3ekw5bxo9vkfi5yi7k" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Although test and quiz problems are few and far between, they occasionally do happen. Here are some general recommendations for taking online tests and quizzes in Isidore. If you experience any problem when taking an online test or quiz, please notify your instructor immediately.`

-   Make sure that you're connected to a stable wireless or hard-wired
    connection. A hard-wired network connection will be more stable than
    a wireless network connection.
-   Do not open Isidore in more than one browser tab or browser window.
    This may result in loss of answers.
-   Do not leave the test or quiz once you've started.
-   Do not view the feedback of another assessment while you\'re taking
    a test. This may result in total loss of your answers.
-   Utilize the **Save** button at the bottom of your test or quiz.
-   Do not use your browser's forward or back buttons to navigate
    through the assessment. Use the **Next** and **Previous** buttons
    within Isidore to navigate through your assessment.
-   If you're taking a timed assessment, make sure that you check
    Isidore's server clock at the bottom of the page to make sure your
    computer's time isn't different. Your test will be submitted when
    the due date and time hits according to Isidore's clock.
-   Make sure to click on the **Submit** button when you\'re done taking
    your assessment.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Tests and
Quizzes](Tests_and_Quizzes "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="1398" sha1="rg912vpyhi9wvuq75w44eyh4uwgm2fr" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Attendance may be recorded in an Excel spreadsheet, then imported into the Attendance tool. To do so, first follow the instructions for `[`exporting Attendance records`](Export_Attendance_Records "wikilink")`, then refer to the directions below to record Attendance. Please note that new items cannot be created in the spreadsheet and imported into the Attendance tool.`

To record Attendance in Excel:

1.  Open the exported Attendance spreadsheet.
2.  You will see a list of the students in your class as well as a
    column for each of your existing Attendance items. Each of your
    Attendance items will have a date and timestamp in its title.
    -   **Note:** If you selected the option to include columns for
        Attendance comments, you will see an additional column to the
        right of each Attendance item column where you may record
        comments for students\' attendance records.
3.  You may use the following words or initials to enter into cells to
    record students\' attendance:
    -   A - Absent
    -   P - Present
    -   L - Late
    -   LE - Left Early
    -   E - Excused
    -   **Note:** You may use either the initial or the full word. You
        may use capital or lower case letters.
4.  When you are finished recording attendance, follow the instructions
    for [importing attendance
    records](Import_Attendance_Records "wikilink") to bring these
    changes into the Attendance tool in Isidore.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [Attendance](Attendance "wikilink") page

`     ``<text bytes="1427" sha1="0j4hx1miqug2s9ra3otezpko09dbk76" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`To capture a video with your mobile device or phone:`

On both Apple and Android Devices:

1.  Open a web browser and navigate to
    [isidore.udayton.edu](https://isidore.udayton.edu).
2.  Go into your Isidore course site.
3.  Click on the **Warpwire Video** tool in the course tool menu.
4.  Click on the **+** button.
5.  Select **Capture from camera** from the drop down menu.

\<blockquote\> On an Android Device:

1.  You may need to click on **Allow** to give Adobe Flash access to
    your device.
2.  Make sure that the correct camera and microphone are selected.
3.  Click on the video camera (Record) button to start the recording.
4.  Click on the red square (Stop) button to stop the recording.

On an Apple Device:

1.  Click on the **Take Photo or Video** button.
2.  Select **Video**.
3.  Click on the red circle to start the recording.
4.  Click on the red square to stop the recording.
5.  Select **Use Video** to upload the recording.

\</blockquote\> On both Apple and Android Devices:

1.  If you wish, you can change the title of the recording. Click on the
    **Save Recording** button.
2.  You\'ll see a green progress bar at the bottom of your screen while
    the video is uploading.
3.  Your video will be queued while it is uploading. It will appear in
    grey while it is in the queue.
4.  Once it\'s finished uploading, your video will appear in course\'s
    media library.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Warpwire
Video](Warpwire_Video "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="1630" sha1="sn6h3jtwtp80k3aukyhixgopyigxdqv" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`These instructions will walk you through recording the  proper pronunciation of your name through `[`NameCoach`](What_is_NameCoach? "wikilink")`.`

1.  Click on the link in the upper right-hand corner of Isidore that
    displays your first name. Alternately, click on the **ISIDORE** link
    in the upper left-hand corner of Isidore.
2.  Click on **Profile**.
3.  Click on the **Create Name Pronunciation** button.
4.  *(Optional)* Enter you full name as you would like it
    said/announced.
5.  *(Optional)* Enter a phonetic spelling of your name.
6.  *(Optional)* Enter pronouns you would like to be used.
7.  *(Optional)* Select an honorific you would like to be used.
8.  Select whether you would like to record your name through a phone or
    a microphone installed on your computer.
    -   If phone is selected, please enter a phone number that can be
        used to reach you. Click on the **Submit and Call me** button.
        Your phone will ring and you\'ll be able to record your name
        pronunciation at the prompt.
    -   If web recorder is selected, please click on the **Record**
        button. Once you\'ve recorded your name pronunciation, click on
        **Submit and Finish**.
9.  You may need to refresh the Profile tool several times before you
    can view and play your name pronunciation recording.

Please note that once your name pronunciation is recorded, the **Create
Name Pronunciation** button will disappear and a new purple **play name
pronunciation** button will be displayed next to your name in the
**Profile** tool. \<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main
[Roster](Roster "wikilink") page\<br /\> Return to the main
[Profile](Profile "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="1278" sha1="3jwq985flrc22wawk5ki2p6o32bre5i" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`==Creating Discussion Groups==`

Before following the instructions below, please make sure that you\'ve
created groups in Site Info \> Manage Groups. For step by step
instructions, please see [Manage groups](Manage_groups "wikilink"). Once
you\'ve setup forum and topic permissions, you should not rename the
groups, as this will break the permissions you\'ve established.

## Setting Forum Permissions for Groups {#setting_forum_permissions_for_groups}

To release forums and/or topics to specific groups:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click **New Forum** or **New Topic** to create new a new forum or
    topic, or click **Forum Settings** or **Topic Settings** to modify
    an existing forum or topic.
3.  On the Forum Settings or Topic Settings page, expand the
    \"Permissions\" section.
4.  Next to the \"Student\" role, select **None** from the \"Permission
    Level\" drop-down menu.
5.  Next to the \"Team\" role, select **Contributor** from the
    \"Permission Level\" drop-down menu. *Example: If this will be Team
    One\'s forum, then Team One should have contributor permissions,
    while the other teams should have none.*
6.  At the bottom of the page, click **Save**.

Repeat these steps to setup other forums and topics for each group. \<br
/\>\<br /\>Return to main [Forums](Forums "wikilink") page
`</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="1448" sha1="bzv3qoh6fvxewk6gt3wef28x0l80825" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`The directions below show instructors how to release an assessment to one group of section of students.`

To release an assessment to only one group or section:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Select **Settings** from the **Action** drop-down menu next to the
    assessment. *If the assessment has already been published, you
    won\'t be able to change this setting.*
3.  Click on the **Availability & Submissions** tab.
4.  Under the **Who is this assessment released to?** section you can
    pick the group or section of students you would like the assessment
    released to, from the drop-down menu.
5.  Continue adjusting the settings on the \"Availability &
    Submissions\" tabs and the other tabs.
6.  When you're done configuring the rest of the settings, you'll want
    to click on the **Publish** tab and click on the **Save Settings and
    Publish** button to release the assessment to students.
7.  Click the **Publish** button on the next screen to confirm once
    you've reviewed the information on the page.
8.  You will now see two copies of the assessment you just published -
    one is in draft mode and one is published.

To release the assessment to specific groups at different times, please
see instructions for [setting up time limit and delivery date
exceptions](Setup_Extended_Time_Assessments "wikilink"). \<br /\>\<br
/\> Return to the main [Tests and Quizzes](Tests_and_Quizzes "wikilink")
page `</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="959" sha1="kk9ekt09dghfy6fm5hsmlvu3p91s8rk" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`== Removing questions from a question pool ==`

To remove a question from a question pool:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Click **Question Pools**.
3.  On the Question Pools screen, select the pool that you wish to
    enter.
4.  On the next screen, you will see all the questions in the desired
    pool. Subpools will also be listed below. If you wish to edit any
    questions within a subpool, you must enter the subpool from this
    screen.
5.  Find the question you wish to remove, and check the box in the
    \"Remove\" column next to the question.
6.  You\'ll need to click **Remove** to verify its deletion.

**Note: If this question pool has already been added to an assessment,
you will need to edit the assessment and click on the \"Update
Questions\" button.** \<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Question
Pools](Question_Pools "wikilink") page\<br /\> Return to the main [Tests
and Quizzes](Tests_and_Quizzes "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

## Removing a Lessons tool {#removing_a_lessons_tool}

To remove a Lessons tool

1.  Navigate to the **Site Info** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **Manage Tools**.
3.  Click on **settings icon** (gear/cog) and click on **Delete this
    Tool**.
4.  Click on the **Save** button.

Note that the page is not actually removed from the database. It may be
attached as a subpage to another page, effectively moving it to a
different location.

## Restoring a Deleted Lessons Subpage {#restoring_a_deleted_lessons_subpage}

To restore a deleted Lessons page:

1.  Navigate to a Lessons page in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **Add Content** and select **Add Subpage**.
3.  Enter a page title.
4.  Select **Choose Existing Page**.
5.  Click on the radio button next to a page under \"The following pages
    are currently not in use.\" and click **Use selected item**.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Lessons](Lessons "wikilink") page

By default, new content items are added to the bottom of a Lessons page.
You can use the Reorder tool to arrange the content in any order.

## Reorder Items {#reorder_items}

To reorder items:

1.  Navigate to a Lessons page.
2.  Click the **Reorder** button at the top of the page.
3.  Drag and drop content items into your preferred order.
4.  Click **Save** to complete the process.

Note that it is also possible to use the keyboard to move items. Select
the number to the left of the item, and use the control key, plus
up-arrow or down-arrow. With certain browsers it may be necessary to key
the arrows twice.

## Remove Items from a Page {#remove_items_from_a_page}

To remove items from the page:

1.  Navigate to a Lessons page.
2.  Click the **Reorder** button at the top of the page.
3.  Click on the **trash can** icon to the right of an item to remove
    it.
4.  Click **Save** to complete the process.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Lessons](Lessons "wikilink") page

## Adding a Reply {#adding_a_reply}

To reply to a thread:

1.  Navigate to a threaded discussion in the Lessons tool of your
    Isidore course site.
2.  Click on the title of a thread.
3.  Type the text of your reply into the text box.
4.  Click on **Reply**.

## Editing a Reply {#editing_a_reply}

To edit a reply:

1.  Navigate to a threaded discussion in the Lessons tool of your
    Isidore course site.
2.  Click on the title of a thread.
3.  Locate the reply you\'re wanting to edit and click on the **pencil**
    (edit) icon.
4.  Make the desired changes.
5.  Click on **Update**.

## Deleting a Reply {#deleting_a_reply}

To delete a reply:

1.  Navigate to a threaded discussion in the Lessons tool of your
    Isidore course site.
2.  Click on the title of a thread.
3.  Locate the reply you\'re wanting to delete and click on the **trash
    can** (delete) icon next to it.
4.  Click on **Delete** to verify deletion.

## Guest Users {#guest_users_2}

If you have an Isidore guest account, you can reset your Isidore
password.

To do so:

1.  Navigate to
    [<https://isidore.udayton.edu>](https://isidore.udayton.edu) and
    click on the **Guest Users** link.
2.  Click on the **Reset Password** link.
3.  Enter your email address in the text box and press the **Send
    Password** button.
4.  An email will be sent to your email account that contains
    instructions for resetting your password. You\'ll need to reset your
    password within 1 hour or else the link to reset your password will
    expire.

Your instructor may request you to resubmit an assignment. To do so,
follow these steps:

1.  Click on the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click the title of the assignment you want to resubmit.\<br
    /\>**Note**: Returned assignments will say \"Returned\" in the
    \"Status\" column of the Assignments table.
3.  You will see the original assignment instructions and your original
    submission text or attachment. Your instructor may have included
    comments in the text of your original submission, which will appear
    in red. Any additional comments from your instructor will appear
    near the bottom of the page. In the box labeled \"Enter resubmission
    text below\", edit or paste your revised submission for the
    assignment or remove your original attachment file and upload your
    new attachment file.
4.  When you are finished revising your assignment, click **Resubmit**.
    Alternatively, you can click **Save draft** to save your submission
    and continue working later. Just make sure you return later to
    submit your assignment or else your instructor won\'t be able to
    view it.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [Assignments](Assignments "wikilink")

\_\_TOC\_\_

## Reviewing Submissions By Requirement {#reviewing_submissions_by_requirement}

This approach allows you to review all students\' submissions to a
specific requirement.

1.  Navigate to the **CompFolio** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  On the **Home** page of the CompFolio tool, choose the **By
    Requirement** tab.
3.  Click to expand whichever category includes the requirement you\'d
    like to review.
4.  Next to the requirement, you will see the number of students who
    have recently submitted to it.
5.  Click on the requirement\'s title to view the students\'
    submissions.
6.  You will see a list of students and their corresponding status for
    this requirement.
    -   **Note:** Use the filter by group/section feature to see a
        specific roster or group.
7.  Find a student whose submission has the status of **Submitted**
    (yellow) and click on the student\'s name.
8.  You will see the time and date at which the student submitted, as
    well as the submitted attachment(s). Click on the attachment(s) to
    download to your computer.
9.  In the feedback panel, write any comments you have for the student.
    You may also attach a document with comments.
    -   *Note: Some feedback must be provided in the form of a file
        and/or comments.*
10. Choose **Save and Complete** to mark this requirement as completed
    for this student. Or choose **Save and Reopen** to mark this
    requirement as reopened for this student.
11. You will be returned to the list of students and their statuses for
    this requirement.

## Reviewing Submissions By Student {#reviewing_submissions_by_student}

This approach allows you to review a specific student\'s submissions to
all requirements.

1.  Navigate to the **CompFolio** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  On the **Home** page of the CompFolio tool, choose the **By
    Student** tab.
3.  Next to each student\'s name, you will see a progress bar indicating
    the students\' progress through the requirements.
    -   The green part of the bar indicates the number of completed
        requirements.
    -   The orange part of the bar indicates the number of submitted
        requirements.
    -   The red part of the bar indicates the number of reopened
        requirements.
    -   The remainder of the bar indicates the number of requirements
        that are ready for them to submit.
4.  Click on a student\'s name to see their submissions.
5.  Next to each category, there are colored boxes with numbers to
    indicate the student\'s progress through the requirements in the
    category.
    -   *Note: Click the **Switch to Table View** in the top right hand
        corner to see the expanded list of requirements in order with
        colored highlighting to indicate statuses.*
    -   The blue box indicates the number of requirements with the
        status of **Ready**.
    -   The red box indicates the number of requirements with the status
        of **Reopened**.
    -   The orange box indicates the number of requirements with the
        status of **Submitted**.
    -   The green box indicates the number of requirements with the
        status of **Completed**.
6.  Find a requirement that has the status of **Submitted** (yellow) and
    click on it to view the student\'s submission.
7.  You will see the time and date at which the student submitted, as
    well as the submitted attachment(s). Click on the attachment(s) to
    download to your computer.
8.  In the feedback panel, write any comments you have for the student.
    You may also attach a document with comments.
    -   *Note: Some feedback must be provided in the form of a file
        and/or comments.*
9.  Choose **Save and Complete** to mark this requirement as completed
    for this student. Or choose **Save and Reopen** to mark this
    requirement as reopened for this student.
10. You will be returned to the specific student\'s list of requirements
    and categories.

## Reviewing Submissions By Recently Submitted {#reviewing_submissions_by_recently_submitted}

This approach allows you to review student\'s most recent submissions to
any requirement in the tool.

1.  Navigate to the **CompFolio** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  On the **Home** page of the CompFolio tool, choose the **Recently
    Submitted** tab.
3.  You will see a descending list of students\' most recent submissions
    that require action from the instructor before they can proceed
    further.
    -   *Note: Each column in the table is sortable. To sort by most
        recently updated, click the **Last Updated** column header
        twice.*
4.  Click on the link to the requirement in the **Requirement** column
    to see the student\'s submission.
5.  You will see the time and date at which the student submitted, as
    well as the submitted attachment(s). Click on the attachment(s) to
    download to your computer.
6.  In the feedback panel, write any comments you have for the student.
    You may also attach a document with comments.
    -   *Note: Some feedback must be provided in the form of a file
        and/or comments.*
7.  Choose **Save and Complete** to mark this requirement as completed
    for this student. Or choose **Save and Reopen** to mark this
    requirement as reopened for this student.
8.  You will be returned to the recently submitted tab.

1.  Click on the **Play Mode** tab at the top of the menu.

    option.

    without questions.

### To view the video with questions: {#to_view_the_video_with_questions}

1.  Click on the **Play Mode** tab at the top of the menu.
2.  You will be prompted with a popup to choose how you would like to
    view the video - either with questions or without questions.
3.  Click the **Continue** button to view the video with questions
    again.
    -   Note: Any questions you answer on this second viewing will
        override your previous answers.
4.  You will be able to watch the video again and re-answer the
    questions.

## Reviewing Questions & Answers {#reviewing_questions_answers}

To review study questions added by other individuals:

1.  Navigate to an instance of a study question on a Lessons page or
    subpage and click on the link.
2.  Any study questions that have been added by others will appear in a
    list. Some instructors may choose to enable a setting where students
    must post their own study question before being able to see
    questions posted by others. In that case, you\'ll need to follow the
    steps to [add a study
    question](Add/Edit/Delete_a_study_question "wikilink") before
    you\'re able to see the list of questions.
3.  Click on **Click to Reveal Answer** to view the answer to a study
    question.
    -   If you\'re an instructor, you can click on the **Mark as
        verified** link to show students you\'ve verified that their
        question and answer are accurate. The button should now read
        \"Verified answer\".
    -   If you\'re a student, answers that have been reviewed by your
        instructor will have text reading, \"Verified answer\" next to
        them.
4.  You can also verify additional answers by following the steps above
    after clicking on **Reveal Answers**.

## Editing Questions & Answers {#editing_questions_answers}

*Students can edit and delete their own questions and answers.
Instructors can edit and delete everyone\'s questions and answers.*

To edit a study question and/or answer:

1.  Navigate to an instance of a study question on a Lessons page or
    subpage and click on the link.
2.  Click on the study question you want to modify.
3.  Click on **Edit Q&A**.
4.  Make the desired changes and click on the **Save** button.
5.  You can also edit additional answers by following the steps above
    after clicking on **Reveal Answers**.

## Deleting Questions & Answers {#deleting_questions_answers}

*Please be cautious when deleting data from Study Questions, as the data
is not recoverable.*

*Students can edit and delete their own questions and answers.
Instructors can edit and delete everyone\'s questions and answers.*

To delete a study question and/or answer:

1.  Navigate to an instance of a study question on a Lessons page or
    subpage and click on the link.
2.  Click on the study question you want to modify.
3.  Click on **Edit Q&A**.
4.  Click on **Delete Question**.
5.  Click on **OK** to confirm deletion.
6.  You can also delete additional answers by following the steps above
    after clicking on **Reveal Answers**.

`     ``<text bytes="1331" sha1="sg92vwtoekda57ks39g1gqf8odemx1i" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Instructors can view the Event Log by visiting the Tests & Quizzes tool in their Isidore sites. The Event Log appears as one of the tabs across the top of the main Tests & Quizzes page.`

The Event Log table contains the following columns:

-   Title - contains titles of assessments
-   Assessment ID - contains assessment IDs
-   Name - contains students\' names and usernames
-   Entry Date - contains the date and time students began (entered) an
    assessment
-   Date Submitted - contains the date the assessment was submitted (if
    at all) by the student (User Submit) or when the timer runs out
    (Timer Submit)
-   Duration - contains the amount of time a student spent in an
    assessment
-   Errors - contains errors students encountered, such as entering an
    incorrect assessment password
-   IP Address - contains the IP address of the device a student took
    the assessment with

## Considerations for Using IP Address Information {#considerations_for_using_ip_address_information}

**Please use caution when using the IP addresses from the Event Log
table. IP address may not be a good indicator of physical location.**

There are many reasons why a student\'s IP address may appear like it\'s
a non-UD IP address, including:

-   Connecting to a virtual private network (VPN)
-   Connecting to a cellular 4G/5G network

`     ``<text bytes="1931" sha1="4m3pm1bc72lz1p72wb8pws90siv9mr5" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Zoom can be used to hold private meetings with individual students or groups of students. Below is our recommended method for setting up these meetings. `

### To schedule virtual office hours: {#to_schedule_virtual_office_hours}

1.  Navigate to the Isidore site where you\'d like to host virtual
    office hours.
2.  Click on the **Zoom** tool from the tool menu.
3.  Click on the **Schedule a Meeting** button.
4.  In the **Topic** field, type in something like \"Office Hours\".
5.  In the **When** field, choose the date of your first office hours
    meeting.
6.  In the **Duration** field, choose the duration of your first office
    hours meeting.
7.  Under the **Time Zone** field, select **Recurring Meeting** and
    choose how often the office hours meeting room should repeat.
8.  In the **Meeting Options** section, click the checkbox next to the
    **Enable waiting room** option.
9.  Press the **Save** button.
10. Return to the main page of the Zoom tool. On the **Upcoming
    Meetings** tab, you will see each of your Office Hours sessions
    coming up.

### Using virtual office hours: {#using_virtual_office_hours}

1.  When you are ready to start your office hours, click **Start** next
    to the correct meeting time.
2.  When the room launches, click on the **Participants** tool from the
    host controls to open the participant tool.
3.  If students would like to meet with you, they will appear in the
    **Participants** tool as \"waiting\".
4.  Hover over the student\'s name. Click on the **Admit** button next
    to the student\'s name to let the student into the room. The student
    will join the room.
5.  When you are finished meeting with the student, either ask them to
    leave the room or hover over the student\'s name and click the
    **Remove** button.
6.  If there are additional students waiting, click on their names to
    admit them.
    -   **Note:** Make sure you do NOT record these meetings or else
        they will be visible to other students in the class.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [Zoom](Zoom "wikilink") page

`     ``<comment>`{=html}`Created page with "To schedule a meeting:  #Navigate to the `**`Zoom Meetings`**` tool in your Isidore course site. #Click on the `**`Schedule a New Meeting`**` button. ##Enter a topic (or title) of..."``</comment>`{=html}\
`     ``<origin>`{=html}`6920``</origin>`{=html}\
`     ``<model>`{=html}`wikitext``</model>`{=html}\
`     ``<format>`{=html}`text/x-wiki``</format>`{=html}\
`     ``<text bytes="1841" sha1="pr6bmpd9oa9w0yo5egpkbm1l8axgcpb" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`To schedule a meeting:`

1.  Navigate to the **Zoom Meetings** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on the **Schedule a New Meeting** button.
    1.  Enter a topic (or title) of the meeting.
    2.  (Optional) Enter a description of the meeting.
    3.  Enter a date, time, and duration of the meeting. Adjust the time
        zone if needed. If the meeting will occur more than once, check
        the \"Recurring meeting\" check box and specify that recurrence,
        how frequently it repeats, and the end date.
    4.  By default, required registrations is off. If you would like
        require registration, check the box next to \"Required\".
    5.  If you would like to allow hosts and/or participants to share
        video via their webcam, toggle the settings to \"on\".
    6.  Choose whether audio will go through the phone, computer, or
        both. In most cases, computer audio will be the preferred
        setting.
    7.  If you would like to require participants to enter a password to
        join the meeting, check the box next to \"Require meeting
        password\".
    8.  If you would like participants to be able to join the meeting
        before the host, leave the box checked next to \"Enable join
        before host\".
    9.  If you would like participants to be muted upon entry, check the
        box next to \"Mute participants on entry\". This will cut down
        on background noise from participants, but they\'ll need to
        press a button before they speak.
    10. You can enable a waiting room if you want participants to have
        somewhere to wait until you let them into the meeting.
    11. Check the box next to \"Record the meeting automatically in the
        cloud\" if you would like meetings to be recorded automatically
        and stored in Cloud Recordings.
    12. If someone will be co-hosting the meeting with you, enter their
        email addresses in the \"Alternative Hosts\" text box.
    13. Click on **Save**.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Zoom
Meetings](Zoom_Meetings "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="815" sha1="518ctkrhlp1oz3dunm8iirujkl5gp00" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`To search for text in a message:`

1.  Navigate to the **Messages** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click the folder you wish to search.
3.  Next to \"Search for text:\", type your search terms in the text
    box, and then click **Search**. The standard search will look for
    your terms in the subject line of the messages in the selected
    folder. Searches are case sensitive.
4.  To modify the search parameters, click **Advanced Search** and check
    the appropriate box(es). Available parameters are:
    -   Subject

        remain checked for subsequent searches until you clear them by

`     ``<text bytes="1182" sha1="gqknb3wx4krdutf5unxu9zl6uibp8s1" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`==Quick Poll Results for Instructors==`

There are a couple things to note about Quick Poll results:

-   By default, students can see the results summary, but not how
    individuals responded.
-   By default, instructors can see the results summary, and how
    individuals responded.
-   If a poll is set to anonymous, no one can see how individuals
    responded.
-   Instructors may choose to hide the results summary from students.

To view Quick Poll results:

1.  Click on the link of the Quick Poll instance you added to your site.
2.  Locate the results (graph) icon next to the poll and click on it.
    *If the poll is set to be anonymous, the results (graph) icon will
    be disabled.*
3.  You\'ll be able to review how many individuals responded to each
    option and the names of individuals who responded to each option.

## Quick Poll Results for Students {#quick_poll_results_for_students}

To view Quick Poll results:

1.  Click on the link of the Quick Poll instance in your Isidore site.
2.  Once you\'ve selected your response, you\'ll be able to see how your
    peers responded to the poll. That is, if the setting to allow
    students to see the results summary is enabled.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Quick Poll](Quick_Poll "wikilink")

## Sending a message {#sending_a_message}

To send a message:

1.  Navigate to the **Messages** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  On the Messages screen, click **Compose Message**.
3.  Next to \"To\", use the list to select the individual or group you
    want to receive the message. Once you select one recipient, you may
    click back in the \"To\" box to select another recipient. You can
    also choose to send your message to the entire site, or to all users
    with a particular role (e.g., all instructors or all assistants).
4.  If you wish to blind carbon-copy someone, click on the \"Add Bcc\"
    link and select the recipient you want to Bcc.
5.  If you would like to send the message out to the recipients\' UD
    email addresses, check the box next to \"Send a copy of this message
    to recipients\' email address(es)\".
6.  Next to \"Subject\", type the subject of your message.
7.  Under \"Message\", use the rich-text editor to compose your
    message.\<br /\>**Note**: Pasting text into the [Rich-text
    editor](Rich-text_editor "wikilink") should preserve most
    formatting, but some types of formatting, such as colored text, may
    need to be added manually in the editor after pasting.
8.  Under \"Attachments\", you can attach a file from your local
    computer or from Resources, or specify the URL for a file on the
    web.
9.  To send your message, click **Send**.

## Forwarding a message {#forwarding_a_message}

To forward a message to another recipient:

1.  Navigate to the **Messages** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  On the Messages screen, click **Received** to view the messages
    you\'ve received.
3.  Click on the Subject of the message you wish to forward.
4.  Click **Forward**.
5.  Next to \"Select Forward Recipients\", use the list to select the
    individual or group you want to receive the message. Once you select
    one recipient, you may click back in the \"Select Forward
    Recipients\" box to select another recipient. You can also choose to
    send your message to the entire site, or to all users with a
    particular role (e.g., all instructors or all assistants).
6.  If you wish to blind carbon-copy someone, click on the \"Add Bcc\"
    link and select the recipient you want to Bcc.
7.  If you would like to send the message out to the recipients\' UD
    email addresses, check the box next to \"Send a copy of this message
    to recipients\' email address(es)\".
8.  Under \"Message\", use the rich-text editor to compose your
    message.\<br /\>**Note**: Pasting text into the [Rich-text
    editor](Rich-text_editor "wikilink") should preserve most
    formatting, but some types of formatting, such as colored text, may
    need to be added manually in the editor after pasting.
9.  Under \"Attachments\", you can attach a file from your local
    computer or from Resources, or specify the URL for a file on the
    web.
10. To send your message, click **Send**.

## Replying to a message {#replying_to_a_message}

To reply to a message:

1.  Navigate to the **Messages** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  On the Messages screen, click **Received** to view the messages
    you\'ve received.
3.  Click on the Subject of the message to which you\'re replying.
4.  Click **Reply** or **Reply to all**.
5.  If you wish, you can use the list next to \"Select Additional
    Recipients\", to select additional individual(s) or group(s) you
    want to receive the message. You can also choose to send your
    message to the entire site, or to all users with a particular role
    (e.g., all instructors or all assistants).
6.  If you wish to blind carbon-copy someone, click on the \"Add Bcc\"
    link and select the recipients you want to Bcc.
7.  If you would like to send the message out to the recipients\' UD
    email addresses, check the box next to \"Send a copy of this message
    to recipients\' email address(es)\".
8.  Under \"Message\", use the rich-text editor to compose your
    message.\<br /\>**Note**: Pasting text into the [Rich-text
    editor](Rich-text_editor "wikilink") should preserve most
    formatting, but some types of formatting, such as colored text, may
    need to be added manually in the editor after pasting.
9.  Under \"Attachments\", you can attach a file from your local
    computer or from Resources, or specify the URL for a file on the
    web.
10. To send your message, click **Send**.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Messages](Messages "wikilink") page

`     ``<text bytes="1115" sha1="6khgg5pdi3okschfwd7cr7b60r5yz6x" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Whether you are typing a long assignment submission in the text editor, or posting a detailed discussion forum post, you’ll no longer be the victim of lost work and will no longer be logged out of Isidore without warning. A new security feature has been installed that will inform users before their session times out so they won't lose any work they’ve composed in Isidore.`

After 1 hour and 10 minutes of inactivity in Isidore, users will receive
a pop-up warning message. If you're still in front of the computer
working on Isidore you'll be able to click a 'continue working in
Isidore' button to remain logged in.

In 10 minutes, if you're away from your computer (or haven't clicked the
button to remain logged in) the previous warning message will be
replaced by another message informing you that you've been logged out.
If you had work on the screen that you don't want to lose you'll be able
to follow the instructions in the message to copy and paste your work
from Isidore to your computer to prevent data loss. \<br /\>\<br /\>
Return to the main [Isidore](Isidore "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="1237" sha1="gf7mbzo01gfow0i5tudvvx80hbokxp0" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`==Setting empty cells to zero for an individual gradebook item==`

To set empty cells to zero for an individual item:

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your course site\'s menu bar.
2.  Locate the title of the gradebook item and click on the
    downward-facing arrow in the lower right hand corner of the cell and
    select **Set Score for Empty Cells**.
3.  Click on the **Done** button.
4.  Click on the **Continue** button.
5.  Zeros should now be entered in the cells that were previously empty.

## Setting all empty cells in Gradebook to zero {#setting_all_empty_cells_in_gradebook_to_zero}

**Please note that setting empty cells to zeros should not be done until
the very end of the semester. There is no way to undo this action.**

To set all empty cells to scores of zero:

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your course site\'s menu bar.
2.  Locate the cell that is titled **Course Grade**.
3.  Click on the downward-facing arrow in the lower right hand corner of
    the cell and select **Set Zero Score for Empty Cells**.
4.  You\'ll also have the option to keep or overwrite comments.
5.  A warning will be displayed, letting you know this is not
    reversible. Click on **Update** to set all empty cells to zero.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [Gradebook](Gradebook "wikilink") page

`     ``<text bytes="3278" sha1="90ava6z4he9h23rk0jyzg6w3dya46yc" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`== General information ==`

You can change the permissions from the default settings either while
you\'re creating a new forum or topic (see [Create Forums and Topics in
Forums](Create_Forums_and_Topics_in_Forums "wikilink")), or when you\'re
editing an existing forum or topic (see [Edit or Delete a Forum or
Topic](Edit_or_Delete_a_Forum_or_Topic "wikilink")).

In **Forum Settings** and **Topic Settings**, under **Advanced Options**
-\> **Permissions**, you can modify permission levels for participant
roles (and groups, if you\'ve created them; see [Manage
Groups](Manage_Groups "wikilink")). Click the right arrow next to
\"Permissions\" to expand the options available. Next to the role of the
participant, use the **Permission Level** drop-down list to select from
several predefined permission levels. Additionally, you can create
custom permission levels by clicking the right arrow next to
\"Customize\" to enable or disable specific functions.

**Note:** If you\'re wanting to have a whole class discussion, the
default permissions do not need to be changed.

**Note**: Forum permission settings will apply to all subsequently
created topics in that forum, but if you modify forum permission
settings after topics have been created, you must change the topic
permission settings separately.

## Custom permission levels {#custom_permission_levels}

When creating custom permission levels, the functions you can allow
participants to perform are:

-   **New Forum**: Participants may create a new forum. You can modify
    this option only via Template Settings.
-   **New Topic**: Participants may create a new topic.
-   **New Conversation**: Participants may create a new conversation in
    the topic.
-   **Reply**: Participants may respond to an existing conversation.
-   **Post to Gradebook**: Participants may grade responses and add
    comments to the Gradebook.
-   **Change Settings**: Participants may change the forum or topic
    settings.
-   **Read**: Participants may read forum or topic responses.
-   **Mark as Read**: Participants may mark messages as read.
-   **Moderate Messages**: Participants may moderate messages posted to
    the forum/topic (available if you\'ve chosen to moderate your forum
    or topic).
-   **Edit Messages**: Participants may not revise any messages, may
    revise their own messages, or may revise any messages.
-   **Delete Messages**: Participants may not remove any messages, may
    remove their own messages, or may remove any messages.

## Limiting access to a specific group {#limiting_access_to_a_specific_group}

To release forums and/or topics to specific groups:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool.
2.  Click **New Forum** or **New Topic**, or click **Forum Settings** or
    **Topic Settings** to modify an existing forum or topic.
3.  On the Forum Settings or Topic Settings page, click on the
    **Advanced Options** tab. Under \"Permissions\", next to the
    relevant role (e.g., \"student\"), from the **Permission Level**
    drop-down list, select **None**.
4.  In the **Permission Level** drop-down list:
    -   Next to the **Student** role, select **None**. This will prevent
        other students from accessing this forum or topic.
    -   Next to the **Group** role, select **Contributor**. If you\'re
        wanting to give Team 1 access to this particular forum or topic,
        make Team 1 a contributor in this step.
5.  At the bottom of the page, click **Save**.

## Change Overall Resource Permissions {#change_overall_resource_permissions}

To change permissions for the Resources tool:

1.  Navigate to the **Resources** tool in your course site.
2.  Click on the **Permissions** tab.
3.  Check or uncheck the boxes to grant the permissions. Options for
    permissions include:
    -   **Create resources**: Add new resources
    -   **Read resources**: View and download resources - **students
        MUST have this permission to open any files in the course site**
    -   **Edit any resource**: Modify any resources
    -   **Edit own resources**: Modify own resources
    -   **Delete any resource**: Remove any resources
    -   **Delete own resources**: Remove own resources
    -   **Access/create group resources**: Allows participants to see
        all resources, even those assigned to specific groups
    -   **Read hidden resources**: Allows participants to see Resource
        items
4.  Click **Save**.

## Change Folder Resource Permissions {#change_folder_resource_permissions}

To change permissions for a folder in Resources, follow these steps:

1.  Navigate to the **Resources** tool in your course site.
2.  Click on the **Actions** button next to the folder and click **Edit
    Permissions**.
3.  Check or uncheck the boxes to grant the permissions based on
    participant role. Options for permissions include:
    -   **Create resources**: Add new resources
    -   **Read resource**: View and download resources
    -   **Edit any resources**: Modify any resources
    -   **Edit own resources**: Modify own resources
    -   **Delete any resource**: Remove any resources
    -   **Delete own resources**: Remove own resources
    -   **Access/create group resources**: Allows participants to see
        all resources, even those assigned to specific groups
    -   **Read hidden resources**: Allows participants to see Resource
        items
4.  Click **Save**.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Resources](Resources "wikilink")

`     ``<text bytes="2321" sha1="c0zaaydta862gedxorprr2301ibw776" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Wiki has two levels of permissions at site level and at page level. Site level permissions are the default permissions for all pages. However, permissions can be changed for individual pages. For example, you can alter permissions so that wiki is editable by everyone, apart from one page which can only be edited by maintainers.`

There are 5 levels of permission within Wiki:

-   Wiki read (read pages)
-   Wiki create (create new pages; edit must be enabled to allow this)
-   Wiki edit (edit pages)
-   Wiki admin (alter site permissions)
-   Wiki super-admin

Remember that permissions cascade downwards. Therefore, you cannot
update a page if you cannot read it, so it makes no sense to enable
\'update\' but dis-enable \'read\'. If you enabled \'create\' or
\'update\', Wiki will assume that you want \'read\' permission enabled
as well.

We recommend the following Wiki permissions:

*Default - using Wiki as a traditional wiki tool*

With these permissions, all users can edit the wiki. This would allow
collaborative drafting of documents, for example. This is the default
setting for permissions.

             Read   Create   Edit   Admin   Super
  ---------- ------ -------- ------ ------- -------
  Access     yes    yes      yes            
  Maintain   yes    yes      yes    yes     yes

\_\_TOC\_\_

## Site-level Permissions {#site_level_permissions}

Site level permissions are the default permissions for all pages.

To alter site-level permissions, select \'info\' and then select \'edit
site permissions\'. Click and un-click the boxes to switch permissions
on and off.

## Page-level Permissions {#page_level_permissions}

Page-level permissions apply to that page only. For example, you can
alter permissions so that wiki is editable by everyone, apart from one
page which can only be edited by maintainers.

To alter page-level permissions, select \'info\'. Click and un-click the
boxes below the permissions to alter the permissions settings. Because
permissions cascade downwards, this may not always have the effect that
you imagine. For example, if \'edit\' is enabled for a role, you cannot
dis-enable \'read\' for that role, because users must be able to read a
page to update it.

The \'create\' permission is not applicable to page-level permissions
and can only be altered at site level. \<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main
[Wiki](Wiki "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

## Enabling Manual Grading {#enabling_manual_grading}

To grade attendance manually:

1.  Navigate to the **Attendance** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on the **Grading** tab.
3.  Enter the number of points possible (the maximum number of points a
    student with perfect attendance would receive for the entire
    semester).
4.  Choose whether students will be allowed to see their grades in the
    Attendance tool.
5.  If you have the Gradebook tool installed, choose whether you want to
    send students\' attendance grades to the Gradebook. If you\'re using
    Categories or Categories & Weighting in your Gradebook, you can
    select a category to send the grades to.
6.  Leave the grading mode set to **Manually grade students\'
    attendance.**
7.  Click on **Save Settings**.

## Enabling Automatic Grading {#enabling_automatic_grading}

To enable automatic grading with rules:

1.  Navigate to the **Attendance** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on the **Grading** tab.
3.  Enter the number of points possible (the maximum number of points a
    student with perfect attendance would receive for the entire
    semester).
4.  Choose whether students will be allowed to see their grades in the
    Attendance tool.
5.  If you have the Gradebook tool installed, choose whether you want to
    send students\' attendance grades to the Gradebook.
6.  Change the grading mode to **Define rules to automatically grade
    attendance.**
7.  Choose whether you would like students to start with a total number
    of points and lose points as they miss class, or whether you would
    like to start with zero points and earn points as they attend class.
8.  Click on **Save Settings**.

### Adding Grading Rules {#adding_grading_rules}

1.  Select an attendance status from the **Status** drop-down.
2.  Enter the numerical range for which the rule takes effect. The range
    is inclusive, meaning that it includes values in the **from** and
    **through** boxes.
3.  Enter the number of **points** (positive or negative), that will be
    added to or subtracted from a student\'s grade, if the rule applies
    to the student.
4.  Click on **Add Rule**.
5.  To add another rule, additional rules, repeat the steps above.

*For example, setting \"Status\" to \"Absent\", \"From\" to \"5\",
\"Through\" to \"10\", and \"Points\" to \"-10\" results in the rule:
\"Student receives -10 points for being Absent 5 through 10 times.\"*
\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [Attendance](Attendance "wikilink") page

Please see this video walkthrough of how to set up extended time
exceptions. \<br /\> \<youtube\>zKnCfk-JG9I\</youtube\> \<br /\>\<br /\>
To release an assessment to a specific student or group of students:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Select **Settings** from the **Action** drop-down menu next to the
    assessment.
3.  Click on the **Exceptions to Time Limit and Delivery Date** tab.
    1.  If an individual student needs an exception, click the radio
        button next to the **Exception for User** option and select the
        student\'s name from the \"Select User\" drop-down. If a group
        of students needs an exception, click the radio button next to
        **Exception for Group** and select the group from the \"Select
        Group\" drop-down.
    2.  Set the open date and time and the due date and time by clicking
        on the calendar icon.
    3.  If the assessment should have a time limit, select the hours and
        minutes the student or group of students should receive. If
        it\'s untimed, leave the hours and minutes set to \"00\".
    4.  If late submissions should be allowed, set the late submission
        date and time by clicking on the calendar icon. If late
        submissions should not be allowed, then set the late submission
        date and time to the same date and time as the due date by
        clicking on the calendar icon.
    5.  Click on the **Add an Exception** button to save the exception
        and/or add another exception.
4.  Click on the **Save & Exit** button.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Tests and
Quizzes](Tests_and_Quizzes "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="2129" sha1="hooeuld8d0o99404z0jsfcwzg96kuor" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`There are multiple ways to setup extra credit in Isidore's Gradebook. `

-   If you have Categories or Categories & Weighting enabled, adding an
    extra credit category with gradebook items in it will help the
    student\'s overall course grade as they earn extra credit. If you
    have an extra credit item within a specific category, it will help
    the student\'s grade in that particular category as they earn extra
    credit.
-   If you don\'t have Categories or Categories & Weighting enabled,
    adding an extra credit item in your gradebook will help the
    student\'s overall course grade as they earn extra credit.

*Please note that setting up extra credit in Isidore\'s Gradebook will
allow a student\'s grade to go over 100%.*

## Adding an extra credit gradebook item {#adding_an_extra_credit_gradebook_item}

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your course site.
2.  Click on **Add Gradebook Item**.
    -   Enter a title for the item.
    -   Enter a point value for the item.
    -   Check the box to indicate it\'s extra credit.
    -   Select a category for the item to calculate into (if you\'re
        using Categories or Categories & Weighting).
    -   Release the item to students.
    -   Include the item in the course grade calculations.
    -   Click on **Create**.

*Enabling this option allows a student\'s course grade to go over 100%.*

## Setting up an extra credit gradebook category {#setting_up_an_extra_credit_gradebook_category}

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your course site.
2.  Click on **Settings**.
3.  Click on **Categories & Weighting**.
4.  Select the **Extra Credit** check box next to an existing category
    you want to make extra credit, or use the **Add a category** button
    to add a new category, marking it as extra credit.
5.  Click on the **Save Changes** button.
6.  Now you can use the **Add Gradebook Item** button to add gradebook
    items to the extra credit category you created. *You should NOT mark
    the gradebook items within that category as extra credit because
    that\'s already covered by the category settings.*

*Enabling this option allows a student\'s course grade to go over 100%.*

## Setting up the assignment {#setting_up_the_assignment}

**Note: You must first have created groups under [Site Info -\> Manage
Groups](Manage_Groups "wikilink") AND added students to each group
before you setup your group assignment. You will NOT be able to edit the
groups later once the assignment is released to a group and posted.**

To setup a group assignment:

1.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **Add**.
3.  Fill in the assignment title and instructions.
4.  If you would like students to acknowledge the honor pledge before
    submitting their work, check the box next to \"Add honor pledge\".
5.  If you would like to add attachments to the assignment that contains
    instructions or a template to complete the assignment, click on the
    **Add Attachments** button, browse to where the files are located,
    and upload the files.
6.  Set the open date, due date, and accept until date by clicking on
    the calendar and selecting a date. Once a date is selected, adjust
    the time by either using the slider or the minus and plus icons. The
    open date is when students will be able to see the assignment and
    begin submitting it. The accept until date is a date that students
    won\'t see, but allows them to submit their assignments late.
    Assignments submitted after the due date will be flagged as late.
7.  Set advanced date options, such as hiding the due date from students
    (not recommended), adding the due date to the calendar (only shown
    if the Calendar tool is installed), and/or adding an announcement
    about the open date to announcements (only shown if the
    Announcements tool is installed). If you enable the announcements
    option, you\'ll be able to choose whether to send an email
    notification about the open date to all participants.
8.  In the \"Assign To\" section, select \"The selected group(s), as a
    group assignment (one group member submits on behalf of the entire
    group).
9.  Select one or more groups the assignment is released to, and click
    on the **Check Now** button to ensure the groups don\'t have any
    participants in common.
10. Submission type refers to the format of the student\'s submitted
    assignment.
    -   Attachments only is the most common type, where students can
        upload file attachment(s) for the instructor to review. Students
        may upload up to 5 file attachments per assignment.
    -   Inline means that students type or paste their assignment into a
        text box for the instructor to review.
    -   Inline and Attachments means that students can choose whether to
        upload a file attachment or type or paste their assignment into
        a text box.
    -   Non-electronic is used to provide assignment instructions, but
        students aren\'t expected to submit anything electronically. One
        use case might be bringing an article to class. Single file
        upload works just like the attachments type, but restricts the
        number of files students can upload to one.
11. If you would like students to be able to resubmit their assignment
    prior to the due date, you can enable the \"Allow Resubmission\"
    option. Once enabled, enter the number of resubmissions students are
    allowed to have and when those resubmissions should be due (usually
    the due date or before).
12. If you would like to have student papers run through Turnitin (UD\'s
    plagiarism detection software), check the box next to \"Use
    Turnitin\". By default students are allowed to see their originality
    reports (recommended), but you can uncheck that option.
13. If you would like to grade anonymously, you can check the box next
    to \"Hide submitters\' identities (e.g. for anonymous grading)\".
    When grading, students\' names will be replaced with an alphanumeric
    code. This setting can be toggled back on at any time. Please note
    that if students include their name within their file attachment or
    the filename, you\'ll be able to see their identities.
14. The default setting is that assignments are set to be graded, but
    this can be turned off my unchecking the \"Grade this assignment\"
    box.
    -   If you\'re setting up a graded assignment, select a grading
        scale. Please note that \"Points\" is the only grading scale
        that works with Gradebook.
    -   Specify the maximum number of points.
    -   Enable rubric grading if you wish to use a rubric. For more
        assistance with rubric grading, please visit the
        [Rubrics](Rubrics "wikilink") page for step-by-step
        instructions.
    -   If you would like the assignment grades to be sent to the
        Gradebook, check the box to enable the setting. This setting
        only appears if you have the Gradebook tool installed.
    -   If you would like to setup peer review, check the box next to
        \"Use peer assessment\" and adjust the other settings. Please
        note that the start date for the peer review period is set to
        the assignment\'s accept until date.
15. Notification email options and additional information sections are
    expandable if you would like to adjust the notification settings and
    add items like a model answer.
16. Click on **Post** to save your assignment settings and make the
    assignment available to students at the specified open date and
    time.

## Grading the assignment {#grading_the_assignment}

To grade the group submission assignment:

1.  Go into the **Assignments** tool.
2.  Click on the **Grade** link beneath the group assignment you wish to
    grade.
3.  Click on the name of the group whose submission you want to grade.
4.  You can open the submitted attachments or review the inline text,
    enter a grade in the \"Grade\" box, type feedback in the
    \"Instructor Summary Comments\" box, add feedback files using the
    **Add Attachments** button.
    -   If you want to assign grade overrides for individual students,
        click on the \"Assign Grade Overrides\" check box. You can enter
        individual grades for students who didn\'t contribute as much to
        the team assignment.
5.  If you want to release the grades and feedback to students
    immediately, click on the **Save and Release to Student** button. If
    you want to save the grades and feedback, but release it to students
    later, click on **Save and Don\'t Release to Students**. You can
    also allow a resubmission for the group on this screen.

To configure your Gradebook:

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **Settings**.
    -   In the **Grade Entry** section, the default setting is
        **Points**. You\'ll be able to setup your category percentages
        in a later step. *The Center for Online Learning no longer
        supports the \"Relative Weightings\" option due to calculation
        errors and issues reported. Please contact the Center for Online
        Learning if you have any questions about this change. If you\'ve
        used relative weightings in the past, you may continue to do so,
        but your gradebook is no longer maintained & supported by the
        Center for Online Learning.*
    -   In the **Grade Release Rules** section, you can choose whether
        to make gradebook items and current calculated course grades
        available to students.
    -   In the **Statistics** section, you can choose whether to display
        assignment statistics and course grade statistics to students.
    -   In the **Categories & Weighting** section, you can choose
        whether to setup your Gradebook with:
        -   No categories - the Gradebook will be setup to display
            individual gradebook items.
        -   Categories only - the Gradebook will be setup with
            individual gradebook items in specified categories.
            -   If you choose this option, you\'ll need to populate the
                names of your gradebook categories (i.e. assignments,
                quizzes, homework, etc.).
        -   Categories & weighting - the Gradebook will be setup with
            individual gradebook items in specified categories that are
            worth a specified weight.
        -   In this section, you can also utilize options like [Drop the
            Lowest](Drop_the_Lowest "wikilink"), [Keep the
            Highest](Keep_the_Highest "wikilink"), [Drop the
            Highest](Drop_the_Highest "wikilink"), and [Setup Extra
            Credit](Setup_Extra_Credit "wikilink").
            -   If you choose this option, you\'ll need to populate the
                names of your gradebook categories (i.e. assignments,
                quizzes, homework, etc.) and the weights of each
                category (must equal 100%).
    -   In the **Grading Schema** section, choose what type of overall
        course grades students will receive - letter grades with +/-,
        letter grades, or Pass/Not Pass.
        -   Then configure the grading scale percentages by entering the
            minimum percentage students would need to earn to receive a
            particular letter grade. **Note: The grading scale should be
            set to the same scale that is listed in the grading policy
            in your course syllabus**.
3.  Click on **Save Changes** once you\'re finished adjusting gradebook
    settings.

*Note: If you\'ve enabled Categories or Categories & Weighting, please
note that categories will not be visible on the main Gradebook screen
until there is at least one gradebook item assigned to that category.*

## Setting up the assignment {#setting_up_the_assignment_1}

1.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **Add**.
3.  Fill in the assignment title and instructions.
4.  Set the open date, due date, and accept until date. **Important
    Note: The accept until date is the date the peer review period
    begins.**
5.  Setup other assignment settings as you normally would.
6.  Under the \"Grading\" section, enter the max points the assignment
    is worth.
7.  Select whether to send the grades to the Gradebook.
8.  Enable the \"Use peer assessment\" option.
9.  Set the date and time the evaluation period finishes, by clicking on
    the calendar icon.
10. Choose whether students should be able to see the identities of
    their peers.
11. Choose whether students should be able to see their peers\' reviews
    of their submissions.
12. Enter the number of submissions students must review.
13. Enter peer review instructions.
14. Click on **Post**.

## Grading the assignment {#grading_the_assignment_1}

Note: You\'ll be able to read students\' reviews during the peer review
period, but you will not be able to assign grades until the peer review
period ends. You can remove peer reviews by clicking on the student\'s
name in the **Reviewed By** column and then clicking on the **Remove
Review** button.

1.  Once the evaluation period has closed, enter your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Go into the **Assignments** tool.
3.  Click on the **Grade** link beneath the peer review assignment you
    wish to grade.
4.  You can review the students' original submissions by clicking on
    their name in the Student column.
    -   You can enter grades and instructor comments on the screen like
        you do with a regular assignment.
    -   Also on this screen, you can see the reviewers' scores in the
        **Reviewer Grade** column.
    -   To review the peer reviewers' comments, click on the peer
        reviewers' names in the **Reviewed By** column.
5.  In order for students to see their peers\' reviews of their papers
    you must release the grades for the assignment.
    -   One way to release grades is to click on an individual
        student\'s name and click the **Save and Release to Student**
        button.
    -   A second way to release grades to students is to click on the
        **Release Grades** button when viewing the list of students\'
        names.

## Step 1: Setup prerequisites and required items {#step_1_setup_prerequisites_and_required_items}

1.  In your Isidore site, navigate to the **Lessons** tool or subpage
    that contains the items you would like to require or make
    prerequisites.
2.  Hover over each item and click on the \"edit\" (pencil/paper) icon
    next to it.
3.  Expand the \"Prerequisites & Requirements\" section.
4.  If an item is a prerequisite for another item, check the box next to
    \"Don\'t Release Item Until All Prerequisites are Completed\".
5.  If an item is required, check the box next to \"Require that the
    student use this item\".
6.  Click on **Update Item**.

## Step 2: Ensure items are in the correct order {#step_2_ensure_items_are_in_the_correct_order}

To ensure that items are in the correct order:

1.  Navigate to a **Lessons** tool or subpage in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Click on **Reorder**.
3.  Drag the items into the correct order.
4.  Click on **Save**.

## Step 3: Add a link to Simple Certificate {#step_3_add_a_link_to_simple_certificate}

*Note: You\'ll want to make sure that the Simple Certificate link is the
last item on the Lessons page. This will ensure that students can\'t
receive a certificate until they\'ve successfully completed the
requirements and prerequisites. You can use the [Reorder
Content](Reorder_Content "wikilink") feature to move it to the bottom of
the list.*

To install Simple Certificate in Lessons:

1.  Navigate to a **Lessons** tool or subpage in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Click on **Add Learning App**.
3.  A window will launch with a list of available learning apps.
4.  Click on **+ Install** button for Simple Certificate.
5.  A link to the new learning app will appear on your Lessons page.

## Step 4: Enable prerequisites and requirements on the certificate link {#step_4_enable_prerequisites_and_requirements_on_the_certificate_link}

1.  In your Isidore site, navigate to the Lessons tool or subpage that
    contains the certificate link.
2.  Hover over the certificate link and click on the \"edit\"
    (pencil/paper) icon next to it.
3.  Expand the \"Prerequisites & Requirements\" section.
4.  Check the box next to \"Don\'t Release Item Until All Prerequisites
    are Completed\".
5.  Check the box next to \"Require that the student use this item\".
6.  Click on **Update Item**.

## Publicly Sharing a Rubric {#publicly_sharing_a_rubric}

To share a rubric (or make it public):

1.  Navigate to the **Rubrics** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on the **globe icon** (make public icon) in the \"Actions\"
    column next to the rubric. The globe will turn blue, indicating that
    public sharing is active.
3.  A copy of the rubric you made public will be placed below in the
    \"Publicly Shared Rubrics\" section.

## Revoking Public Sharing {#revoking_public_sharing}

To revoke public sharing access:

1.  Navigate to the **Rubrics** tool of the site in which you originally
    made the rubric public.
2.  Click on the **globe icon** (revoke public sharing icon) in the
    \"Actions\" columns next to the rubric. The globe will turn gray,
    indicating that public sharing is not active.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Rubrics](Rubrics "wikilink") page

`     ``<text bytes="2362" sha1="nqmpvnvqioyq5l982l4s97azay350lm" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`By default, videos are shared with all participants in a specific site.  For example, if you've uploaded a video to your EDT 634 01 Isidore site, all EDT 634 01 students will be able to view the video, as well as anyone who shows up in the `**`Site Info`**` or `**`Roster`**` tools.`

To change the default video permissions:

1.  Go into your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on the **Warpwire Video** tool.
3.  Locate the video you want to share.
4.  Click on the circle with the ellipsis (or 3 dots) next to the title
    of video.
5.  Select **Share** from the drop down menu.
6.  Underneath the link to the video you have a variety of options when
    sharing your video
    -   Checking the box next to **Start at** will allow you to begin
        the video wherever you want to in the video. Enter the time
        minutes:seconds in the box next to **Start at**.
    -   Checking the box next to **Stop at** will allow you to end the
        video wherever you want to in the video. Enter the time
        minutes:seconds in the box next to **Stop at**.
    -   Checking the box next to **Autoplay** means the video will begin
        immediately when students open the page the video is on.
    -   Checking the box next to **Hide Share** means the video display
        will not include a Share link to your users.
    -   Checking the box next to **Hide Title** means the video display
        will not include the title.
7.  Click on the **Share with additional Users and Groups:** menu and
    choose the permission level you prefer:
    -   **Share with additional Users and Groups (Protected):** - You
        can specify who has access to the videos.
    -   **Share with all Dayton Username users (Institution):** - You
        can specify that everyone who has a UD account can access the
        video.
    -   **Share with everyone on the web (Public):** - You can specify
        that anyone can access the video.
8.  At the bottom there is a search box that allows you to share with
    specific users or groups. Type a user or group\'s name and then
    select them from the list when they appear to share the video with
    them. Note: You can only share videos with users who have an
    official UD Username.
9.  You can use the \"Share Link\" button to highlight and copy the link
    (URL) to the video. Then you can paste the link into an email to
    share it with the individuals you specified in the previous steps.

## FAQs {#faqs_6}

**Can I choose to moderate shoutouts?**\<br /\>Yes, the ability to
moderate shoutouts can be enabled in Settings using the \"Enable
Moderation\" option. Please see [Moderate
shoutouts](Moderate_shoutouts "wikilink") for more detailed
instructions.

**Can I choose to make shoutouts anonymous?**\<br /\>Yes, the ability to
make shoutouts anonymous can be enabled in Settings using the
\"Anonymous to Students\" setting.

**Can I enable/disable specific shoutouts?**\<br /\>Yes, you can enable
and disable the different shoutout types in Settings by clicking on
shoutout types in the \"Potential Shoutouts\" section.

**Can I add my own shoutouts?**\<br /\>No, at this time, you cannot add
custom shoutout types.

**Can the instructor send shoutouts?**\<br /\>No, at this time,
instructors cannot send shoutouts. \<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main
[Learning Apps](Learning_Apps "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}
