## Create a Blank Site from Scratch {#create_a_blank_site_from_scratch}

*This option allows you to create an empty (or blank) course site. If
you choose this option, you\'ll be able to select which tools are
installed in the course site.*

Please see this 2-minute video walkthrough of this process:\<br/\>
\<youtube\>oJj69vj3tF8\</youtube\>

1.  Click on the **Sites** menu (3x3 waffle icon) in the upper
    right-hand portion of the screen.
2.  Click on the **Create New Site** button.
3.  Under the \"Create a site from scratch\" option, select the academic
    term in which you\'ll be teaching and select **Continue**.
4.  Any courses that you\'re listed as the instructor of record will be
    displayed on the screen. To create a course site, select the check
    box next to the course you would like to create. *Please note that
    if you select multiple courses during this step, they will be
    combined into the same course site. If you would like to create
    separate course sites, you need to create your course sites one at a
    time.* Click on **Continue**.
    -   If you do not see your course(s) listed, click on the **I\'m
        unable to find my course or section\...** link and click on
        **Continue**. Select the \"Subject\", \"Course\", and
        \"Section\" from the drop-down menus and click on **Continue**.
    -   If you still don\'t see your course listed, click on the **Still
        cannot find your course/section?** link and manually enter the
        \"Subject\", \"Course\", and \"Section\" and click on
        **Continue**. A request will go to the Center for Online
        Learning who will either approve the request or will contact you
        for more information.
5.  Verify your name and email address on the next screen and click
    **Continue**.
6.  Check the box next to the tools you wish to use in your course site.
    *Please note that students are often annoyed if a tool sits empty
    all semester, so make sure that you\'re only selecting tools that
    will be used during the course.* Click **Continue**.
7.  Select how the course should be published (made available to
    students):
    -   Automatic - This is closest to what you\'ve experienced in the
        past. Isidore will automatically publish your site at 8:00 AM on
        the first day of the term and unpublish your site 2 weeks after
        the term ends.
    -   Scheduled - You can set a publish date/time for your site and an
        optional unpublish date/time. If you don\'t set an unpublish
        date/time, your site will remain available to students.
    -   Manual - You can manually publish and unpublish the site as you
        please.
8.  Click on **Continue**.
9.  Click on the **Create Site** button.
10. Your course site is now available. You may begin modifying it for
    the upcoming semester.

## Duplicate a Site, reusing all content from a previous semester {#duplicate_a_site_reusing_all_content_from_a_previous_semester}

*This option allows you to create an exact copy of another course site.
If you select this option, no student submissions, forum posts, or
grades will be copied over to the new site. You\'ll need to [update
dates and content](Updating_a_Duplicated_Site "wikilink") for the
current semester*

Please see this 2-minute video walkthrough of this process:\<br/\>
\<youtube\>pcDqgDDFklo\</youtube\>

1.  Click on the **Sites** menu (3x3 waffle icon) in the upper
    right-hand portion of the screen.
2.  Click on the **Create New Site** button.
3.  Select **Duplicate an existing site or create from template**.
4.  Select the site you wan to copy.
5.  Select the term in which you\'ll be teaching.
6.  Scroll down to the bottom of the page and click **Go to Roster
    Selection**.
7.  Any courses for which you are listed as the instructor of record
    will be displayed on the screen. Select which roster(s) of students
    should have access to the new site. *Please note that if you select
    multiple rosters during this step, they will be combined into the
    same course site. If you would like to create separate course sites,
    you need to create your course sites one at a time.* Click on
    **Continue**.
    -   If you still don\'t see your course listed, click on the **Still
        cannot find your course/section?** link and manually enter the
        \"Subject\", \"Course\", and \"Section\" and click on
        **Continue**. A request will go to the Center for Online
        Learning who will either approve the request or will contact you
        for more information.
8.  Select how the course should be published (made available to
    students):
    -   Automatic - This is closest to what you\'ve experienced in the
        past. Isidore will automatically publish your site at 8:00 AM on
        the first day of the term and unpublish your site 2 weeks after
        the term ends.
    -   Scheduled - You can set a publish date/time for your site and an
        optional unpublish date/time. If you don\'t set an unpublish
        date/time, your site will remain available to students.
    -   Manual - You can manually publish and unpublish the site as you
        please.
9.  Click on **Continue**.
10. Click on **Create Site**.
11. The site creation process may take a few minutes, depending on how
    much content is being duplicated.
12. Your course site is now available. You may [begin modifying
    it](Updating_a_Duplicated_Site "wikilink") for the upcoming
    semester.

## Create a Site, using a template {#create_a_site_using_a_template}

*This option allows you to duplicate the template site created by the
Center for Online Learning. If you select this option, the template will
be copied and your roster(s) will be added to the copied site. You will
then need to [modify the template
site](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-firststeps) for
your class.* [Learn more about the template
site.](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-gettingstarted-bigpicture)

Please see this 2-minute video walkthrough of this process:\<br/\>
\<youtube\>-0rMP9fTAqU\</youtube\>

1.  Click on the **Sites** menu (3x3 waffle icon) in the upper
    right-hand portion of the screen.
2.  Click on the **Create New Site** button.
3.  Select **Duplicate an existing site or create from template**.
4.  Select the template site for the upcoming/current term \"Term Year
    Template\" (i.e. \"Spring 2022 Template\") by clicking on the radio
    button next to it.
5.  Select the term in which you\'ll be teaching from the drop-down
    menu.
6.  Scroll down to the bottom of the page and click **Go to Roster
    Selection**.
7.  Any courses for which you\'re listed as the instructor of record
    will be displayed on the screen. Select which roster(s) of students
    should have access to the new site. \<br/\>*Please note that if you
    select multiple rosters during this step, they will be combined into
    the same course site. If you would like to create separate course
    sites, you need to create your course sites one at a time.*
    -   If you do not see your course(s) listed, select the \"Subject\",
        \"Course\", and \"Section\" from the drop-down menus and click
        on **Create Site**.
    -   If you still don\'t see your course listed, click on the **Still
        cannot find your course/section?** link and manually enter the
        \"Subject\", \"Course\", and \"Section\" and click on **Create
        Site**. A request will go to the Center for Online Learning who
        will either approve the request or will contact you for more
        information.
8.  Select how the course should be published (made available to
    students):
    -   Automatic - This is closest to what you\'ve experienced in the
        past. Isidore will automatically publish your site at 8:00 AM on
        the first day of the term and unpublish your site 2 weeks after
        the term ends.
    -   Scheduled - You can set a publish date/time for your site and an
        optional unpublish date/time. If you don\'t set an unpublish
        date/time, your site will remain available to students.
    -   Manual - You can manually publish and unpublish the site as you
        please.
9.  Click on **Continue**.
10. Click on **Create Site**.
11. The site creation process may take a few minutes, depending on how
    much content is being duplicated.

\<br /\>\<br /\>

If you have any problems or questions during the course creation
process, please feel free to contact the Center for Online Learning at
(937) 229-5039 or <onlinelearning@udayton.edu>. \<br /\>\<br /\> Return

#### Instructors

If you don\'t see a site for your course for the upcoming term, you need
to create one. You may create new course sites by using the **Create New
Site** button near the top of the Sites menu. New course sites will be
available for creation approximately 10 weeks before the start of the
next term.

Instructors may choose to have their sites published automatically or at
a specific date/time, or can manually change the status of their sites.
Instructors will always have access to the site, whether it\'s
published, scheduled, or unpublished. (See [Manage
Access](Manage_Access "wikilink"))

#### Students

If you don\'t see a site for a course you\'re enrolled in, your
instructor may not be using Isidore, may not have created their site
yet, or may not have made it available to students yet. Instructors may
unpublish or publish their sites as they please. \_\_TOC\_\_

## Accessing sites via the My Sites tool {#accessing_sites_via_the_my_sites_tool}

To access the My Sites tool:

1.  Click on the **Home** link in the upper left corner of your Isidore
    screen.
2.  Click on **My Sites**.
3.  Any sites that you\'re a participant in will be displayed in the
    list.

## Accessing sites via the Sites menu {#accessing_sites_via_the_sites_menu}

To access sites via the Sites menu:

1.  Click on the **Sites** icon (3x3 waffle) in the upper right-hand
    corner of your Isidore screen.
2.  Any site in which you are a participant should be displayed on the
    drop-down menu, which is separated by term.
3.  If you don\'t see a site, you may need to click on the **View All
    Sites** button near the top of the screen.

## Enable/Disable Autofavoriting of Course Sites {#enabledisable_autofavoriting_of_course_sites}

If you enable autofavoriting of course sites, sites you are added to or
sites you create will be automatically be shown at the top of your
Isidore screen.

To adjust autofavoriting preferences:

1.  Click on the **Sites** link next to your profile picture in the
    upper right-hand corner of the Isidore screen.
2.  Click on the **Organize Favorites** tab.
3.  Click on the **On/Off** toggle next to \"Automatically add new sites
    to your favorites bar.\"

## Manually Favoriting Course Sites {#manually_favoriting_course_sites}

1.  Click on the **Sites** link next to your profile picture in the
    upper right-hand corner of the Isidore screen.
2.  Click on the star next to the course sites you would like to
    favorite.
3.  Click on the blue **X** to close your Sites drawer.
4.  You may need to click on the **Reload** link for the favorited
    course(s) to appear in the blue Isidore bar at the top of the
    screen.

## Reordering Course Sites {#reordering_course_sites}

1.  Click on the **Sites** link next to your profile picture in the
    upper right-hand corner of the Isidore screen.
2.  Click on the **Organize Favorites (#)** tab.
3.  Drag the courses up and down until you get them into your preferred
    order.
4.  Click on the blue **X** to close your Sites drawer.
5.  You may need to click on the **Reload** link for the favorited
    course(s) to appear in the correct order in the blue Isidore bar at
    the top of the screen.

To reorder categories and requirements:

1.  Navigate to the **CompFolio** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click the **Manage** button.
3.  Click the **Sort** button.
4.  Click and hold the item, either category or requirement, that you\'d
    like to reorder. Move it to the position you\'d like it to be and
    release the mouse button.
    -   *Note: It is possible to move requirements between categories.*
    -   *Note: To easily reorder the categories, click the **Collapse
        All** button so only the categories are visible.*
5.  Click the **Save Changes** button at the bottom to save the new
    order. Click the **Reset Changes** link to revert to the original
    order.

## Using the \"Item Order\" button {#using_the_item_order_button}

To reorder items using the \"Item Order\" button:

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Click on the **Item Order** button in the upper right-hand corner of
    the screen.
3.  Drag gradebook items into the proper category.
4.  Click on **Update Sort Order**.

## Using Click and Drag {#using_click_and_drag}

To reorder items using click and drag:

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Locate a gradebook item you wish to move.
3.  Click and drag the title of the cell to the left or right until a
    green line appears when you reach the desired location.
4.  Let the item go and the order should be updated.

## Using Move Left and Move Right {#using_move_left_and_move_right}

To reorder items using the \"Move Right\" and \"Move Left\" feature:

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Locate the gradebook item you wish to move.
3.  Click on the small drop-down arrow at the bottom right of the cell
    and select **Move Right** or **Move Left** until the gradebook item
    is in the preferred location.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [Gradebook](Gradebook "wikilink") page

`     ``<text bytes="5587" sha1="6wbs38gas3v6sz4w0xw057ecqtocbsj" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`While no solution is foolproof when it comes to cheating, there are steps you can take to make it more difficult when offering online assessments through the Tests & Quizzes tool.`

## Randomizing the order of questions {#randomizing_the_order_of_questions}

When question randomization is enabled, Isidore displays questions in a
different order for each student.

To randomize question order:

1.  Navigate to the Tests & Quizzes tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Click on the "Select Action" menu next to the assessment and select
    "Edit".
3.  Locate the part of the assessment (i.e. Part 1) and click on the
    "Edit" link to the right of it.\<br /\>![Edit Part
    Button](Editing%20Part.jpg "Edit Part Button")\<br /\>
4.  Scroll down to the "Question Ordering" section and select "Random
    within Part". Click on "Save" at the bottom of the page.
5.  If your assessment contains more than one part, you'll need to make
    this change to each part if you would like the questions to appear
    in a random order.\<br /\>![Random within Part
    option](Question%20Ordering%20Options.jpg "Random within Part option")

## Randomizing answer choices {#randomizing_answer_choices}

Not only can you randomize questions, but you can also randomize answer
choice options in multiple choice questions. If this setting is enabled,
Isidore displays answer choices in a different order for each student.
Please note that this option should not be used with questions that have
"none of the above" or "all of the above" as options.

To randomize answer choice options:

1.  Navigate to the Tests & Quizzes tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Click on the "Select Action" menu next to the assessment and select
    "Edit".
3.  Locate a multiple choice question and click on the "Edit" link next
    to it.
4.  Scroll down to the "Randomize Answers" option and select the radio
    button next to "Yes". Scroll down and click on "Save". You'll need
    to make this change to every multiple choice question you would like
    to randomize.

## Setting a time limit {#setting_a_time_limit}

Enabling a time limit is considered a deterrent to cheating because
students have a fixed amount of time to complete the assessment and
aren't as tempted to spend time looking up answers or recording the test
content.

To enable a time limit:

1.  Navigate to the Tests & Quizzes tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Click on the "Select Action" menu next to the assessment and click
    on "Settings".
3.  Click on the "Availability and Submissions" tab.
4.  Under the "Do you want this assessment to have a time limit?",
    toggle the "No" option to "Yes" and choose the correct number of
    hours and/or minutes. Scroll down and click on "Save & Exit".\<br
    /\>![Time Limit Setting](Time%20Limit.jpg "Time Limit Setting")\<br
    /\>

## Only displaying one question per page {#only_displaying_one_question_per_page}

The default layout setting in Tests & Quizzes is to display one question
per page. This setting prevents students from capturing all questions in
an exam at once.

To access the one question per page setting:

1.  Navigate to the Tests & Quizzes tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Click on the "Select Action" menu next to the assessment and click
    on "Settings".
3.  Click on the "Layout" tab.
4.  Under the "How any questions should be displayed per page?", select
    the radio button next to "One question per page (Recommended).
    Scroll down and click on "Save & Exit".\<br /\>![Question Per Page
    Setting](One%20Question%20Per%20Page.jpg "Question Per Page Setting")\<br
    /\>

## Use question pools {#use_question_pools}

Instructors can build question pools in their assessments to ensure that
each student receives a different set of questions (ex: each student
randomly gets 10 of 20 question pool). This is a more advanced feature
and requires more questions to be constructed by the instructor, but you
can easily set Isidore up to give each student a random subset of those
questions.

Please see [ our full guide and video](Add_a_Question_Pool "wikilink")
for creating question pools.

## Deliver group-specific exams {#deliver_group_specific_exams}

Sometimes, you may have a test that requires a specific sequence of
questions that cannot be randomized. If this is the case, you can set up
two different exams that have similar, but slightly different variations
of those sequenced questions. Then, use the [feature in
Isidore](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Manage_Groups#Creating_groups_automatically_.28by_role.29%7Cauto-groups)
to randomly divide your students into separate groups. Release one
version of the test to one group, release the other version of the test
to the other group.

## Hide feedback until after the due date {#hide_feedback_until_after_the_due_date}

Instructors can hide a student's overall score, their ability to see the
correct answers, and even review the questions they answered on an
assessment after they submit their assessment until after the due
date/time.

This prevents a student from taking a test and then sharing the correct
answers with their classmates while the assessment window is still open.

## Limit access to a specific time window {#limit_access_to_a_specific_time_window}

Instructors can limit how long a test is available to a class. While
it's generally not a great idea to be very rigid with your time windows
(ex: 10-11 AM on Tuesday only), it's also not a great idea for exams to
be available for extremely long periods of time if you're worried about
cheating. Think about selecting a 1-3 day time period for your students
to take an assessment (while also setting a time limit). This gives them
some flexibility to take it when it best fits their schedule, but also
doesn't keep it open for such a long period of time that sharing answers
becomes extremely easy for a class. \<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main
[Tests and Quizzes](Tests_and_Quizzes "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="1264" sha1="cd95agzun9qgdvcra4jy7syijglco8h" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`You must submit artifacts to requirements to progress through the completion of the portfolio.`

To submit an artifact:

1.  Navigate to the **CompFolio** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  On the **Home** page of CompFolio, you will see a list of
    categories. On the right hand side of each category are a series of
    colored boxes with numbers, each of which refers to the number of of
    requirements in the category as well as indicators of their
    statuses. Click on a category with a number other than 0 in the
    blue, or Ready, box.
3.  Next to each requirement, you will see its status. Find a
    requirement that has the status of Ready, then click on it.
4.  A popup will appear where you can upload artifacts from your
    computer to submit. Press the **Browse** button to find the
    artifacts on your computer.
5.  Once you have attached your submission, click on the **Submit**
    button to submit the requirement.
6.  You will then be taken to the requirement page where you can see a
    bar indicating that you have successfully submitted the requirement.
    The requirement\'s status has been updated to \"Submitted.\" Your
    instructor will now evaluate your submission and either reopen or
    complete the requirement.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [CompFolio](CompFolio "wikilink") page

### Step 2: Copy the link to your video {#step_2_copy_the_link_to_your_video}

To retrieve the link for your video:

1.  From the **Warpwire Video** tool, locate the video you recorded or
    uploaded.
2.  Click on the 3 dots within a circle button (Media Asset Options) and
    select **Share**.
3.  If you want to link to your video, click on **Copy** next to the
    share link. If you wish to embed your video, click on **Embed Code**
    and then click **Copy**.
4.  Once you\'ve clicked copy, click on the **x** to close the window.

### Step 3: Add your video and submit the assessment {#step_3_add_your_video_and_submit_the_assessment}

To start an assessment that requires a video submission from within
Tests & Quizzes:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Click on the title of the assessment you wish to take.
3.  Read the instructions that are displayed on the screen.
4.  Click on **Begin Assessment**.
5.  You will first see a plain text editor. To open up the rich-text
    editor (and access Warpwire) click on **Show Rich-Text Editor (and
    character count)**.
6.  If you wish to link to your video, paste the link into the text box,
    highlight it, and click on the \"Link\" icon in the editor. Paste
    the link to the video into the URL box and click on **OK**. If you
    wish to embed your video, click on the **Source** button in the
    editor, paste in the embed code, and click on the **Save** button.
7.  Continue taking the assessment.
8.  When you are ready to submit your assessment, click **Submit for
    Grading** at the bottom.
9.  A submission warning page will appear. Click **Submit for Grading**
    to confirm your submission.
10. A review page of your submission will appear. Click **Continue**.
    You will be taken back to the Assessments home page.

`     ``<text bytes="3420" sha1="b4l5cdh258dp1qoxhh8esymd6ub127l" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`The Summer Online website provides information about all courses offered online during the summer at UD. It is designed to help students easily browse and search for online classes. Below are answers to some frequently asked questions about this website. `

**NOTE: Online courses on the 2U platform are not listed on this page.**

### FAQs for Instructors {#faqs_for_instructors}

**How do I add or edit information about my class?**\<br/\> Some
information on this website can be modified by instructors, and other
information must be modified by the Registrar\'s Office. \<br/\> The
following fields can be modified by instructors:

-   Why should someone take your course?
-   How will this course operate?
-   Technologies/Activities used in this course
-   Instructor biography
-   Instructor image
-   Course trailer or introductory video

To add or edit this information, follow the steps below:

1.  Login with your UD credentials at
    <https://isidore.udayton.edu/summeronline/>.
2.  To edit course information, click on the **My Courses** button.
3.  You will see a list of the courses for which you are the instructor
    of record. Click on the **Edit** button next to the course you\'d
    like to modify.
    -   \'\'\'If you do not see a course you are teaching, contact your
        administrative assistant, your Chair, or the Registrar\'s Office
        so they can make you the instructor of record for the class.
4.  Fill in or edit the fields for your class.
5.  Click **Save**.
6.  To edit your biographical information, click on the **My Info**
    button.
7.  Fill in or edit the fields.
8.  Click **Save**.
    -   If you change your picture, it may take a few minutes for the
        picture to change on your end due to browser caching. Changing
        your picture here will also change your picture within Isidore.
        \<br/\>

All other course information such as course description, meeting times,
attributes, etc. can only be modified in Banner. Contact your
administrative assistant, your Chair, or the Registrar\'s Office to
learn more about changing the course details. \<br/\>

**I don\'t see the course(s) I\'m teaching. Where is it?**\<br/\> There
are a few reasons you might not see your courses:

-   The most likely reason is that you\'re not listed as the instructor
    of record for the course. Contact your administrative assistant,
    your Chair, or the Registrar\'s Office so they can make you the
    instructor of record for the class.
-   Another reason could be that you\'re not the primary instructor for
    the course. For courses that are taught by multiple instructors,
    only the primary instructor can modify the course information.
-   There are also some classes that are intentionally **not** displayed
    in the table. Early Launch Program courses and courses with a
    capacity of 0 might not display on this website.

### FAQs for Students {#faqs_for_students}

**How can I share classes?** \<br/\> You must first be logged in to
share classes. Click on the Log In button in the top right corner to
login with your UD credentials. Locate the **Share** button next to any
class you\'d like to share with others. Add the person\'s email address,
write your message, and press Send.

**How can I bookmark classes?** \<br/\> You must first be logged in to
share classes. Click on the Log In button in the top right corner to
login with your UD credentials. Locate the **Bookmark** button next to
any class you\'d like to add to your bookmarks. See your bookmarked
courses by clicking on the **My Courses** button in the top right
corner.`</text>`{=html}

-   the Center for Online Learning for Isidore support or to request new
    features.

## Take attendance for an existing item {#take_attendance_for_an_existing_item}

1.  Select an existing attendance item from the **Attendance** tab.
2.  You will be taken to a page where you can see your list of students
    in the **Take Attendance** table.
3.  For each student, you have the option of selecting one of the
    following statuses: Present, Absent, Excused, Late, or Left Early.
    To mark all students as a status, click on the **Choose One**
    drop-down menu and select a status. Then you can adjust individual
    students\' attendance statuses by clicking on the appropriate icon
    next to their names.
    -   *Once you have selected a status for a student, the attendance
        record will save automatically.*
4.  You also have the option to leave a comment by clicking on the
    **comment bubble** next to a student\'s name.
5.  Click the refresh icon next to the **Attendance Item Statistics**
    box to see the statistics update based on the new attendance
    records.

## Take attendance using the Take Attendance Now button {#take_attendance_using_the_take_attendance_now_button}

1.  Click the **Take Attendance Now** button above the table on the
    **Attendance** tab.
2.  Isidore will automatically create an attendance item for the date
    and time when you clicked the button.
3.  For each student, you have the option of selecting one of the
    following statuses: Present, Absent, Excused, Late, or Left Early.
    Then you can adjust individual students\' attendance statuses by
    clicking on the appropriate icon next to their names.
    -   *Once you have selected a status for a student, the attendance
        record will save automatically.*
4.  You also have the option to leave a comment by clicking on the
    **comment bubble** next to a student\'s name.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [Attendance](Attendance "wikilink") page

`     ``<text bytes="2529" sha1="tidykasul9ga6ha3n3g3pxrdrxjpnvl" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`The Online Learning template site emphasizes consistency and organization through date-released, week-by-week pages where instructors can add content for each week. The template site also includes all the tools we think are necessary to facilitate student success and satisfaction.`

## Template Site Overview {#template_site_overview}

For a brief overview of what is included in the template site, please
watch this 4 minute video from our training package or read the
description of each tool below.

-   **Overview**: The landing page for your course site has been
    configured to give students the most important information they need
    for your class. Specifically, the Homepage Builder tool on the
    Overview provides a spot for instructors to enter standard
    information for their course, such as meeting times, course
    description, syllabus, and schedule. The tool creates a standardized
    homepage that displays important class information to students and
    creates a consistent experience across all course sites.
-   **Announcements**: We suggest using this tool to communicate with
    students at least on a weekly basis. All Announcements are also sent
    to the students' UD email accounts.
-   **Calendar**: Students rely on an up-to-date calendar to keep track
    of the important dates for your class.
-   **Lessons**: The Lessons tool is pre-configured with templated
    weekly pages where you will add all instructions, tasks, and
    resources that students need for each week.
-   **Assignments**: Use this tool to electronically collect and grade
    students' written work.
-   **Gradebook**: A centralized location for all course grades.
-   **Zoom Meetings**: Use this tool for live lectures and synchronous
    activities.
-   **Warpwire Video**: Use this tool to upload pre-recorded lectures.
    You can also configure this tool to allow students to upload their
    own video presentations.
-   **Roster**: Contact information and pictures for everyone in your
    course.

## Template Site FAQs {#template_site_faqs}

-   **How can I import content from previous semesters into the template
    site?** \<br/\>

Watch this [3 minute video](https://udayton.warpwire.com/w/e-YBAA/) to
learn how to import content. \<br/\>

-   **I am teaching as part of a program where my Isidore sites are
    created for me. Do I need to do anything?**\<br/\>

No. All pre-existing program sites will be created as has been done in
the past.

-   **Will you be offering training about how to use this template
    site?** \<br/\>

Please check our training page for any upcoming training sessions and
all pre-recorded training sessions. \<br/\>`</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="2053" sha1="okhbppc9ewmjphlzai6lkln39pni0dt" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`When thinking about text content, you need to consider individuals who use screen readers, have trouble perceiving colors, and have visual impairments. `

The addition of titles and headings help those using screen readers, and
help all readers by visibly placing text into manageable chunks or
blocks. A properly formatted title can introduce the topic of a page of
information. Headings help readers know how to navigate around a page.
They can jump to a specific section of the page instead of listening to
all of the text on the page.

WebAIM provides a great [Contrast
Checker](https://webaim.org/resources/contrastchecker/) so you can see
if the background and text colors contain enough contrast for those who
experience visual impairments.

## Best Practices for Formatting Text {#best_practices_for_formatting_text}

Here are some tips for making text accessible:

-   Use good contrast, preferably black text on a white background.
-   Use a font that is sans serif (a font without the little lines at
    the end of letters and numbers) and easy to read.
-   Avoid red-green and blue-yellow color combinations.
-   Use bold, italics, or underlines, instead of color, to indicate
    meaning.
-   Use a font size of 12 pt or bigger.

## Titles

To format text as a title:

1.  Navigate to where the text is stored and flip into edit mode.
2.  Highlight the text you wish to format as a title.
3.  Click on the \"Styles\" drop-down menu and select \"Italic Title\".
4.  Your text should now be formatted as a title.
5.  Save your changes.

![How to Format a Title](Making_a_Title.gif "How to Format a Title")

## Headings

To format text as a heading:

1.  Navigate to where the text is stored and flip into edit mode.
2.  Highlight the text you wish to format as a heading.
3.  Click on the \"Normal\" drop-down menu and select \"Heading 3\" or
    some other heading you wish to use.
4.  Your text should now be formatted as a heading.
5.  Save your changes.

![How to Make Headings](Making_Headers.gif "How to Make Headings") \<br

accessible](Making_content_and_media_accessible "wikilink") page

-   A thread is a message
-   A reply is a response to a message

`     ``<text bytes="1207" sha1="26afqcdnkveu3vwnorr2ir4ec149xrh" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Warpwire Video is designed to be easy and simple to use. However, the tips below will ensure you have the best possible experience using this tool.`

-   Make sure you are in area with stable internet. If you begin
    uploading a video and the internet drops for even a second, the
    upload process will terminate and you will need to begin again.
-   Make sure Adobe Flash is installed for your browser. Check to make
    sure your flash player is installed in your browser
    [here](https://get.adobe.com/flashplayer/).
-   If you record your video on your phone, be aware that smart phones
    by default record high quality videos. A high quality video of 10
    minutes will be a large file. Temporarily change your camera's
    resolution in your phone\'s settings to create a smaller size video
    that will take less time to upload.
-   If you are having trouble embedding the video, you can retrieve the
    link to the video which you can share with anyone in your class. To
    retrieve the link, click on the three ellipses next to the video in
    the Warpwire Tool, then select Share to retrieve a link that you can
    copy and paste into any text editor in Isidore.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Warpwire
Video](Warpwire_Video "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

## FAQs for Instructors {#faqs_for_instructors_1}

**How many tokens should be issued for the semester?**\<br /\>The
recommended amount of tokens issued per semester is about 5. Most token
economies consist of issuing 5-10 tokens to students.

**What does an example token economy look like?**\<br /\>[View an
example token economy](View_an_example_token_economy "wikilink")

**Do you have an example of a Tokens policy I can add to my
syllabus?**\<br /\>[View a sample Tokens
policy](View_a_sample_Tokens_policy "wikilink")

**Do students receive email notifications about tokens requests?**\<br
/\>Yes, students receive email notifications when they request to use a
token, as well as when an instructor accepts or rejects a token request.

**Do instructors receive email notifications when students request to
use tokens?**\<br /\>Yes, instructors receive email notifications when
students request to use their tokens (by default). However, there is a
setting to opt-out of these notifications.

**If a student has gone above and beyond in some manner, can I award
them additional tokens?**\<br /\>Yes, you can select specific students
to award additional tokens. [Learn
more](Give_Specific_Students_Additional_Tokens "wikilink") \<br /\>\<br
/\> `</text>`{=html}

## One-on-One Training {#one_on_one_training}

We are always happy to provide one-on-one help. Below are a few of the
one-on-one training options available:

-   **Option 1:** For quick questions, we recommend calling or emailing
    us at 937-229-5039 or
    [onlinelearning@udayton.edu](mailto://onlinelearning@udayton.edu).
    We will get back to you quickly within business hours.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```
-   **Option 2:** Online Learning offers daily one-on-one appointments
    on our appointment calendar. Feel free to [sign-up for an
    appointment](https://calendar.google.com/calendar/u/0/selfsched?sstoken=UU1zVmFjWno1Q1NvfGRlZmF1bHR8YTQwZGM0NGY4NDRiODlmM2I0NmYxZDI2OWFhMDUwMzk)
    during our blocked off times, or email us at
    [onlinelearning@udayton.edu](mailto://onlinelearning@udayton.edu)
    for a time that works for you.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```
-   **Option 3:** For longer, more involved questions or discussions, we
    recommend submitting a [consultation request
    form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScMUNrbmr8RkVl4Xa2ImYNUEweq2l9ieLdvkSsDJvAnenMsyw/viewform?usp=sf_link).
    Once you submit the request, someone from Online Learning will set
    up an appointment with you to discuss your questions.

## Group Training {#group_training}

Group training sessions can be beneficial because you get to connect
with other faculty members who may have questions you hadn\'t previously
thought of. We\'ve had many faculty share feedback that they enjoy
getting the chance to learn from and with each other in the group
training sessions.

-   **Option 1:** Most semesters, Online Learning runs a series of group
    training sessions on different days and times. The training schedule
    for any given semester will be posted below.
    -   **Isidore Site Creation and Updating Your Sites**- Tuesday, May
        11 at 10 AM: If you\'re not sure where to get started with
        updating and creating your Isidore sites, this is the session
        for you! We\'ll review the different options for creating
        Isidore sites and help you select which option best meets your
        needs. We\'ll also help faculty who are duplicating existing
        sites figure out what needs to be updated for the next term and
        guide you through that process.
    -   **Zoom and Warpwire** - Wednesday, May 12 at 3 PM: These two
        tools handle video content in different ways. Come to this
        session to learn more about when, why, and how to use each of
        these tools.
    -   **Assignments and Tests & Quizzes** - Thursday, May 13 at 2 PM:
        The Assignments and Tests & Quizzes tools in Isidore are the
        most commonly used assessment tools for online classes. During
        this session, we\'ll guide you through the basics of how to use
        each tool, and some tips to speed up your grading.
    -   **Tips and Tricks in Isidore** - Friday, May 14 at 11 AM: There
        are many overlooked features in Isidore that can help
        instructors speed up their grading and make the online
        components of their classes more engaging. Come try them out
        yourself at this session!

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```
-   **Option 2:** Online Learning can deliver training sessions tailored
    to your specific group. Most commonly, Chairs of departments ask an
    Online Learning staff member to join a monthly departmental meeting
    to provide training on a specific topic or a general update on new
    Isidore / ed tech features. However, we\'re also happy to join just
    a small group of you and your colleagues to discuss whatever topic
    you want. To schedule this kind of group training session, please
    email
    [onlinelearning@udayton.edu](mailto://onlinelearning@udayton.edu) or
    complete [the Online Learning consultation request
    form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScMUNrbmr8RkVl4Xa2ImYNUEweq2l9ieLdvkSsDJvAnenMsyw/viewform?usp=sf_link).

## Asynchronous Training {#asynchronous_training}

Asynchronous training is designed so that you can complete it on your
own time at your own pace. You can also re-watch these training programs
over and over again as needed.

-   **Option 1:** There are several asynchronous training modules
    available on our LEARN training platform at \[learn.udayton.edu\]:
    -   [1](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons/templatesites-gettingstarted):
        A 60-minute module designed to help you understand, modify, and
        best use the components of template Isidore sites.
    -   [I\'m Brand New! What Do I
        Do?](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons#onboarding): A 15 minute
        training module for those who are completely new to Isidore or
        need a refresher of the basics.
    -   [Isidore 101](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons#isidore101): A
        45 minute training module about the most commonly used tools in
        Isidore.
    -   [Accessibility](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons#accessibility):
        A 35 minute training module reviewing the concepts of digital
        accessibility and how to make your classes accessible for all
        learners.
    -   [Zoom Video
        Conferencing](https://learn.udayton.edu/lessons#zoom): A 20
        minute training module about the basics of using Zoom, as well
        as some strategies for teaching with Zoom.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```
-   **Option 2:** We have recorded versions of our previously offered
    \"in-person\" training sessions that you may watch below:
    -   **Developing Your Template Site**: An Online Learning staff
        member answered questions about how to add content to template
        sites prior to the Fall 2020 semester.
    -   **Personalizing and Enhancing Your Template Site**: An Online
        Learning staff member showed tips and tricks for enhancing
        Isidore template sites. UD students are here to learn from YOU.
        How can you show your expertise and knowledge through a website?
        How can you give your site that "UD feeling"? We'll discuss
        different strategies to achieve these goals.
    -   **Conducting an Engaging Zoom Session:** Teaching through Zoom
        is not the same as teaching in the classroom. In this session,
        an Online Learning staff member goes beyond the simple answer of
        "use Zoom breakout rooms" as a means to foster engagement with
        your students. And, we'll tell you the honest truth (you won't
        be able to engage everyone!) - and how to handle that.
    -   **Video, Video, Video**: All your questions about video,
        answered. In this session, an Online Learning staff member
        explained the differences between the recommended video capture
        and streaming platforms, and covered best practices on how to
        record different kinds of videos.
    -   **Course Communications**: How many emails are too many?
        Probably fewer than you'd think. Whether you're teaching
        face-to-face or online, it's a fine line to walk between too few
        and too many communications. During these sessions, an Online
        Learning staff member provided guidance on best practices and
        some ideas for other ways to engage with students that don't
        involve email.
    -   **Crafting and Facilitating Effective Forum Discussions:**
        Conducting a meaningful forum discussion is so much more
        difficult than it seems. During this session, and Online
        Learning staff member reviewed what makes a forum effective -
        and what doesn't. They also outline the instructor's role within
        a discussion, and how to quickly grade forums.
    -   **Hybrid Teaching - Part 1: Technology in the Classroom:**
        Hybrid teaching (with students in the classroom and online via
        Zoom) will be a powerful part of the flexible teaching
        approaches used this fall semester. This session explores what
        technologies can be used from the classroom to reach students in
        the room and online simultaneously.
    -   **Hybrid Teaching - Part 2: Active Learning and Assessment:**
        Hybrid teaching (with students in the classroom and online via
        Zoom) will be a powerful part of the flexible teaching
        approaches used this fall semester. This session focuses on how
        these synchronous meetings can be used to deepen learning
        through the use of active learning strategies. This session also
        reviews how to deliver assessments in a hybrid format.
    -   **Assessment Options in Isidore:** Best practices for developing
        a flexible assessment strategy are discussed in this session.
        The facilitator also demonstrates how to create and grade
        assessments within the Tests & Quizzes tool, while also
        highlighting features that can be used to diminish the chance of
        academic dishonesty. Assignments and Learning Apps are also
        demonstrated.`</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="3565" sha1="l9qoskkbo9gi56rbfdvbmcys33guiay" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Just like with any technology, some problems can happen. The most important thing is to stay calm and think through the steps to solve the issue. `

The Center for Online Learning can provide support for Zoom issues from
8:00 - 5:00 EDT, M-F. Call us at 937-229-5039 or email us at
[onlinelearning@udayton.edu](mailto://onlinelearning@udayton.edu).

You may also contact [Zoom
support](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/201362003) at
1-888-799-9666 ext 2 for assistance.

Below are some tips for troubleshooting issues related to Zoom.

## Zoom is not launching {#zoom_is_not_launching}

-   Review the [guide for installing the Zoom
    client](https://drive.google.com/open?id=1JK9vY6FfApozV-JQXA9ekawLeCkyaFhh)
    to make sure you have followed all the steps.
-   Make sure you are joining the right room. If it was a scheduled
    meeting, check the time the meeting was supposed to start and make
    sure you are joining at the right time.
-   Check [Zoom\'s status](https://status.zoom.us/) to check if
    everything is up and running.

## No record button! {#no_record_button}

This issue occurs when someone joins the room before the host does. Zoom
will assign the first person who joins the room as the host, even if
this person did not set up the meeting. To solve this issue, the host
should click on the \"Claim Host\" button at the bottom of the
participants list. The host will be prompted to enter a host key. To
find your host key:

1.  Click on the \"Sign In\" link at \[go.udayton.edu/zoom\]
2.  Click on the link to \"My Profile\"
3.  Scroll down to find the **Host Key**

For more help with this issue, please see [Zoom\'s
article](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/115001315866-Host-Key-Control-For-Zoom-Rooms).

## No recordings links! {#no_recordings_links}

Students access links to recordings via the \"Previous Meetings\" tab.
Sometimes, the links to the rooms do not NOT show up in this tab. We are
currently working with Zoom to resolve this issue. In the meantime,
instructors can share the links to the recordings with their students.
To do so:

1.  Navigate to the **Zoom Meetings** tool within Isidore
2.  Click on the **Cloud Recordings** tab
3.  Click on the title of the room whose recording you need to share
4.  Click on the **Share** link under the thumbnail of the recording
5.  Click on the **Copy** button in the popup window
6.  Paste the link in an email or Announcement to students

## No one can hear me! {#no_one_can_hear_me}

-   Make sure you are [not muted by checking the mic
    icon](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/201362173-Mute-And-Unmute)
    in the tool menu. If there\'s a slash through it, you are muted.
-   Make sure you have selected the correct mic on your device. Click on
    the arrow next to the mic icon on the tool menu to open the mic
    selection menu.
-   Make sure your mic is working by testing out your devices in the
    Zoom test room: <http://zoom.us/test>.
-   Check the invitation to see if there is a dial-in option. You may be
    able to use your phone to call in.
-   Check [additional Zoom audio troubleshooting
    advice](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/201362283-Testing-Computer-or-Device-Audio).

## No one can see me! {#no_one_can_see_me}

-   Make sure your webcam is turned on in Zoom.
-   Make sure you have selected the correct webcam on your device. Click
    on the arrow next to the webcam icon on the tool menu to open the
    webcam selection menu.
-   Make sure your webcam is working by testing out your devices in the
    Zoom test room: <http://zoom.us/test>.
-   Check [additional Zoom webcam troubleshooting
    advice](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/202952568-My-Video-Camera-Isn-t-Working).

`     ``<text bytes="2539" sha1="hhppiwzqabvfd30cfzqzz45t16p2hob" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Turnitin Originality is a service checks papers for originality against websites, student papers, periodicals, and journals. Feedback Studio is powerful grading and feedback software that allow instructors to assess student work online. Students upload their papers to Turnitin.com, and an originality report is returned to the instructor. The instructor is able to choose whether or not the originality report is displayed to students. The instructor may then grade and provide feedback to students via Feedback Studio using grading, commenting, audio, and/or rubrics.`

Turnitin may be used as an integration within Isidore\'s Assignments
tool or through Turnitin\'s website
([turnitin.com](http://www.turnitin.com)).

**Students cannot run their papers through Turnitin unless their
instructor has created a class and assignment.**

If you are an instructor who needs access to Turnitin.com, please
contact the Center for Online Learning via (937) 229-5039 or
<onlinelearning@udayton.edu> to get added to UD\'s Turnitin account.

`     ``<text bytes="1625" sha1="tl4k4930tqsxfsqips0xks7v24fsux3" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`==Understanding Isidore Roles==`

There are 5 predefined roles within Isidore sites. These roles may not
relate to the person\'s role at UD, they determine the level of
permissions and functionality the individual has in your Isidore site.
You may have more roles if you\'re utilizing a textbook company\'s
resources.

-   **Instructor** - can read/add/edit/delete content, grade, and manage
    participants
-   **SI Leader** - Supplemental Instruction Leader: can read content
    and post announcements
-   **Student** - can read content and submit assignments/assessments
-   **TA-Grading** - Teaching Assistant: can read content and grade in
    Assignments/Tests & Quizzes/Gradebook\<nowiki\>\*\</nowiki\>
-   **TA-Limited** - Teaching Assistant: can read content

*\<nowiki\>\*\</nowiki\>Note: Please note that if you want your TA to be
able to grade in Gradebook, you need to [give them permission to do so
in
Gradebook](https://ewiki.udayton.edu/isidore/Allow_my_TA_to_Grade).*\</br\>

## Best Practices for Using Roles {#best_practices_for_using_roles}

Please use extreme caution when adding someone with the \"Instructor\"
role. They will have complete access to your site, meaning they can add,
edit, or delete your content. They also have access to view, edit, and
change grade information in your course site.

[Read more about FERPA at the University of
Dayton](https://udayton.edu/fss/your_resources/your_forms/ferpa.php)

If you have any questions about roles or permissions, please contact us
via (937) 229-5039 or <onlinelearning@udayton.edu>. \<br /\>\<br /\>
Return to the main [Site Info](Site_Info "wikilink") page

If you see a *gray* \"play\" button next to a student\'s name in the
Roster tool, it means that they have not yet recorded a pronunciation of
their name through [NameCoach](What_is_NameCoach? "wikilink").

If you see a *purple* \"play\" button next to a student\'s name in the
Roster tool it means a student has recorded the proper pronunciation of
their name. You may press the play button to listen to the
[NameCoach](What_is_NameCoach? "wikilink") recording. \<br /\>\<br /\>
Return to the main [Roster](Roster "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

## How Course Grades are Calculated with a Points-Based Grading System {#how_course_grades_are_calculated_with_a_points_based_grading_system}

If you have not set up weighted categories in your Gradebook, you are
using a point-based grading system. With this setup, the Gradebook
calculates a student's overall course grade based on the number of
points earned out of the number of points possible. The course grade
only includes items that the instructor has specified to be included in
the course grade.

*It is important to note if a cell in the Gradebook is empty, it is not
included in the course grade calculation, which is why students' grades
make look inflated until the instructor enters zeros into the empty
cells for missing assignments and assessments (shown below).* \<br
/\>\<br /\> ![Students with Empty
Cells](Empty_Cells.png "Students with Empty Cells"){width="715"}

## How Course Grades are Calculated with a Weighted-Categories System {#how_course_grades_are_calculated_with_a_weighted_categories_system}

If you have set up weighted categories in your Gradebook, you are using
a weighted-category system. With this setup, the Gradebook calculates
the grade for each category (e.g. Homework, Tests, Participation) based
on the points available in the category. The grade for each category is
then multiplied by its weight (e.g. if a student earned a 90% in the
Assignments category, and the Assignments category is worth 10% of the
overall course grade, the calculation would be 90 \* .1). The final
grade is the sum of each of those weighted grades.

Below is an example of how the grade is calculated.

**Categories and Weights**

-   Homework category is worth 50% of overall course grade. This
    category is set to drop the one lowest score.
-   Participation category is worth 20% of overall course grade
-   Quiz category is worth 20% of overall course grade
-   Final Exam category is worth 10% of overall course grade
-   Extra Credit category is worth 2% **on top of** the overall course
    grade. This category is actually selected in the system as extra
    credit, so its calculation happens differently than the other
    categories\'.

Rose is a student in your class. Here is how her grade is calculated.

**Rose\'s Grades in Each Category**

-   With five 10-point homeworks in the Homework category, and one drop
    lowest, the denominator is 40 points. Rose earned 35 points. 35 / 40
    \* 100 = 87.5%.
-   With twenty 3-point items in the Participation category, and one
    extra credit item also worth 3 points, the denominator is 60 points.
    Because of the extra credit item, it is possible to earn a 63 /60.
    Rose earned 61 points. 61 / 60 \* 100 = 101.67
-   With two 30-point quizzes in the Quiz category, the denominator is
    60 points. Rose earned 40 points. 40 / 60 \* 100 = 67%
-   With one 10-point item in the Extra Credit category, the denominator
    is 10 points. Rose earned 6 points. 6 / 10 \* 100 = 60%
-   The final has not been graded yet, so it is not included in the
    course grade calculation. We\'ll handle this in a later step.

**Applying the Weights to each Category Grade**

-   The Homework category is worth 50% of the grade. We take Rose\'s
    87.5 in that category and multiply it by .5 to get the weight. 87.5
    \* .5 = 43.75
-   The Participation category is worth 20% of the grade. We take
    Rose\'s 101.67 in that category and multiply it by .2 to get the
    weight. 101.67 \* .2 = 20.334
-   The Quiz category is worth 20% of the grade. We take Rose\'s 67 in
    that category and multiply it by .2 to get the weight. 67 \* .2 =
    13.4
-   The Extra Credit category is worth 2% **on top of** the overall
    grade. We take Rose\'s 60 in that category and multiply it by .02 to
    get the weight. 60 \* .02 = 1.2

**Calculating the Final Grade**

First, we add the sums of all the weighted grades. We EXCLUDE the Extra
Credit category from this calculation.

`  43.75 + 20.3 + 13.4 = 77.5`

Because the Final Exam category has no grade, we need to divide this sum
by the sum of the weights that are being used. We EXCLUDE the Extra
Credit weight from this sum.

`  Sum of weights = .5 + .2 + .2 = .9`\
`  77.5 / .9 * 100 = 86.1`

Because the Extra Credit is calculated OUTSIDE of all the other weights,
we can now add the extra credit. To do this, we just need to add Rose\'s
weighted grade for the Extra Credit category to overall course grade.

`  86.1 + 1.2 = 87.3`

Rose\'s calculated course grade is 87.3.

## Enter Zeros in Empty Gradebook Cells all at Once {#enter_zeros_in_empty_gradebook_cells_all_at_once}

If it's the end of the semester and you want to quickly enter zeros in
all of the empty gradebook cells, you can follow these directions:

*Please note that there is no automatic "undo" for this action. These
steps should only be completed at the end of the semester when you're
trying to calculate final course grades.*

1.  In your Isidore course site, enter your Gradebook.
2.  Locate the "Course Grade" header.
3.  In the bottom right-hand corner of the "Course Grade" cell, click on
    the downward-facing arrow, and select "Set Zero Score for Empty
    Cells".
4.  Click on "Update".

![Setting Zero Scores All at
Once](Set_Zero_Score.png "Setting Zero Scores All at Once"){width="356"}

## Further Explanation & An Example {#further_explanation_an_example}

**Scenario:** In the example below Sara Jones has a 100% in the class
gradebook even though she has only completed one of the two assignments?
That can't be right, can it? How did the Course Grade column come up
with this number? \<br /\>\<br /\> ![Students with Inflated
Grades](Student_Inflated_Grade.png "Students with Inflated Grades"){width="716"}
\<br /\>\<br /\> **Explanation:** There's actually nothing wrong with
the gradebook in the image above. The gradebook doesn't count an item
towards the students' total points possible if there's an empty cell.
The gradebook simply assumes that Sara hasn't attempted this item yet,
thus it doesn't count it against her. That is also why the [Course Grade
percentage has been
hidden](Make_Grades_Available_to_Students "wikilink") from students by
default in each site -- so as not to mislead them.

Sara's grade should actually be a 50%. The instructor needs to put zeros
in the spots where empty cells are if the due date has passed. \<br
/\>\<br /\> ![Students with Entered
Zeros](Entered_Zero.png "Students with Entered Zeros"){width="716"} \<br
/\> *Note: The reason the Gradebook functions like this is to allow an
instructor to create their entire gradebook before the first day of
class, fill in grades as they occur throughout the semester, and always
have the Course Grade column display a current percentage.* \<br /\>\<br
/\> Return to main [Gradebook](Gradebook "wikilink") page

tool to assist them in delivering a better student experience. On the

student visited their course site and how many times a student has
visited their course site. Instructors may see their students\' photos

`     ``<text bytes="5008" sha1="j69vfveprkns7nsyzmtmu76elkqp4jp" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`When an Isidore site is duplicated semester-to-semester, there are a number of things you may want to update before making the course site live to students. `

## Isidore Updates {#isidore_updates}

Below is a list of items you may have in your site that need to be
updated. \<br/\>Please note that you might not be using all of these
features or tools, so feel free to skip over any that do not apply to
your sites. \<br/\>Please note that this list is not exhaustive.

#### Dates

There are many locations within Isidore where dates can be optionally
added or are required to be used. Making sure dates are updated wherever
you use them will help your students stay on track throughout the
semester. Many dates can be updated in bulk by using the [ Date
Manager](Use_Date_Manager "wikilink") tool, but below are a list of
locations where dates may be used.

-   Homepage Builder
    -   Class meeting times
    -   Course start and end Date
    -   Office hours
    -   Any schedule you have uploaded
    -   Any syllabus you have uploaded
-   Syllabus: Any syllabus or schedule you have added
-   Assignments: Open and due dates for each Assignment
-   Tests & Quizzes: Open and due dates for each Test / Quiz
-   Forums: Open and close dates for forums or topics
-   Lessons
    -   Date releases on subpages
    -   Dates on subpages (use the [Bulk Edit Subpages
        feature](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BTkREivbtYU) rather
        than the Date Manager tool to update these dates quickly)
    -   Important dates boxes
-   Zoom: Zoom meetings don\'t duplicate from site to site, but you will
    need to schedule new Zoom meetings for each class
-   Attendance: Attendance items don\'t duplicate from site to site, but
    you will need to add new Attendance items for any class where you
    want to take Attendance using this tool.

#### Outdated Videos {#outdated_videos}

One of the hardest things to do when creating videos for your class is
to remember the importance of shelf life. Videos can be time-consuming
to make, so we always recommend avoiding references to specific page
numbers, dates in the semester, etc. for any video that you\'d like to
use for more than one or two semesters.

Even if you\'re videos do reference things that don\'t apply for this
specific class, don\'t panic. It\'s not mandatory or even really
recommended that you re-shoot the video. Just add a bit of text above
wherever the video is located that corrects anything that needs to be
updated in the video. And, make a note of which videos do eventually
need to be updated so you can keep track for when you do have time.

We do recommend updating lecture videos every few years (usually at
least every 4 years) so that you can add the latest updates from the
industry, re-state any muddy points, or simply develop a higher quality
video.

#### Broken Links {#broken_links}

Anything you had uploaded to Isidore in your previous sites should have
copied over correctly to the new site. However, links to external
resources, like YouTube videos or news articles, should be checked
periodically to make sure they still work.

#### Unused Tools {#unused_tools}

Do you have tools in your course site that you are no longer using or
will never use? Students prefer to only see tools in the tool menu that
are actively being used in your class. Use the [Manage
Tools](Manage_Tools "wikilink") option within the Site Info tool to hide
or remove unused tools. Depending on how you\'re using them, here are
some tools you may want to hide or remove:

-   Check-In: This tool is usually used only for a limited time in the
    semester. Hide this tool until you\'re ready for students to use it.
-   Online MID: This tool is usually used only for a limited time around
    mid-semester. Hide this tool until you\'re ready for students to use
    it.
-   Resources: If you are using the Lessons tool to deliver course
    content, we recommend hiding the Resources tool so students don\'t
    have to look in two spots for their course materials.
-   Commons: Most instructors use the Commons widget on the Overview
    page for their class so it\'s the first thing students see when they
    access your course site. The Commons tool is just a duplicate of the
    Commons widget, so it\'s redundant to include it in the tool menu.
    We recommend removing this tool.

#### Course Review {#course_review}

The Online Learning staff are pros at checking through an Isidore site
and making sure it\'s all set to go. If you\'d like Online Learning to
review your course site, please complete our [Isidore Site Review
Request
form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSf6cSEp7BIoFIvIY90sBSy2w5MJs5b8yWJJ7pfNNj3rlWQOPw/viewform?usp=sf_link).

## Teaching Updates {#teaching_updates}

Teaching should be an iterative process where each semester you try to
make at least some small improvement. Before starting a new semester,
take some time to review your SET feedback, or even better, any feedback
you might have received from the Check-In tool or the Online MID tool.
Is there anything proactive you can address and improve before the
semester begins that will help students for the next go around?

Below are some suggestions of items you may want to examine.

## Adjust Dates Using the \"Shift By\" Feature {#adjust_dates_using_the_shift_by_feature}

The \"shift dates by\" feature allows you to bump all dates within your
site by a set number of days.

**NOTE:** This feature can only update dates that are set in the system,
not dates manually typed in by the user such as within assignment
instructions, page titles, etc. \<br/\>\<br/\>See a step-by-step video
of this process: \<br/\>\<youtube\>BWW14c1yKqI\</youtube\>

1.  If you haven't already done so, we recommend first following the
    [steps to duplicate your site](Site_Creation "wikilink") to the new
    semester.\</br\>\</br\>
2.  Navigate to the **Site Info** tool in your site and click on the
    **Date Manager** tab.\</br\>\</br\>
3.  Evaluate the existing dates in your site by expanding each tool to
    determine which dates you want to shift forward. You probably do
    **NOT** want to shift the dates for the Calendar or Announcements
    tools, but it would make sense to shift dates for Assignments, Tests
    & Quizzes, Lessons, and Forums. \</br\>\</br\>
4.  Determine the number of days to shift by.
    -   Find the earliest date in your class from the previous semester
        and match it to the equivalent date in the next semester. For
        example, if the first Lesson for the class opened on August
        23rd, 2021, I would then want the first Lesson for the class in
        the next semester to open on January 10th, 2022.
    -   Use the [date duration
        calculator](https://www.timeanddate.com/date/duration.html) to
        determine the number of days in between those two dates. Hint:
        do NOT select the \"Include end date in calculation\" option.

:   

    :   ![Steps to Calculate Number of Days using Date
        Calculator](DateDuration.png "Steps to Calculate Number of Days using Date Calculator")

1.  \<li value=\"4\"\>Once you have the number of days to shift by, make
    sure to expand only the tools to which you'd like to apply the date
    shift.\</br\>\</br\>
2.  Type in the number of days to shift by and click the "Apply to
    expanded sections only" button. \</br\>\</br\>

:   

    :   ![Using the Shift By
        Feature](ShiftBy.png "Using the Shift By Feature")

1.  \<li value=\"5\"\>Spot check a few dates to see if the dates shifted
    as you would expect. If the dates mostly look correct, press **Save
    Changes** at the bottom. If they do not, just press **Cancel**.
    \</br\>\</br\>
    -   **NOTE:** If it turns out your dates are not correct and you
        have already pressed Save Changes, you can \"undo\" the action
        by shifting the dates by putting a minus sign in front of the
        number (e.g. -140) and applying it. \</br\>\</br\>
2.  Fine-tune any dates that need to be adjusted to account for a
    different academic calendar. Refer to our [Module Date
    Planner](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/Module%20Date%20Planner-Summer2021-Spring2022.xlsx)
    to see all the dates for the semester.

\<br/\>

## Adjust Dates Manually {#adjust_dates_manually}

1.  Navigate to the **Site Info** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on the tool link to expand the section and view items within
    that tool.
3.  Click on the **calendar** icon to edit dates with the date picker by
    selecting year, then month, then day. Use the time sliders or **+**
    and **-** buttons to adjust times.
4.  You can update the dates of multiple tools at the same time.
5.  When you\'re done making changes, click on the **Save Changes**
    button near the bottom of the page.
6.  If the dates have been successfully updated, a confirmation message
    will be displayed on the screen.
    -   If some dates couldn\'t be updated, an error message will be
        displayed on the screen. Check the date and time format to make
        sure it\'s correct and click on **Save Changes** again. You may
        need to update these dates manually.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Site Info](Site_Info "wikilink")

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your course site.
2.  Locate the student\'s overall course grade you\'re wanting to
    override.
3.  Click on the downward-facing arrow in the bottom right of the course
    grade cell and select **Course Grade Override**.
4.  Enter a letter grade in the **Grade Override** column and click on
    **Save Course Grade Override**.
5.  The student\'s adjusted grade will now dispay in the **Course
    Grade** column.

*Note: You won\'t be able to enter grades for items coming from External
Tools (like Assignments or Tests & Quizzes), but quick entry will be
available for items created in the Gradebook.*

To access the quick entry tab:

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on the **Quick Entry** tab.
3.  Select a gradebook item.
4.  Use the form on the page to enter grades and comments.
    -   Move left and right through the table columns using the Tab key
        or the left and right arrow keys on your keyboard.
    -   Move up and down through the table rows using the Enter key or
        the up and down arrows on your keyboard.
    -   **Set Score For Empty Grades** allows you to apply a grade to
        all empty grade textboxes.
    -   **Fill Empty Comments** allows you to apply typed feedback
        comments to all empty comment textboxes.
5.  Click on the **Update** button near the bottom of the page to save
    your changes.

## Setting Up an Assignment with Rubric Grading {#setting_up_an_assignment_with_rubric_grading}

To setup an assignment for rubric grading:

1.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  You can either attach a rubric to an existing assignment by clicking
    on **Edit** or you can create a new assignment by clicking on
    **Add**.
3.  Enable grading by checking the box next to "Grade this assignment"
    in the "Grading" section.
4.  Ensure that "Grade Scale" is set to "Points", as this is the only
    grading scale that rubrics work with.
5.  Enter the maximum number of points the assignment is worth.
6.  Select the "Use the following rubric to grade this assignment"
    option and choose the rubric you wish to use to grade the
    assignment.
7.  Selecting the "Adjust individual student scores" option allows you
    to enter scores between the point value of your ratings. For
    example, if you have ratings Exceeds expectations = 2, Meets
    expectations = 1, Inadequate = 0, you could manually enter a 1.5 for
    an individual student.
8.  If you wish to hide the rubric from students, check the box next to
    that option.
9.  If you would like to send grades to the Gradebook, check the box
    next to that option.
10. Once you've completed adjusting the assignment settings, scroll down
    and click on **Post** at the bottom of the page.

## Grading an Assignment with Rubrics {#grading_an_assignment_with_rubrics}

Once students submit the assignment, you can review their submissions.
Additionally, you can complete a rubric for a student who has not yet
submitted the assignment.

1.  To review a students' assignments, navigate to the **Assignments**
    tool.
2.  Click on the **Grade** link beneath the assignment.
3.  Click on a student's name.
4.  Review their submitted text and/or attached file.
5.  Click on the **Grading Rubric** tab.
6.  Select a rating for each criterion by clicking in the appropriate
    cell and/or click on the comment bubbles to leave comments for each
    criterion. Students will be able to view these comments if you
    didn't select the option to hide it from them.
7.  The student's grade will be tallied automatically, and you may
    provide summative comments in the "Instructor Summary Comments" box.
8.  If you wish to include a file with your feedback, you may add an
    attachment.
9.  You can return students' feedback immediately by clicking on the
    **Save and Release to Student** button, or you can do so at a later
    time by clicking on the **Save and Don't Release to Student**
    button.
10. Once the assignment is released to students, they can review the
    rubric, scores, and feedback in both the Assignments tool and the
    Gradebook tool (if the assignment is sent to Gradebook, the
    gradebook item is visible to students, and you didn't select the
    "hide rubric from students" option).

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Rubrics](Rubrics "wikilink") page.

## Setting Up Forums/Topics with Rubric Grading {#setting_up_forumstopics_with_rubric_grading}

To setup a forum or topic with rubric grading:

1.  First, follow the steps on the [Use Rubrics in
    Gradebook](Use_Rubrics_in_Gradebook "wikilink") page to create a
    gradebook item (or edit an existing gradebook item) and attach a
    rubric to it.
2.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your Isidore course site.
3.  You can use a rubric to evaluate an existing topic or forum by
    clicking on **Topic Settings** or **Forum Settings**, respectively,
    or a new topic or forum by clicking on **New Topic** or **New
    Forum**, respectively.
4.  Scroll down and expand the "Grading" section of the settings page.
5.  Select a gradebook item to associate the topic or forum with. If by
    chance a newly created gradebook item doesn't show up in the list,
    you may need to click on the **Forums** heading at the top of the
    page to reset the tool, then open Topic Settings or Forum Settings
    again.
6.  You will not be able to change the rubric settings in this location,
    but can change them in the Gradebook tool.
7.  Click on the **Save** button.

## Grading Forums/Topics with Rubrics {#grading_forumstopics_with_rubrics}

To grade a students\' forum post with a rubric:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Click on the **Grade** link that can be found at the top of a
    student's post or to the right of the forum or topic title under
    "More".
3.  Select a rating for each criterion by clicking in the appropriate
    cell and/or click on the comment bubbles to leave comments for each
    criterion. Students will be able to view these comments if you
    didn't select the option to hide the rubric from students.
4.  The student's grade will be tallied automatically.
5.  Once you've completed your evaluation, click on **Submit Grade**.
6.  Students can review the rubric, scores, and feedback in the
    Gradebook tool if the gradebook item is visible to students and you
    didn't select the "hide rubric from students" option.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Rubrics](Rubrics "wikilink") page.

## Setting Up a Gradebook Item with Rubric Grading {#setting_up_a_gradebook_item_with_rubric_grading}

To setup a gradebook item for rubric grading:

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  You can either attach a rubric to an existing gradebook item by
    clicking on the **drop-down arrow** in the cell that contains the
    item name and selecting **Edit Item Details**, or you can create a
    new gradebook item by clicking on the **Add Gradebook Item** button
    and attach a rubric to the newly created item.
3.  Under the "Grading Rubric" section, select the "Use the following
    rubric to grade this assignment" option.
4.  Selecting the "Adjust individual student scores" option allows you
    to enter scores between the point value of your ratings. For
    example, if you have ratings Exceeds expectations = 2, Meets
    expectations = 1, Inadequate = 0, you could manually enter a 1.5 for
    an individual student.
5.  If you wish to hide the rubric from students, check the box next to
    that option.
6.  Click on **Save Changes** if you're editing an existing item, or
    click on **Create** if you're creating a new item.

## Grading a Gradebook Item with Rubrics {#grading_a_gradebook_item_with_rubrics}

To grade a student with a rubric in Gradebook:

1.  Once the rubric is attached to the gradebook item, you can use it to
    grade students' work.
2.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your Isidore site.
3.  Locate the gradebook row of the student you wish to grade.
4.  In the column of the gradebook item that has the rubric attached,
    click on the **drop-down arrow** and select **Grade Rubric**.
5.  Select a rating for each criterion by clicking in the appropriate
    cell and/or click on the comment bubbles to leave comments for each
    criterion. Students will be able to view these comments if you
    didn't select the option to hide the rubric from students.
6.  The student's grade will be tallied automatically.
7.  When you're done grading, click on **Save Rubric Grading**.
8.  Students can view the rubric, scores, and feedback in the Gradebook
    tool, if you didn't select the "hide rubric from students" option.
