## Setting Up an Assessment with Rubric Grading {#setting_up_an_assessment_with_rubric_grading}

To setup a Tests & Quizzes question with rubric grading:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  You can add a rubric to questions in an existing assessment by
    clicking on **Actions** \> **Edit**, or a new assessment by clicking
    on **Add**.
3.  Once you're in edit mode, you can modify existing questions by
    clicking on **Edit**, or add a new question by selecting a question
    type next to **Add Question**, to enable rubric grading.
4.  Scroll to where the "Grading Rubric" section is. If the section
    isn't displayed, then the question type does not support rubric
    grading.
5.  Select the "Use the following rubric to grade this assignment"
    option and select the rubric you wish to use.
6.  Selecting the "Adjust individual student scores" option allows you
    to enter scores between the point value of your ratings. For
    example, if you have ratings Exceeds expectations = 2, Meets
    expectations = 1, Inadequate = 0, you could manually enter a 1.5 for
    an individual student.
7.  If you wish to hide the rubric from students, check the box next to
    that option.
8.  Click on **Save**.
9.  Proceed with adjusting the settings and publishing the assessment as
    you normally would.

## Grading an Assessment with Rubrics {#grading_an_assessment_with_rubrics}

Once students begin submitting the assessment, you'll be able to
evaluate their responses with the grading rubric.

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore site.
2.  To access the grading rubric, select **Actions** \> **Scores** next
    to the assessment you want to grade.
3.  You can either grade an individual student by clicking on their name
    and locating the question containing the rubric, or you can click on
    the **Questions** tab and click on the question number that contains
    the rubric to grade all students' responses at once.
4.  If you elected to grade all students via the "Questions" tab, click
    on the rubric icon in the "Scores" column.
5.  If you've elected to grade an individual student's submission, click
    on the **Grading Rubric** tab to bring up the grading rubric.
6.  Select a rating for each criterion by clicking in the appropriate
    cell and/or click on the comment bubbles to leave comments for each
    criterion. Students will be able to view these comments if you
    didn't select the option to hide the rubric from students.
7.  The student's grade will be tallied automatically.
8.  Once you've completed your evaluation, click on **Update**. If
    you're grading an individual student's submission, you may need to
    scroll to the bottom of the page to locate the "Update" button. If
    you're grading all students via the "Questions" tab, you'll need to
    click on **Save**.
9.  Students can review the rubric, scores, and feedback in the Tests &
    Quizzes tool (if question-level feedback is enabled in assessment
    settings, and you didn't select the "hide rubric from students"
    option).

## Statistics by participant {#statistics_by_participant}

To view statistics for site participants:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Click **Statistics & Grading**.
3.  You\'ll see the participant list followed by columns showing the
    statistics by user, namely, \"Authored\", \"Read\", \"Unread\", and
    \"Percent Read\".\<br /\>*Note: To sort by a particular column,
    click the column heading.*
4.  Click a participant\'s name to see the following individual
    statistics:
    -   **Messages Authored**: Lists the titles of the forums and topics
        of all posts authored by the participant, the date and time they
        were created, the subject and the word count
    -   **Messages Read**: Lists the titles of the forums and topics of
        all posts read, the date and time they were read, and the
        subject
5.  To review the content of all of a particular participant\'s posts at
    once, from the list of messages authored, click **Show Full Text for
    All Authored Messages**.\<br /\>You can also grade the post and see
    an individual posting in context by clicking **\[display in
    conversation\]**.\<br /\>To go to the next or previous participant,
    click the appropriate button above the text of the authored
    messages.
6.  Click **Forums** to return to the Forums page.

## Statistics by topic {#statistics_by_topic}

To view statistics for each forum topic:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your Isidore site.
2.  Click **Statistics & Grading**.
3.  Click **Statistics & Grading by Topic**, which lists the forums with
    columns labeled \"Topic Title\", \"Date\", and \"Total
    Messages\".\<br /\>**Note**: To sort by a particular column, click
    the column heading.
4.  Click a forum or topic title to see more detailed information.
    You\'ll see a list of participants who have contributed to the forum
    or topic, followed by columns labeled \"Authored\", \"Read\",
    \"Unread\", and \"Percent Read\". To see the individual statistics
    for a participant (as described above), click **Details**. To grade
    a participant, click **Grade**, and select a gradebook item. (For
    more, see [Grading Forum
    Postings](Grading_Forum_Postings "wikilink").)

\<br /\>\<br /\>Return to main [Forums](Forums "wikilink") page

The best part about using TurnItIn through Isidore is that neither you
nor your students need to setup or maintain an account with TurnItIn.
Isidore does all of the communication with TurnItIn for you. If you've
used TurnItIn before you no longer need to visit their website to create
sites or have assignments checked. \_\_TOC\_\_

## Enabling Turnitin in Isidore\'s Assignments tool {#enabling_turnitin_in_isidores_assignments_tool}

1.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **Add**.
3.  Fill in the assignment title and instructions.
4.  If you would like students to acknowledge the honor pledge before
    submitting their work, check the box next to \"Add honor pledge\".
5.  If you would like to add attachments to the assignment that contains
    instructions or a template to complete the assignment, click on the
    **Add Attachments** button, browse to where the files are located,
    and upload the files.
6.  Set the open date, due date, and accept until date by clicking on
    the calendar and selecting a date. Once a date is selected, adjust
    the time by either using the slider or the minus and plus icons. The
    open date is when students will be able to see the assignment and
    begin submitting it. The accept until date is a date that students
    won\'t see, but allows them to submit their assignments late.
    Assignments submitted after the due date will be flagged as late.
7.  Set advanced date options, such as hiding the due date from students
    (not recommended), adding the due date to the calendar (only shown
    if the Calendar tool is installed), and/or adding an announcement
    about the open date to announcements (only shown if the
    Announcements tool is installed). If you enable the announcements
    option, you\'ll be able to choose whether to send an email
    notification about the open date to all participants.
8.  In the \"Assign To\" section, the settings allow you to select
    different options, such as individual assignments or group
    assignments.
    -   Assigning an assignment to each individual member of the site is
        the most frequently used option. This means that each student
        will submit their own assignment.
    -   Assigning an assignment to each individual member of the
        selected group(s) is used if you only want to assign an
        assignment to a specific group or section of students. Each
        student in the group or section will submit their own
        assignment.
    -   Assigning an assignment to the selected group(s), as a group
        assignment (one group member submits on behalf of the entire
        group) means that students are working in teams and only one
        student within that team will submit an assignment on behalf of
        the group.
9.  Submission type refers to the format of the student\'s submitted
    assignment.
    -   Attachments only is the most common type, where students can
        upload file attachment(s) for the instructor to review. Students
        may upload up to 5 file attachments per assignment.
    -   Inline means that students type or paste their assignment into a
        text box for the instructor to review.
    -   Inline and Attachments means that students can choose whether to
        upload a file attachment or type or paste their assignment into
        a text box.
    -   Non-electronic is used to provide assignment instructions, but
        students aren\'t expected to submit anything electronically. One
        use case might be bringing an article to class. Single file
        upload works just like the attachments type, but restricts the
        number of files students can upload to one.
10. If you would like students to be able to resubmit their assignment
    prior to the due date, you can enable the \"Allow Resubmission\"
    option. Once enabled, enter the number of resubmissions students are
    allowed to have and when those resubmissions should be due (usually
    the due date or before).
11. Enable Turnitin by clicking on the **Use Turnitin** option. By
    default, students are allowed to see their originality reports
    (recommended), but you can uncheck that option.
12. If you would like to grade anonymously, you can check the box next
    to \"Hide submitters\' identities (e.g. for anonymous grading)\".
    When grading, students\' names will be replaced with an alphanumeric
    code. This setting can be toggled back on at any time. Please note
    that if students include their name within their file attachment or
    the filename, you\'ll be able to see their identities.
13. The default setting is that assignments are set to be graded, but
    this can be turned off my unchecking the \"Grade this assignment\"
    box.
    -   If you\'re setting up a graded assignment, select a grading
        scale. Please note that \"Points\" is the only grading scale
        that works with Gradebook.
    -   Specify the maximum number of points.
    -   Enable rubric grading if you wish to use a rubric. For more
        assistance with rubric grading, please visit the
        [Rubrics](Rubrics "wikilink") page for step-by-step
        instructions.
    -   If you would like the assignment grades to be sent to the
        Gradebook, check the box to enable the setting. This setting
        only appears if you have the Gradebook tool installed.
    -   If you would like to setup peer review, check the box next to
        \"Use peer assessment\" and adjust the other settings. Please
        note that the start date for the peer review period is set to
        the assignment\'s accept until date.
14. Notification email options and additional information sections are
    expandable if you would like to adjust the notification settings and
    add items like a model answer.
15. Click on **Post** to save your assignment settings and make the
    assignment available to students at the specified open date and
    time.

## Reviewing Student TurnItIn Originality Reports {#reviewing_student_turnitin_originality_reports}

Once an assignment has been submitted it will be sent to TurnItIn to be
checked for plagiarism. An assignment can take anywhere from 15 minutes
to 24 hours to be reviewed in TurnItIn and returned to the Isidore
Assignments tool in your site.

1.  To review the reports you can click on the **Grade** link under the
    Assignment title.
2.  You'll see that a report is ready for your review when there's a
    flag icon under the **TurnItIn** column. Click on the flag icon next
    to the paper to open the Originality Report on TurnItIn's website.
    -   The color of the report icon indicates the similarity score of
        the paper, based on the amount of matching or similar text that
        was uncovered. The percentage range is 0% to 100%. The possible
        similarity ranges are:
        -   Blue: No matching text
        -   Green: One word to 24% matching text
        -   Yellow: 25-49% matching text
        -   Orange: 50-74% matching text
        -   Red: 75-100% matching text

-   **Please note that students\' submitted documents must be more than
    20 words for Turnitin to accept for review.**
-   **Please note that originality reports take at least 24 hours to be
    viewable for resubmission assignments.**
-   [View Instructor Guide for Interpreting Similarity Reports
    (PDF)](https://isidore.udayton.edu/access/content/public/eWiki%20Resources/Instructor%20Guide_Interpreting%20the%20Similarity%20Report.pdf)
-   [View Turnitin\'s online help for Interpreting Similarity
    Reports](https://help.turnitin.com/feedback-studio/turnitin-website/instructor/instructor-category.htm#TheSimilarityReport)

## Student View {#student_view}

If you've allowed students to review their Originality Reports they will
see a similar icon on the page where they submitted their work. They can
click on the flag icon to view their report on TurnItIn's website.

Note: If you didn't allow students to review their Originality reports
when you created the assignment you can go back in, edit the assignment,
and turn on that option for after the reports have been created and
you've reviewed them.

## How Turnitin Works {#how_turnitin_works}

It's important to review each Originality Report carefully -- just
because the similarity index number is high doesn't necessarily mean the
paper has been plagiarized. It's up to you as the instructor to review
the report and determine whether plagiarism has actually occurred.
TurnItIn will simply find matches of groups of text and show those to
you. It could very well be that student simply hasn't cited text
properly which makes it appear as copied.

TurnItIn looks for text matches of 7 words or more in three separate
areas:

-   Previously submitted papers to TurnItIn
-   Current and archived sites on the Internet
-   Collection of periodicals and journals -- some but not all

**Please note that originality reports take at least 24 hours to be
viewable for resubmission assignments.** \<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main

`     ``<text bytes="1053" sha1="t29v0de1l8rg6gkrnifi0sqc0639lap" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`To use your tokens:`

1.  Navigate to the **Tokens** tool in your Isidore site.
2.  View your token balance and the categories of items and associated
    cost you\'re eligible to use your tokens on. If a category is
    disabled, then you may not have enough tokens to cover the request.
3.  To make a request, click on the category of item you want to use
    your tokens on.
    -   Enter some comments that will be helpful for your instructor to
        have when reviewing your request. If you\'re using tokens to
        miss a class, enter the date of the missed class. If you\'re
        using tokens on an assignment, include the name of the
        assignment you would like to use your tokens on.
    -   Click on **Submit**.
4.  Click on **Confirm**.
5.  Click on **Done**.
6.  You will receive an email notification that your request to use
    tokens has been submitted.
7.  Your instructor will approve or deny your request and you will be
    notified of their decision by email. You may also check the status
    of the request through the Tokens tool.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Tokens](Tokens "wikilink") page
`</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="1497" sha1="ds0ypfb5o09emmv3yx7p4slesu46w5w" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`The notifications feature is available from anywhere in Isidore once you're logged in. Look for the white bullhorn icon near the top of the screen. If you have new notifications, there will be a red number alert next to the white bell that shows you how many new notifications you have. If you don't have any new notifications or you've cleared all notifications, the red number alert will disappear. If you click on the bullhorn icon, all of your notifications will be displayed in the notifications drop-down menu. You may dismiss an individual notification by clicking on the "x" icon next to it or you can clear all notifications by clicking on the `**`Clear All`**` link near the bottom of the notifications list. `

Please keep in mind that there is not a way to retrieve notifications
once they\'re dismissed or cleared.

Currently, the only events that trigger notifications are listed below.

#### Notifications for Students {#notifications_for_students_1}

-   A message or reply is received from the Messages tool
-   An announcement is posted in the Announcements tool
-   An assignment opens in the Assignments tool
-   An assignment reminder 24 hours before the due date in the
    Assignments tool
-   Assignment grade and feedback are returned in the Assignments tool

#### Notifications for Instructors {#notifications_for_instructors_1}

-   An announcement is posted by a co-instructor in the Announcements
    tool
-   A message or reply is sent to them from the Messages tool

[Notifications](Notifications "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

`     ``<text bytes="1070" sha1="5jryyvk5f3ylwsdgbsnq0s1548ij0xe" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`If you are an instructor who would like to live broadcast to your students follow these instructions:`

1.  Go into your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on the **Warpwire Video** tool in the course tool menu.
3.  Click on the **+** button.
4.  Select **Screen Capture** from the drop down menu.
5.  Click on the **Launch Warpwire Screen Capture** button.
6.  Give the app permission to open. If you\'re using Chrome, you may
    need to download a plug-in before it works.
7.  Select whether you\'ll be sharing your **Entire Screen** or a
    **Specific Window**.
8.  Give the app permission to use audio.
9.  Select your audio source (preferably a headset if you have one).
    Click on the **camera** button (record) to begin recording.
10. Complete your screen capture.
11. Return to the Warpwire recording window and click on the **camera**
    button to stop recording.
12. Enter a title for your recording and click on **Save**.
13. The screen capture will be ready for your to play after it\'s
    finished processing.

`     ``<text bytes="1724" sha1="dx5k0zdyngezcpohaab2jb6zc01zklm" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`The Book a Librarian Service allows faculty, staff, and students to schedule appointments with librarians for assistance with research.`

[Learn More About Roesch Library\'s
Services](https://udayton.edu/libraries/help.php)

To book an appointment with a librarian:

1.  Navigate to the **Home** page in Isidore.
2.  Click on the **Book a Librarian** tool in the tool menu.
    -   To book an appointment for assistance with general research,
        select the **Research Support** section, then click the option
        for **General Research Assistance**. Click on the ![screenshot
        of information
        icon](InfoIcon.png "screenshot of information icon") icon for
        more information about general research.
    -   To book an appointment for assistance with researching a
        specific topic, select the **Subject Areas** section, then click
        the option for the subject in which you are interested. Click on
        the ![screenshot of information
        icon](InfoIcon.png "screenshot of information icon") icon for
        more information about the librarian with whom you will be
        meeting.
3.  Once you have selected your research option, scroll down to see a
    calendar from which you can select a date when the librarian is
    available. For any day you select, there will be times listed when
    the librarian is available.
4.  Select a time and date that works with your schedule.
5.  You will be prompted for some details to schedule your appointment.
    -   Enter your first name.
    -   Enter your last name.
    -   Enter your email address.
6.  Press the **Confirm Appointment** button.
7.  You will receive an email confirming your appointment time.
8.  You will receive a reminder email about the appointment on the day
    of the appointment.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main [Home (Isidore
Home)](Home_(Isidore_Home) "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

## Uploading a SCORM Package {#uploading_a_scorm_package}

To upload a SCORM package:

1.  Navigate to the **SCORM Player** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on the **Upload New Content Package** tab.
3.  Click on **Browse\...** or **Choose File\...**, navigate to the
    location of the SCORM package on your computer, select it, and click
    on the **Upload File** button.
4.  The package should appear in the List of Content Packages.

## Configuring a SCORM Package {#configuring_a_scorm_package}

To configure a SCORM package:

1.  Navigate to the **SCORM Player** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Click on **Configure** underneath a SCORM package.
    -   Edit the content package name (if needed).
    -   Set an open date (required).
    -   Set a due date (optional).
    -   Set an accept until date (optional). This is a date that
        students don\'t see, but allows an instructor to set a grace
        period in which submissions can be submitted after the due date.
    -   Specific the number of attempts allowed.
    -   Choose whether to display the structure of the content package
        in the player.
    -   Choose whether to display the player controls.
    -   Select whether you would like scores to be sent to Gradebook,
        keeping in mind that the item in Gradebook will be scored out of
        100 points.
    -   When all settings have been adjusted, click on the **Update**
        button.

`     ``<text bytes="2358" sha1="fijorrfray52rtlmxma7nronjw8vmj4" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`As you're preparing video content, you need to consider individuals who are deaf, who are hard of hearing, or whose native language may not be the language the video was recorded in. Captions or transcripts may also help those who do not have speakers or who may be viewing the video in a noisy environment.`

All video content posted online or shown in class must either be
closed-captioned or have a written transcript to go along with it. An
easy way to accomplish this it to write a script before recording a
video that can be used for captioning or as a transcript.

Captions are text that is displayed while the video is being played, or
when users click on the **cc** button. They may include text of what is
spoken during the video, or may describe what viewers are seeing,
hearing, or experiencing.

[Learn more about accessible videos at the University of Washington\'s
\"Creating Accessible Videos\"
website](http://www.washington.edu/accessibility/videos/free-captioning/)

## Warpwire Video {#warpwire_video}

**Videos uploaded for classroom use by UD instructors will be
automatically closed-captioned by [Rev.com](https://www.rev.com).**

If you\'re uploading your course videos to Warpwire Video, there\'s a
quick and easy way to request closed-captioning from
[Rev](https://www.rev.com/) (a captioning service).

How to request captions from Warpwire:

1.  Locate the Warpwire video you wish to have captioned.
2.  Click on the **\...** (ellipsis symbol) next to it.
3.  Click on **Settings**.
4.  Click on the **Add** button next to \"Captions\".
5.  Click on **Request Caption**.
6.  Click on **Create Request**.
7.  Click on the **X**.
8.  Within 3-5 business days, captions for your video will be
    automatically added.

## YouTube

If you\'re uploading your course videos to YouTube, they have a built-in
feature that allows you to transcribe and auto-sync the captions.

[View YouTube captioning
instructions](https://support.google.com/youtube/answer/2734796?hl=en)

## Other Video Sources {#other_video_sources}

If you\'re using other video sources in your course, check to make sure
that captioning is available by clicking on the **cc** icon at the
bottom of the video. If captions are not available, you should supply a
written transcript to go along with the video. \<br /\>\<br /\> Return
to the main [Making content and media
accessible](Making_content_and_media_accessible "wikilink") page

`     ``<text bytes="1815" sha1="fynidopxzcxzhbuhi3azubtmnn2qbhi" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Microsoft Photos comes standard on all current Windows PCs. Although it is called “Photos” it contains an effective video editor that allows you to:`

-   Combine, trim, and split video clips
-   Add text, title screens, images, and effects to videos
-   Add narration and background music to videos
-   Save the edited video as an mp4 file

[Visit Microsoft\'s Photos Support
Site](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/photos-help-702104c6-7541-6757-d624-c0846b3bdbd3)
for more information.

## Quick Steps {#quick_steps}

1.  Open the Photos app on your computer by searching for \"Photos\" in
    the Windows search bar.
2.  Click on either option titled **Video Editor** \> **New video
    project** or **New video** \> **New video project**.
3.  Enter a name for your video and click **OK**.
4.  Use the tools to create and edit your video (see tutorials below).
5.  Click **Finish video** \> **Export**. This will save it to your
    computer as an mp4 file).

        total number of present, absent, excused, late, or left early
        statuses.

        and may include comments from the instructor. If there are
        comment bubbles displayed to you, you may click on them to read
        comments from your instructor.

`     ``<text bytes="2765" sha1="bcyai3hzip0lk8o9qgoiitli47wfuis" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`== Calculated Question ==`

\<youtube\>MBiRNmSPpBE\</youtube\>

A calculated question calculates new answers for every test, based on
variables whose value changes each time. The answer is based on a
formula, using those variables.

-   A variable definition has a name, a minimum and maximum value, and a
    number of decimal places.
-   A formula definition has a name, an mathematical expression that
    uses the variables, and a tolerance, so that answers within that
    tolerance of the answer are also considered correct.

Example: Kevin has {x} apples. He buys {y} more. Now Kevin has
[{x}+{y}]({x}+{y} "wikilink"). Jane eats {z} apples. Kevin now has { {w}
}.

The formula w in the example above would be defined as: {x} + {y} - {z}

More instructions and examples are provided on the page where you create
your calculated question.

## File Upload {#file_upload_1}

Presents a question or assignment that requires the user to upload a
file.

## Fill in the Blank {#fill_in_the_blank_2}

Presents users with a question followed by a text box in which they
enter the answer; each user\'s answer is compared to a list of allowed
answers.

## Hot Spot {#hot_spot}

Presents users with an image that they can click on and select an area
that answers the question. The instructor pre-specifies the area of the
image that is the correct answer.

## Matching

Presents users with a series of choices and possible matches.

Please see a video demonstration of the Hot Spot question type: \<br/\>
\<youtube\>uZo49dqU0BE\</youtube\>

## Multiple Choice {#multiple_choice_2}

Presents users with a question followed by a list of possible answers.
You can choose to have either one or several correct answers.

## Numeric Response {#numeric_response}

Presents users with a question followed by a text box in which they
enter a numeric answer; each user\'s answer is compared to a list of
allowed answers

## Short Answer/Essay {#short_answeressay_2}

Presents users with a question followed by a text box in which they
enter the answer.

## Student Audio Response {#student_audio_response}

Presents users with a question that they must answer audibly; recording
applet opens and allows user to record the answer using a microphone.

## Survey

Designed for collecting survey data; presents users with a question or
statement to which they respond using the rating scale of your choice:

-   Dichotomous: Choose from \"Yes, No\" or \"Disagree, Agree\".
-   Likert scales: Choose from semantic or numeric differentials (e.g.,
    Strongly disagree-Strongly agree, 1-5).

## Survey - Matrix of Choices {#survey___matrix_of_choices}

Presents users with a table made up of choices in the columns and rows.
Users can then make a selection by clicking one of the radio buttons.

## True/False {#truefalse_2}

Presents users with a statement that they must identify as being either
true or false. \<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Tests and
Quizzes](Tests_and_Quizzes "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

To view feedback:

1.  Navigate to the **CompFolio** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  On the **Home** page of CompFolio, you will see a list of
    categories. On the right hand side of each category are a series of
    colored boxes with numbers, each of which refers to the number of of
    requirements in the category as well as indicators of their
    statuses. Click on a category with a number in the green (Completed)
    or red (Reopened) box.
3.  Next to each requirement, you will see its status. Find a
    requirement that has the status of Completed or Reopened, and click
    on its title.
4.  On the requirement page, look for the **Feedback** section. Your
    instructor may provide either text comments or provide an attachment
    for you to review.
5.  Click the **Back** button to return to the main page of CompFolio.

    submitted, and reopened.

        the progress bar as a green bar and the number of requirements
        completed.
    -   The submitted requirements will appear second in the progress
        bar as an orange bar and the number of requirements submitted.
    -   The reopened requirements will appear third in the progress bar
        as a red bar and the number of requirements reopened.

To view your grades:

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  When you enter Gradebook, depending on what information your
    instructor has made available, you will see one or both of the
    following:
    -   **Overall Course Grade**: The course grade is a cumulative grade
        based on items you have completed. Any items you have not
        completed are not included in the course grade calculation
        unless your instructor has explicitly assigned zeroes to those
        items. A grade percentage appears in parentheses and shows the
        actual percentage derived from completed items.
    -   **Scores on Individual Gradebook Items**: The list of gradebook
        items shows each item name, its due date (if applicable), your
        grade, and any comments associated with the grade.

To view the Criteria Summary:

1.  Navigate to a gradebook item, assignment, assessment question, or
    discussion forum or topic that has a rubric associated with it.
2.  Click on the rubric icon to preview the rubric or navigate to the
    grading page.
3.  When the rubric loads, click on the **Criteria Summary** tab.
4.  If at least one student has been rated, you\'ll be able to see
    statistics for each criterion. If the option to \"adjust scores\" is
    enabled, and students\' scores fell between two ratings, their
    ratings will appear in columns titled \"Adjusted Scores\".
5.  To close this view, click on the \"X\" in the upper right-hand
    corner.

To view the Overview tool in course sites:

1.  Navigate to your course site.
2.  Click on **Overview**. You may already be on the Overview tool when
    you navigate to the course.
3.  Any information that the instructor has added will be displayed on
    the screen.

## Overview in Home (Isidore Home) {#overview_in_home_isidore_home}

To view the Overview tool in your Isidore Home:

1.  Click on the **Home** site in the upper left-hand corner of the
    Isidore screen.
2.  Click on **Overview**. You may already be on the Overview tool when
    you navigate to your home.

1.  Gives a list of all previous versions of that page, with the name of
    the user who altered it and the date.
2.  Allows you to view any previous version.
3.  Compare the contents of any version with the current version.
4.  Compare the contents of any version with the version immediately
    previous, to see what changes were made by each user.
5.  Allows you to revert to any previous version.

If you have accidentally deleted content from your page, you can use the
\'revert to this version\' option to revert to an earlier, correct
version, for example. \<br /\>\<br /\> Return to main

`     ``<text bytes="872" sha1="pbw4mz62lj37w295u5ix38924cr4sjp" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`To get the information on any page:`

1.  Navigate to the **Wiki** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Navigate to the wiki page you want to view the info of.
3.  Click on **Info**.

The following information is displayed:

1.  Permissions
2.  Lists all pages the page links to
3.  Lists all pages that link to this page
4.  Gives the page owner (usually the person who created it)
5.  Gives the global page name, to allow linking to it from outside the
    Wiki
6.  Gives the page permission details (the site you need to be a member
    of to see it)
7.  Gives details of when the page was last edited

\'Info\' also allows you to open the following versions of the page:

1.  Printer friendly version
2.  Un-editable HTML version
3.  An open document format (.odf) version (which can be opened in Open
    Office, for example)
4.  An RSS feed of recent changes

## Viewing your Profile {#viewing_your_profile}

To view your profile:

1.  Click on the circle that contains your initials or profile picture
    in the top right hand corner of Isidore.
2.  Click on the **Profile** link.
3.  Your profile is displayed on the screen and you can choose a photo
    to display in Isidore or record your name pronunciation if you wish.

## Changing your Profile Picture {#changing_your_profile_picture}

To change your profile picture:

1.  Click on the circle that contains your initials or profile picture
    in the top right hand corner of Isidore.
2.  Hover over the circle that contains your initials or profile picture
    next to your name in the pop up menu and click on **Change**.
3.  A \"Change Profile Picture\" window will pop up.
4.  Click the **Browse** or **Choose File** button to open up your
    computer\'s file explorer.
5.  Find the picture you would like to add and click open.
6.  Adjust the zoom and size of your picture using the buttons at the
    bottom of the picture.
7.  When you are finished, press **Save**.

## Adding your Name Pronunciation Recording {#adding_your_name_pronunciation_recording}

To record the proper pronunciation of your name with
[NameCoach](What_is_NameCoach? "wikilink"):

1.  Click on the circle that contains your initials or profile picture
    in the top right hand corner of Isidore.
2.  Click on the **Profile** link.
3.  You\'ll be able to record your name\'s pronunciation by clicking on
    the **Create Name Pronunciation** button.
4.  Make sure your information is correct in the recording popup window.
5.  At the bottom of the recording popup, you can record your name by
    having the NameCoach system call you, or by using a web recorder.
6.  Once you\'ve created your pronunciation recording, you can listen to
    it and re-record if necessary.
7.  Click the **Submit and Finish** button to create your name
    pronunciation recording.
8.  After the page has been refreshed, a play button will appear next to
    your name on your **My Profile** page.
9.  Click on the play button to listen to your name pronunciation
    recording.

## Reviewing Scores {#reviewing_scores}

To view students\' scores:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Click on the **Action** menu next to the assessment and select
    **Scores**.
3.  If more than one submission was allowed, select **All Submissions**
    from the \"View\" drop-down menu.
4.  You may use the \"Adjustment\" column to add or remove points, and
    the \"Comments for Students\" text box to enter comments for the
    student to review. Click on **Update** to save these changes.

## Reviewing Responses by Student {#reviewing_responses_by_student}

To view an individual student\'s submission:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Click on the **Action** menu next to the assessment and select
    **Scores**.
3.  Click on the student\'s name to view their submission.
4.  You may adjust scores for an individual question by entering points
    into the point text box. You may also enter comments for the student
    to review in the \"Comments\" text box at the top of the page, or
    for specific questions using the \"Comments for Student\" text boxes
    underneath each question. There\'s also a spot to add attachments.
    Be sure to save your changes by scrolling down to the bottom and
    clicking on **Update**.

## Reviewing Responses by Question {#reviewing_responses_by_question}

To view students\' responses by question:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Click on the **Action** menu next to the assessment and select
    **Scores**.
3.  Click on **Questions**.
4.  Navigate to each question by clicking on the question links labeled
    \"Q1\", \"Q2\", \"Q3\", etc.
5.  For each question, you can adjust points using the \"Score\" text
    box, enter comments for student review using the \"Comments for
    Student\" text box, or add an attachment. Be sure to click on the
    **Save** button before navigating to the next question.

    average for those ratings.

    corner.

`     ``<text bytes="4498" sha1="ado0rr0sf4q98hza4rimqjxti0fkxns" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`== Summary of site visits ==`

The following information is displayed on the \"Visits\" control from
the tool Overview page:

-   **Visits**: Total number of site visits.
-   **Users who have visited site**: Total number of distinct users that
    visited the site.
-   **Site members**: Total number of users that are member of the
    current site.
-   **Members who have visited site**: Total number and percentage of
    users that are site members and have visited the site. This number
    may be different from Unique Visits if there are visits from users
    that are no longer members of the site.
-   **Members who have not visited site**: Total number and percentage
    of users that are site members and have not visited the site.
-   **Average presence time per visit**: Average time an user stays
    present on the site, per visit.

A more detailed report can be obtained by clicking on the items above
(e.g., clicking on \'Members who have not visited site\' will display a
report of all site users that never visited the site).

Clicking on the **Show more** link will present a chart and table view
for a quick view of visits statistics. Some considerations:

-   Clicking on **By date** or **By user** will group statistics by date
    or user, respectively.
-   Selecting **Since site creation**, **Last 365 days**, **Last 30
    days** or **Last 7 days** will filter statistics accordingly.
-   Clicking on the chart image will produce a maximized version of the
    image.
-   Clicking on **View complete report** will display the full data for
    the current displayed statistics.

## Summary of activity {#summary_of_activity}

The following information is displayed on the \"Activity\" control from
the tool Overview page:

-   **Events**: Total number of site activity events (from the list
    specified on the tool Preferences page).
-   **Most active tool**: The tool that generated most events (from the
    list specified on the tool Preferences page). Hovering the mouse
    over the value will display the full tool title.
-   **Most active user**: The user that generated most events (from the
    list specified on the tool Preferences page). Hovering the mouse
    over the user EID will display the full user name.

A more detailed report can be obtained by clicking on the items above
(e.g., clicking on \'Most active user\' will display a report with total
activity per user, sorted by total activity).

Clicking on the **Show more** link will present a chart and table view
for a quick view of activity statistics. Some considerations:

-   Clicking on **By date**, **By user** or **By tool** will group
    statistics by date, user or tool, respectively.
-   Selecting **Since site creation**, **Last 365 days**, **Last 30
    days** or **Last 7 days** will filter statistics accordingly.
-   Clicking on the chart image will produce a maximized version of the
    image.
-   Clicking on **View complete report** will display the full data for
    the current displayed statistics.

## Summary of resource activity {#summary_of_resource_activity}

The following information is displayed on the \"Resources\" control from
the tool Overview page:

-   **Files**: Total number of existing site files (folders excluded)
    from the Resources tool.
-   **Files opened**: Total number and percentage of site files (folders
    excluded) from the Resources tool that were already opened for
    reading.
-   **Most opened file**: The site file (from the Resources tool) that
    were most opened for reading. Hovering the mouse over the value will
    display the full resource file name.
-   **User who has opened the most files**: The user that opened most
    site files (from the Resources tool) for reading. Hovering the mouse
    over the user EID will display the full user name.

A more detailed report can be obtained by clicking on the items above
(e.g., clicking on \'Files opened\' will display a report of all opened
files with the number of times each was opened).

Clicking on **Show more** link will present a chart and table view for a
quick view of resource activity statistics. Some considerations:

-   Clicking on **By date**, **By user** or **By resource** will group
    statistics by date, user or file, respectively.
-   Selecting **Since site creation**, **Last 365 days**, **Last 30
    days** or **Last 7 days** will filter statistics accordingly.
-   Clicking on the chart image will produce a maximized version of the
    image.
-   Clicking on **View complete report** will display the full data for
    the current displayed statistics.

`     ``<text bytes="1107" sha1="l2iroyz42cdij76pbnwnbstlywp5qj0" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Instructors may monitor students' usage of a flashcard set. To see students' progress through a flashcard set:`

1.  Locate the flashcard set for which you\'d like to see students\'

3.  On the Usage page, you will see a list of your students and the
    progress they have made through the card set.
    -   A card is counted as progress once a student views both side A
        and side B of any given card. Seeing both sides of the card
        counts as progress in regular mode as well as review mode.
    -   Colors are used on the progress bar to indicate progress. Red
        shows little progress. Orange is medium progress. Green is a
        fully completed flashcard set.
    -   Students may reset their progress, but this does not reset their
        usage in your view.
    -   Usage numbers remain even if you unpublish a card set from
        student view.
4.  To see which individual cards a student has viewed, click the
    \"Export Usage to Excel\" link to download a report of students\'
    progress for each card.

To view requirements:

1.  Navigate to the **CompFolio** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  On the **Home** page of CompFolio, click on a category to expand it
    and see its description and requirements.
3.  Requirements can have one of four statuses: Ready, Submitted,
    Reopened, and Completed.
    -   All requirements are Ready by default. This means you can submit
        an artifact to this requirement at any time.
    -   Requirements with the status of Submitted are requirements to
        which you have already submitted artifacts. The instructor in
        the course must review your submission before you can make any
        further action on this requirement.
    -   Requirements with the status of Reopened are requirements that
        you need to review and resubmit. These requirements will change
        back to the status of Submitted once you resubmit.
    -   Requirements with the status of Completed are requirements that
        you have completed. No further action is required.
4.  If the instructor has added additional details to a requirement,
    click on the \"View Details\" link after selecting the requirement
    to see that information.

## Viewing a Recording in Isidore - Instructors {#viewing_a_recording_in_isidore___instructors}

1.  Navigate to an Isidore site where Zoom is installed.
    -   You can use any Isidore site where Zoom is installed because ALL
        of **your** cloud recordings are available in each instance of
        the Zoom tool in Isidore.
2.  Click on the **Cloud Recordings** tab.
3.  Locate the meeting session that you\'d like to view.
4.  Click on the title of the meeting.
5.  Click on the recording that you\'d like to view.
6.  The recording will launch in a new window.

## Viewing a Recording in Isidore - Students {#viewing_a_recording_in_isidore___students}

1.  Navigate to the Isidore site where the meeting took place.
2.  Click on the **Previous Recordings** tab.
3.  Locate the meeting session that you\'d like to view.
4.  In the \"Recording\" column, click on the **Recording Details**
    link.
5.  Click on the recording that you\'d like to view.
6.  The recording will launch in a new window.

## Sharing a Zoom Recording {#sharing_a_zoom_recording}

Scheduled meetings will be shared in your Isidore site by default, so
for those meetings, students will just need to follow the steps above to
view the recording.

Recordings that you create from your [personal meeting
room](https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/201362843-What-is-Personal-Meeting-ID-PMI-and-Personal-Link-)
will **not** show up for students in Isidore, so you must share the link
to the recording if you want others to be able to see it.

### Method 1 {#method_1}

1.  Navigate to an Isidore site where Zoom is installed.
    -   You can use any Isidore site where Zoom is installed because ALL
        of **your** cloud recordings are available in each instance of
        the Zoom tool in Isidore.
2.  Click on the **Cloud Recordings** tab.
3.  Locate the meeting session that you\'d like to view.
4.  Click on the title of the meeting.
5.  Click on the **Share** link underneath the thumbnail of the
    recording.
6.  Copy the text in the popup window.
7.  Send the copied text via email to anyone with whom you\'d like to
    share the recording.
    -   **Note:** Recordings **cannot** be viewed by anyone outside of
        UD. To share with someone outside of UD, you will have to
        download the recording and share it as an MP4 via email or
        upload it into [Warpwire](Warpwire "wikilink").
    -   **Note:** Recordings are **NOT** locked down to your course
        roster. Anyone at UD with the link to the recording may view the
        recording.

### Method 2 {#method_2}

1.  You will receive an email whenever your recordings are ready to be
    viewed.
2.  Forward the email to anyone you would like to be able to view the
    recording.
    -   **Note:** Recordings **cannot** be viewed by anyone outside of
        UD. To share with someone outside of UD, you will have to
        download the recording and share it as an MP4 via email or
        upload it into [Warpwire](Warpwire "wikilink").

## Accessing Rubrics via Gradebook {#accessing_rubrics_via_gradebook}

To access Rubrics via Gradebook:

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Any gradebook items with a rubric associated to it will have a
    \"Preview Rubric\" icon in the \"Grade\" column that looks like a
    table. Click on the **Preview Rubric** icon to open the rubric.
3.  Each row contains a criteria that the instructor used to evaluated
    your work. The cell with the shaded background is the rating and
    corresponding point value the instructor selected. If the comment
    bubble is yellow, click on the **comment bubble** icon to read their
    comments related to each criteria.
4.  When you\'re finished reviewing the completed rubric, click on the
    **x** in the upper right-hand corner to close the window.

## Accessing Rubrics via Assignments {#accessing_rubrics_via_assignments}

To access Rubrics via Assignments:

1.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Any assignment with a rubric attached will have a \"Preview Rubric\"
    icon next to the assignment title.
3.  Click on the title of the assignment that has been returned by the
    instructor. The completed rubric will be displayed on the screen.
4.  Each row contains a criteria that the instructor used to evaluated
    your work. The cell with the shaded background is the rating and
    corresponding point value the instructor selected. If the comment
    bubble is yellow, click on the **comment bubble** icon to read their
    comments related to each criteria.
5.  When you\'re finished reviewing the completed rubric, you may
    navigate back to the main Assignments page, or another tool in your
    Isidore site.

*Note: Assignment rubrics can also be viewed via the Gradebook tool.*

## Accessing Rubrics via Tests & Quizzes {#accessing_rubrics_via_tests_quizzes}

*Note: Rubric grading is only available for short answer/essay and file
upload type questions.*

To access Rubrics via Tests & Quizzes:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Click on the **Feedback** link next to the assessment that contains
    the rubric. *Please note that the Feedback link may not be available
    to you if your instructor has chosen not to make feedback available
    to you or until a specific date.*
3.  Locate the short answer/essay question that was evaluated using a
    rubric.
4.  The completed grading rubric will appear on the screen. Each row
    contains a criteria that the instructor used to evaluated your work.
    The cell with the shaded background is the rating and corresponding
    point value the instructor selected. If the comment bubble is
    yellow, click on the **comment bubble** icon to read their comments
    related to each criteria.
5.  When you\'re finished reviewing the completed rubric, you can
    navigate back to the main Tests & Quizzes page or another tool in
    your Isidore course site.

## Accessing Rubrics via Forums {#accessing_rubrics_via_forums}

*Note: Even though rubrics can be used to evaluate discussion forums,
completed rubrics are accessed via the Gradebook tool.*

To access Forum Rubrics:

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Any gradebook items with a rubric associated to it will have a
    \"Preview Rubric\" icon in the \"Grade\" column that looks like a
    table. Click on the **Preview Rubric** icon to open the rubric.
3.  Each row contains a criteria that the instructor used to evaluated
    your work. The cell with the shaded background is the rating and
    corresponding point value the instructor selected. If the comment
    bubble is yellow, click on the **comment bubble** icon to read their
    comments related to each criteria.
4.  When you\'re finished reviewing the completed rubric, click on the
    **x** in the upper right-hand corner to close the window.

`     ``<text bytes="3578" sha1="cd9ct38vrpz4hgm539kse8ssi9qmwus" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`Your instructor may choose to assess your work with Rubrics. Rubrics are available in the Assignments, Gradebook, Forums, and Tests & Quizzes tools. An empty rubric may be previewed before you begin, if you're interested in seeing how your work will be evaluated.`

## Accessing Rubrics via Gradebook {#accessing_rubrics_via_gradebook_1}

To access Rubrics via Gradebook:

1.  Navigate to the **Gradebook** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Any gradebook items with a rubric associated to it will have a
    \"Preview Rubric\" icon in the \"Grade\" column that looks like a
    table. Click on the **Preview Rubric** icon to open the rubric.
3.  Each row contains a criteria that the instructor will use to
    evaluate your work. Each cell contains a rating and corresponding
    point value that the instructor will use to rate your work for each
    criteria. The comment bubbles can be used to review written comments
    from your instructor.
4.  When you\'re finished reviewing the completed rubric, click on the
    **x** in the upper right-hand corner to close the window.

## Accessing Rubrics via Assignments {#accessing_rubrics_via_assignments_1}

To access Rubrics via Assignments:

1.  Navigate to the **Assignments** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Any assignment with a rubric attached will have a \"Preview Rubric\"
    icon next to the assignment title.
3.  Click on the **Preview Rubric** icon to open the empty rubric.
4.  Each row contains a criteria that the instructor will use to
    evaluate your work. Each cell contains a rating and corresponding
    point value that the instructor will use to rate your work for each
    criteria. The comment bubbles can be used to review written comments
    from your instructor.
5.  When you\'re finished reviewing the completed rubric, you may
    navigate back to the main Assignments page, or another tool in your
    Isidore site.

*Note: Assignment rubrics can also be viewed via the Gradebook tool.*

## Accessing Rubrics via Tests & Quizzes {#accessing_rubrics_via_tests_quizzes_1}

*Note: Rubric grading is only available for short answer/essay and file
upload type questions.*

To access Rubrics via Tests & Quizzes:

1.  Navigate to the **Tests & Quizzes** tool in your Isidore course
    site.
2.  Begin taking an assessment by clicking on the title.
3.  When you come to a short answer/essay or file upload type question
    that will be evaluated using a rubric, you can click on the
    **Preview Rubric** button.
4.  An empty rubric will be displayed on the screen. Each row contains a
    criteria that the instructor will use to evaluate your work. Each
    cell contains a rating and corresponding point value that the
    instructor will use to rate your work for each criteria. The comment
    bubbles can be used to review written comments from your instructor.
5.  When you\'re finished reviewing the completed rubric, you can click
    on the **x** in the upper right-hand corner to close the rubric and
    continue taking your assessment.

## Accessing Rubrics via Forums {#accessing_rubrics_via_forums_1}

To access Rubrics via Forums:

1.  Navigate to the **Forums** tool in your Isidore course site.
2.  Any topic or forum with a rubric associated to it will have a
    \"Preview Rubric\" icon next to the title. Click on the **Preview
    Rubric** icon to open the rubric.
3.  Each row contains a criteria that the instructor will use to
    evaluate your work. Each cell contains a rating and corresponding
    point value that the instructor will use to rate your work for each
    criteria. The comment bubbles can be used to review written comments
    from your instructor.
4.  When you\'re finished reviewing the completed rubric, click on the
    **x** in the upper right-hand corner to close the window.

`     ``<text bytes="1337" sha1="jen2xkn0hpkvbhkqmzba5m1kxsgmpqm" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}**`Tokens for Attendance and Coursework Leniency`**

\_\_NOTOC\_\_ This class uses the Tokens App to allow students to
request leniency on course expectations. Tokens are given to each
student at the beginning of the term, which can be used through Isidore
to request leniency in the following categories.

-   Missing a class - Costs 1 Token
-   Late Assignment - Costs 1 Token
-   Retake a Quiz - Costs 2 Tokens

Note: Late assignments and quiz retakes will not be accepted one week
beyond the original due date, regardless of when the Token was
submitted.

Once a student has used all their Tokens, no additional leniency will be
granted. Students are advised to budget their Tokens wisely to avoid
this scenario. Tokens will no longer be usable past the date specified
in the Tokens App. The instructor will make an effort to either approve
Token submissions or provide an explanation for disapproving within two
business days. Students do not need to explain why they are using a
Token; however, the Token will be rejected if there is not sufficient
information provided to identify the Token's purpose. For example, for a
late assignment, the student must specify the name of the specific
assignment, but there's no need to explain why they couldn't complete it
on time.

`     ``<text bytes="1557" sha1="rhb6srkomrac1u92lqtjqycug0b5a5k" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`By default, you may take an interactive video quiz as many times as you wish, and your instructor will be able to see your latest responses. However, there is a setting that instructors may use where only your first responses to the interactive video questions will be recorded.`

To view an interactive video:

1.  Click on the Interactive Video tool wherever it has been added.
2.  Make sure you are on the \"Play Mode\" tab at the top of the menu.
3.  You will see the video, the list of questions and their respective
    timestamps when they occur in the video. You will also see play,
    pause, and rewind 10 seconds buttons at the bottom left corner of
    the video. The video duration and your position within the video is
    displayed in the bottom right hand corner.
4.  Press the play button on the video itself or at the bottom left hand
    of the video to start.
5.  The questions will pop up at the timestamps listed on the questions.
    Answer the questions when they pop up to progress through the video.
    -   **NOTE:** Once a question has been viewed or answered, rewinding
        the video 10 seconds will not give you the opportunity to answer
        the question again.
6.  After you answer a question, you will see whether or not you
    answered the question correctly and any feedback your instructor has
    provided.
7.  When the video is finished, you will be taken to the Results page to
    see the questions and your responses. You will also see a link to
    view the video without the questions popping up.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Interactive
Video](Interactive_Video "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

## Example 1 {#example_1}

**5 Tokens Available**

-   Missed Class 1 Token
-   Late Assignment (up to a week) 1 Token
-   Excuse a Quiz 2 Tokens
-   Excuse an Assignment 2 Tokens

Not eligible for token use:

-   Major assignments
-   Final projects
-   Final exams
-   Group work

## Example 2 {#example_2}

**10 Tokens Available**

-   Late for class 1 Token
-   Missed class 2 Tokens
-   Late Assignment (up to a week) 1 Token
-   2nd chance assignment 1 Token
-   Excuse a Quiz 2 Tokens
-   Assignment 2 Tokens

Not eligible for token use:

-   Major assignments
-   Final projects
-   Final exams
-   Group work

### Syllabus {#syllabus_1}

-   A statement regarding support for students with disabilities is
    included in the syllabus.

### Images {#images_1}

-   All images have alt text.

### Videos

-   All videos are captioned or have a transcript.

### Text

-   All text is at least 12 pt font.
-   Text has good contrast with the background color.
-   Titles, headings, and subheadings are included.
-   Bold or underlined text is used (in addition to color) when
    conveying meaning.

### Links or URLs {#links_or_urls}

-   All links or URLs are well-formatted with meaningful descriptions.

### Files and Documents {#files_and_documents}

-   All files are formatted with titles, headings, and subheadings.
-   All images have alt text.
-   All charts, graphs, and tables have alt text.
-   All charts, graphs, and tables have a description.
-   All links or URLs are well-formatted with meaningful descriptions.
-   All text is 12 pt font or larger.
-   Text has good contrast with the background color.
-   If file is scanned, it\'s been run through Sensus Access to make it
    an accessible file.

### Charts, Graphs, and Tables {#charts_graphs_and_tables}

-   All charts, graphs, and tables have alt text.
-   All charts, graphs, and tables have a description.
-   All charts, graphs, and tables have a title.
-   All tables have a header row or column.
-   A secondary method of identification has been used (besides color) -
    data labels, patterns, etc.
-   Charts, graphs, and tables have not been saved as images.

[Accessibility](Accessibility "wikilink") page `</text>`{=html}

## Overview

The overview provides a list of all site participants. By default,
participants are listed alphabetically. A count of participants appears
above the table.

To view your roster:

1.  Navigate to the **Roster** tool in your course site.
2.  You\'ll be on the Overview tab.
3.  From this page, you can listen to students\' NameCoach recordings,
    and see site participants\' total visits and last visit.

To customize the view:

1.  Next to \"Role\" and \"Group\", use the drop-down list to view one
    role, section, or group at a time.
2.  To find a particular person, type the name or user ID in the search
    box and click **Find**.
3.  Instructors can switch between viewing official photos or profile
    photos (pictures students upload themselves).
4.  Instructors can switch between list, cards, and photo grid.

\<br /\>\<br /\> Return to the main [Roster](Roster "wikilink") page

`     ``<text bytes="2051" sha1="g2oegjpnfuf5vjfry0v4xxkcrtbszc7" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}**`Note:`**` WebDAV currently does not work for users with official UD accounts due to 2-factor authentication. If you would like to use WebDAV, please contact the Center for Online Learning at `[`onlinelearning@udayton.edu`](mailto://onlinelearning@udayton.edu)` to be set up with a local account. `

WebDAV is a technology that allows you to easily transfer files and
folders from your local computer to your course site\'s Resources tool.
WebDAV stands for \"Web-based Distributed Authoring and Versioning\".

Once you have set up WebDAV, your computer will treat your Resources
section like any other folder on your local system. You will be able to
drag and drop files and folders from Resources just as you would in My
Computer in Windows or the Finder on a Mac.

For more information about WebDAV, including technical specifications
and major features, see the [WebDAV
FAQ](http://www.webdav.org/other/faq.html).

Things to consider:

-   There must be at least one object (i.e., file or folder) in your
    Resources section before you set up WebDAV.
-   If you are using WebDAV in Windows and have mapped a drive to the
    application via Network Places, you cannot delete a file by dragging
    it from the Network Place window to the Recycle Bin. Instead, select
    the file and click **Delete**.
-   WebDAV will require you to enter the siteID for each site you wish
    to access. The siteID is a unique identifier for each worksite. To
    find the siteID, in the worksite\'s menubar, click **Resources**.
    Click **Upload-Download Multiple Resources**. Your site ID should
    appear near the top of the page.

## Using WebDAV {#using_webdav}

1.  Log in to Isidore with your local account (See note at the top of
    this page).
2.  Navigate to the **Resources** tool in your course site.
3.  Click on **Transfer Files**.
4.  Highlight and copy the URL that is displayed under **Step 1**.
5.  Click on the link of the appropriate operating system under **Step
    2**.
6.  The appropriate instructions will be displayed on the screen.

## Editing links in Isidore\'s text editor {#editing_links_in_isidores_text_editor}

If you\'ve added a link via Isidore text editor, you can make a more
descriptive hyperlink by following these steps:

1.  Switch into edit mode so Isidore\'s text editor is available.
2.  Type in some descriptive text, either the name of the website or
    what action the user can expect when they click on the link.
3.  Highlight the part of the text you want to make the link.
4.  Click on the \"link\" button.
5.  Fill in the \"URL\" box by typing or pasting the link to the
    website. Click \"OK\".
6.  Save your changes.

\<youtube\>LUHLp7f-1nc\</youtube\>

## Editing links in Isidore\'s Lessons tool {#editing_links_in_isidores_lessons_tool}

If you\'ve added a URL via Isidore\'s Lessons tool, you can make a more
descriptive hyperlink by following these steps:

1.  Navigate to the Lessons page the URL was added to.
2.  Click on the \"edit\" icon (paper/pencil) next to the link.
3.  Clear out the text that\'s in the \"Item Name\" text box and type in
    some descriptive text, either the name of the website or what action
    the user can expect when they click on the link.
4.  Save your changes.

`     ``<text bytes="1632" sha1="1g3gtxt5abekccsl4in2oir9flj6idd" xml:space="preserve">`{=html}`By default, only course participants can see your videos.  However, you can choose to make the videos available to specific groups, everyone at UD, or to the public.`

To share your video library with others:

1.  Go into the Isidore course site where you want to share your
    Warpwire library.
2.  Click on the **Warpwire Video** tool.
3.  Click on the down arrow next to the title of video.
4.  Select **Share** from the drop down menu.
5.  Underneath the link to the video you have a variety of options when
    sharing your video
6.  Click on the **Share with additional Users and Groups:** menu and
    choose the permission level you prefer:
    -   **Share with additional Users and Groups:** - You can specify
        who has access to the videos.
    -   **Share with all Dayton Username users:** - You can specify that
        everyone who has a UD account can access the video.
    -   **Share with everyone on the web:** - You can specify that
        anyone can access the video.
7.  At the bottom there is a search box that allows you to share with
    specific users or groups. Type a user or group\'s name and then
    select them from the list when they appear to share the video with
    them. Note: You can only share videos with users who have an
    official UD Username.
8.  You can use the \"Share Link\" button to highlight and copy the link
    (URL) to the library. Then you can paste the link into an email to
    share it with the individuals you specified in the previous steps.
9.  When you are done, click the x in circle to exit Sharing settings.
    The settings you selected will be saved automatically.

Students seeking writing support may submit papers on Isidore to the
Write Place\'s Digital Drop-Off service where they will be reviewed
electronically by Write Place consultants.

## Guidelines

Spend 30 minutes reviewing a submission. The Write Place is not an
editing service; rather, your feedback should include comments about the
paper's content, organization, and mechanics.

## How To Review a Submission {#how_to_review_a_submission}

1.  In your **Isidore Home** tab, select the **Write Place** tool from
    the left menubar.
2.  Click **Staff** to see your individual reviewing page.
    -   Check the **Status** column in the **Documents for Review**
        section to see which submissions are awaiting or currently under
        review.
3.  Click the top most **Start Reviewing** in the **Feedback** column
    -   CAUTION: If you have spent more than several minutes on the
        Staff page, make sure to click the **Refresh** button
        ![](DDO_Refresh.jpg "DDO_Refresh.jpg") before starting a review
        to update the page.
4.  Review the submission:
    1.  Download the student's submission to your computer, then use the
        Review ribbon in Microsoft Word to add comments to the paper.
    2.  Add comments to the text box on the Feedback Form in Isidore.
5.  Submit your review.
6.  You will see the submission move from the **Documents for Review**
    section to the **Completed Review** section.
